webTitle: Solskjaer's late strike rewards impeccable United

fields.headline: Solskjaer's late strike rewards impeccable United
fields.trailText:
Aston Villa 0 - 1 Man Utd
Solskjaer's late strike rewards impeccable United.
fields.body:
Every yuletide Norway sends Britain a fir tree and this Christmas Manchester United have been especially grateful for the spruce finishing of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, whose goals have enabled them to regain and retain their eight-point lead at the top of the Premiership.

Yesterday, in the continued absence of the injured Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole plus the suspended Dwight Yorke, the Norwegian striker scored for the fifth time in as many league matches to bring United a late but thoroughly deserved victory against an Aston Villa side, who seldom lose but have yet to rediscover the art of winning on a regular basis.

Solskjaer's sharply taken header five minutes from the end denied Villa the muted satisfaction of taking a point from a game in which they were at times outplayed.

The goal crowned an impeccable display of passing and movement by United which suggested that by the end of the season the Liverpool defeat will have turned out to be more a hiccup than a convulsion. Certainly John Gregory, the Villa manager, was not arguing with the notion that Sir Alex Ferguson's six-times champions are as well set as ever for a first championship hat-trick.

"It's a foregone conclusion; unless Barcelona come with a late run," Gregory observed wrily. "Today all 10 of their outfield players were totally comfortable with their passing, which was simple and effective from start to finish."

True enough, although Ferguson admitted that "while Ole Solskjaer's a great finisher and might have had four today, when you create chances and can't get a goal it's always possible you might not get something from the game."

A similar thought probably occurred to Villa, except for them it was less a case of chances being missed than almost none being created. Fresh from a 2-1 win at Leeds, Gregory's side might have been expected to stretch Manchester United more than they did but with Dion Dublin, who missed Saturday's game because his wife had just had a baby, on the bench until the final 25 minutes the Villa attack appeared set on tickling the opposition to death with a feather duster.

With Paul Merson forced deep by Nicky Butt and Roy Keane, and the influence of David Ginola fleeting and peripheral, Gilles de Bilde enjoyed scant support as he took on Gary Neville and Wes Brown at the heart of United's defence. After half-time, with Merson making closer contact with the front two, Villa achieved some sort of attacking momentum and just past the hour Ginola cut in from the left before centring for De Bilde's goalbound header to force an instinctive, stretching save from Fabien Barthez.

Had Villa taken the lead it would have made a nonsense of the game's prevailing pattern; it would also have punished United for some earlier profligacy. Certainly Solskjaer should have done better than drag his shot wide after Barthez, way out of goal, had caught Villa's defence square with a perfect example of route one.

Just past the half-hour Scholes's run saw him well placed to meet David Beckham's cross at the far post, but David James managed to keep his header out. After the break Scholes missed the target with a shot and a header, and when Dublin arrived an improving Villa could glimpse something more than a bland, blank draw.

Then Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane worked the ball out to Beckham on the right and from another of his precise crosses, this one to the near post, Solskjaer settled the contest with a nod. United's last Boxing Day defeat was at Villa Park in 1989. Yesterday, for Gregory and his players, that result looked very much a ghost of Christmas past.

webTitle: Arsenal bounce back with Henry hat-trick

fields.headline: Arsenal bounce back with Henry hat-trick
fields.trailText:
Arsenal 6 - 1 Leicester
Henry hat-trick helps revive title challenge.
fields.body:
After their 4-0 hammering at Anfield, Arsenal might have been entitled to a Boxing Day hangover. Instead they produced a performance which made talk of a crisis look as ridiculous as the third place Leicester held before kick-off. All Arsène Wenger has to hope now is that history is about to repeat itself.

As the Arsenal manager celebrated an emphatic win and a first hat-trick for the club from Thierry Henry, his mind must have drifted to Boxing Day 1997. That afternoon Leicester were beaten 2-1 here and Arsenal embarked on an 18-match unbeaten run which saw them recover from 12 points adrift to snatch the title from Manchester United.

Whether this side can claw back an eight-point gap will depend to a good degree on their ability to reproduce displays like this on their travels. Despite scoring six goals here and five at home against Newcastle, Manchester City and Charlton, Arsenal have managed only eight goals in total away from Highbury. Nine wins out of 10 at home contrasts with two away.

Wenger knows what is required to win the title. "Manchester United need to drop their level and we need to be consistent," he said. "We have to keep confident at home but away we must be more efficient. I believe it's more a confidence problem than an attitude problem when you look at the possession and the chances we create away. I'm confident we can redress it." Trips to Charlton, Leicester and Coventry should tell.

For the time being, though, Arsenal will savour the way they ripped apart one of the country's strongest defences. After a subdued start they ultimately overwhelmed Leicester with that familiar mix of pace, movement and touch. Only several fine saves by Tim Flowers prevented double figures.

Having given Arsenal the lead with a sumptuous half-volley, Henry completed his hat-trick, set up two goals and even managed two headers on target. Matt Elliott walked off with the striker's shirt but rarely got that close to it when it mattered.

"Henry was outstanding," Wenger said. "He was involved in everything and very influential. That's the kind of game he can play. Week-in, week-out that is his target."

Not that Henry carried the team alone. Time and again Robert Pires and Silvinho combined to good effect down the left wing, helped by Leicester's strangely negative approach.

Rather than attacking a side whose confidence must have been low after that Anfield collapse, Leicester seemed intent on damage limitation, as if unable to accept that they could beat a side they began level on points with.

Their midfield lacked bite and until Ade Akinbiyi scored to make it 2-1 they had not managed a worthwhile effort on goal. That they registered three shots to Arsenal's 26 told the tale as they went down to their heaviest defeat since rejoining the top flight in 1996.

"Arsenal have got world-class players but we let them have a stroll," Leicester's manager Peter Taylor said. "We didn't have enough belief in ourselves that we could get a result. I have been full of praise for the players all season. They've worked hard, but today they didn't. I think they had a day off. It's the first time I have had to say that."

For all Arsenal's early possession they only fleetingly sparkled before Henry sent Pires's clever corner past a stationary Flowers in the 34th minute. And, although Alex Manninger's failure to hold a Trevor Benjamin header allowed Akinbiyi to give Leicester hope after Henry had set up Patrick Vieira for No2, Arsenal soon found another gear.

Henry turned Elliott from Lee Dixon's high pass to make it 3-1, the substitute Freddie Ljungberg scored with his first touch after Igor Stepanovs had hit the post from another Pires corner, and Nelson Vivas put Henry through for the fifth before the captain Tony Adams encapsulated Arsenal's confi dence by strolling forward to shoot in from an Henry cross. The challenge is to repeat this away from Highbury.

webTitle: Nationwide round-up

fields.headline: Nationwide round-up
fields.trailText: As Watford's slide down the First Division continued, both Nottingham Forest and Preston leapfrogged the former leaders to enhance their play-off credentials, while West Brom's 2-0 defeat at Sheffield United saw them miss the chance to move into third place.
fields.body:
As Watford's slide down the First Division continued, both Nottingham Forest and Preston leapfrogged the former leaders to enhance their play-off credentials, while West Brom's 2-0 defeat at Sheffield United saw them miss the chance to move into third place.

Forest's home win over Crewe came thanks to Gary Jones's 38th-minute goal, his first for the club, and despite a late red card for David Prutton. It ended a miserable run of four defeats in five games.

Preston, meanwhile, over came Wolves at Molineux by a similar scoreline, with Iain Anderson scoring the winner after 14 minutes.

The defeat came in front of Wolves' largest crowd of the season, many of whom were calling for the removal of the chief executive Jed Moxey long before the end.

It was also a blow for John Ward, the caretaker manager, in his quest to succeed Colin Lee on a more permanent basis. But it was a better afternoon for the First Division's other caretaker managers, with Eric Winstanley guiding Barnsley to a 1-0 victory over Burnley, courtesy of Chris Morgan's first goal of the season, and Nigel Worthington taking Norwich to a 3-2 win over bottom-of-the-table QPR .

Rangers were twice in front, but two goals from Iwan Roberts proved their undoing. "There are 22 games to go and a lot of points to play for but we have to start winning games," said Gerry Francis. "We can do it but we must stop talking about it and start doing it on the field."

Huddersfield's recent upwards surge continued as a 3-0 win against Tranmere, their fifth in six games, took them out of the relegation zone. "It's terrifying to think where we would be without these results," said their manager, Lou Macari.

Carl Asaba's hat-trick helped Gillingham to a 4-1 victory over Crystal Palace, although the home side were helped by Palace's continued profligacy from the penalty spot. Neil Ruddock missed the Eagles' fifth successive spot-kick, although Dougie Freedman later stopped the rot by scoring his side's consolation from the spot.

Millwall moved clear at the top of the Second Division after a 6-1 win over Colchester at the New Den. Neil Harris became the division's top scorer by scoring a hat-trick against a team which had won their previous three games.

Stoke were the only other side in the top eight to win, coming from behind to beat Bury 2-1. Second-placed Walsall lost 3-1 at Swansea to leave Millwall four points clear.

It was a day when some of the division's more celebrated runs were finally broken. Rotherham, the only league side to have scored in every game, were held to a 0-0 draw at home to Notts County; Wigan, unbeaten in 18 games, saw Lee Duxbury and Mark Allott secure a 2-1 win for Oldham .

Cambridge United will be less upset about the end of their 13-match - winless - run, Tom Young scoring the only goal of the game against Wycombe.

But Jermaine Defoe's goalscoring streak is showing no signs of letting up - the Bournemouth striker, on loan from West Ham, has scored nine goals in seven games after a brace against Oxford. Luton 's 3-2 win over Peterborough leaves Oxford seven points adrift at the bottom of the table, although Port Vale could yet challenge them for last place if their form fails to improve - a 1-0 reverse at Wrexham was their fourth defeat in succession.

Chesterfield maintained their lead at the top of the Third Division with a 2-0 win over Darlington at Saltergate, the biggest win of a low-scoring day in the division. But their lead remains four points after Brighton won 1-0 at Underhill, Barnet's fourth defeat in five games.

Cardiff slipped into fourth place after seeing their six-match winning streak come to an end at Plymouth, who beat them 2-1, both goals coming from Sean McCarthy. Leyton Orient took full advantage of their slip, leapfrogging into third place with a 1-0 win at Southend.

With bottom-placed Carlisle's game with Hartlepool postponed, the West Country derby, between two struggling sides, took on added importance. In the end the spoils were shared, with Jamie Campbell putting Exeter in front only for Eiffon Williams to equalise for Torquay in the last minute.

The draw allowed Halifax to move up to 22nd after a 1-0 win at Blackpool. Mansfield can only dream of such away success, losing on the road for the sixth successive time, 1-0 at Kidderminster.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Travel-sick Chelsea fail to go distance

fields.headline: Travel-sick Chelsea fail to go distance
fields.trailText:
Ipswich 2 - 2 Chelsea
Travel-sick Chelsea fail to go distance.
fields.body:
Chelsea's miserable record of failing to win an away match this season has been as frustrating as Roger Bannister's early efforts to break the sub-four-minute mile, according to striker Eidur Gudjohnsen.

This latest effort could be compared to one of Bannister's many failed attempts: full of running early on when the dream burned brightly only for them to stumble across the line looking like a shadow of the men who had started.

It had been Gudjohnsen, with two goals in the opening 17 minutes, who had put Chelsea on track to break their appalling sequence. There was a verve and swagger about the London dilettantes at this stage but once Ipswich had punctured that early arrogance Chelsea threw away their advantage spectacularly.

It extended the side's run without an away win to 15 matches, stretching back nearly nine months.

"We are afraid of winning at the moment," claimed Gianfranco Zola. "Sometimes we are too cautious and that is costing us a lot. The fact is we didn't hold our position on the pitch the way we should have. We should have been more in control of the situation."

Gudjohnsen had justified Claudio Ranieri's decision to partner him up front with Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink when after only eight minutes he found a gap in the home defence to sidefoot home Mario Melchiot's low cross.

Nine minutes later there was a facsimile. This time Hasselbaink was the provider for the Icelandic to nip in and tuck away his sixth goal this season.

But Dennis Wise wasted an opportunity to put the match beyond Ipswich before half-time when he ran on to Hasselbaink's through-ball in the 33rd minute only to shoot weakly at Richard Wright.

It proved to be significant because 10 minutes later James Scowcroft headed Fabian Wilnis's cross beyond Ed de Goey and Chelsea's self-belief drained away. "When you have a two-goal lead and are playing quite well you don't expect to end up like that," said Zola.

Chelsea's lack of confidence was perfectly illustrated in the 77th minute when Wise spurned another fabulous opportunity, somehow contriving to miss from less than two yards when faced with a gaping goal after Wright parried Zola's shot to his feet.

Just as in the first half it was a turning point because seven minutes later the equaliser arrived. Herman Hreidarsson's cross was headed across the goalmouth by Scowcroft for Marcus Stewart to hit a shot which squirmed through De Goey's legs.

It was no more than the self-styled "Tractor Boys" deserved after a stirring fightback. "There's a spirit at this club which has taken a long time to build up," said George Burley, the Ipswich manager. "We battled away, never gave up and never let our heads drop."

To Chelsea, an away victory must look as impossible as the four-minute mile once looked to Bannister. But as Gudjohnsen no doubt told his team-mates, Bannister persevered and finally succeeded.

webTitle: Three-goal Phillips keeps Bradford on relegation slide

fields.headline: Three-goal Phillips keeps Bradford on relegation slide
fields.trailText: Bradfprd 1 - 4 Sunderland
fields.body:
Sunderland stepped up their pursuit of a place in Europe by rising to third in the table on the back of a Kevin Phillips hat-trick, albeit against the bottom side in the table who, if they have not already thrown in the towel, have it at least poised and flapping over the ropes.

This was Bradford City's third defeat in a row and although the Sunderland manager Peter Reid talked up their capabilities - "They caught us on a hot day when we had a lot of cylinders firing," - they now face Liverpool, Leicester, Manchester United, Sunderland again and Arsenal, a daunting programme that could put paid to their chances of survival.

Sunderland may not be the most formidable opposition in the top flight but they are among the best organised and they gave their hosts more problems than they could handle yesterday.

The Wearsiders' midfield is little more than ordinary but they make up for their lack of creativity by speed of thought, moving the ball quickly to their frontmen and augmenting their attacks by pushing their full-backs forward as wingers, a forceful game plan which left Bradford back-pedalling for most of the match.

The only surprise was that Sunderland took so long to score. Don Hutchison burst through in the third minute but Gary Walsh was able to palm away his weak shot. Then Phillips, back after missing Saturday's victory over Manchester City due to a one-match ban, managed to put the ball over the bar from practically on the goalline.

Bradford looked to have held out as the half-time whistle approached but a defensive mix-up gave Sunderland a throw-in on the left, Michael Gray crossed and Niall Quinn, after being denied by Walsh at the far post, poked in the rebound.

The home side were caught cold again just after the break. Gavin McCann's pass set Phillips haring away and his right-foot finish was clinical, giving him only his sixth league goal this season.

His aggregate was soon to improve. In the 55th minute Hutchison played a sweet through ball out of defence and Phillips shot home from the left. Robbie Blake, on as a substitute for Jamie Lawrence, bundled in a consolation goal from a corner, but Phillips was not finished, sprinting from left to right across the area then squeezing in a shot from the far post.

There was still time for Phillips to miss a penalty after Wayne Jacobs had chopped down Alex Rae, and the drama increased when an Elvis lookalike in a white, flared suit ran on to the pitch and genuflected at the feet of the striker. webTitle: Thompson torments Everton then Breen twists the knife

fields.headline: Thompson torments Everton then Breen twists the knife
fields.trailText:
Everton 1 - 2 Coventry
Breen twists the knife after Thompson torment.
fields.body:
The shorter Everton's injury list becomes, the worse their results become. Conceding two near identical goals from set-pieces led to a fourth defeat in five games for the Blues, and suddenly the relegation places are looming horribly. Coventry, still in 18th place, are now only three points behind them.

To make matters worse Coventry's goalkeeper Chris Kirkland required treatment at the end of the game after appearing to be hit by an object thrown from the crowd behind his goal.

The afternoon started well enough. Making his first Everton start since November 1998 - injury has confined him to three appearances as substitute since rejoining from Newcastle - the fans rose as one to welcome Duncan Ferguson.

The big man looked about as mobile as a lighthouse; on its own terms a lighthouse is crudely effective and so too was Ferguson. Despite apparently being unable to jump without being previously advised in writing, the Scot nevertheless won his fair share of headers by anchoring himself firmly and waiting with arms extended to prevent anyone else coming too close. Coventry's defenders bounced off him, and during a truly awful first half Ferguson did at least bring two saves from Kirkland.

At the other end Coventry barely registered as an attacking force for 40 minutes. Gordon Strachan's current and questionable strategy is to play his £6.5m striker Craig Bellamy wide on the left, partnering Mustapha Hadji up front with Ysrael Zuniga, but his most creative force was unquestionably the former Liverpool player David Thompson, bought in the summer for £3m.

When Coventry eventually began to get their act together Thompson, playing at right wing-back, was involved in every decent move. He also got into good positions only to lose his head, first firing horribly wide when he had time to control Zuniga's flick on, and then badly losing control when unmarked on the penalty spot after Zuniga's pull-back.

When it came to delivering a dead ball, however, he was accuracy personified, and halfway through the second period his free-kick from 40 yards picked out Hadji's run to perfection, allowing the Moroccan to glance a header across Thomas Myhre and into the far corner.

Ferguson led the fightback, his right-foot shot bringing the best save of the match out of Kirkland, and it was the big man's touch which set up Scot Gemmill to volley home the equaliser in the 85th minute.

The cheers of relief were premature. From around the same distance but the opposite flank Thompson again flighted a free kick into the area; Myhre's advance lacked conviction and Gary Breen guided the ball home for his first goal in three years.

Worrying times for Walter Smith, though as at Charlton last Saturday, he felt his side did not deserve to lose. Strachan was simply thankful for small mercies: "Any win is a big one just now."

webTitle: Revitalised Bolton happy to settle for second best

fields.headline: Revitalised Bolton happy to settle for second best
fields.trailText:
Bolton 2 - 0 Sheff Wed
Bolton happy to settle for second best.
fields.byline: Mark Ogden at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
The Bolton manager Sam Allardyce urged his team's supporters to recreate a 70's atmosphere here yesterday, but it was his players who turned the clock back in a stormy encounter with Sheffield Wednesday.

Allardyce recalled his days as a Bolton player when the club's former home, Burnden Park, had a reputation as one of the more hostile venues in the country. However, the dismissal of the defender John O'Kane and a touchline argument between Allardyce and the Wednesday coach Martin Hodge gave the Bolton manager a trip down Memory Lane that he could have done without.

The tetchy atmosphere on the pitch certainly took the shine off Bolton's sixth win in seven league games, a result that leaves them 10 points behind the runaway First Division leaders Fulham. Despite having little money to spend, Allardyce has guided his team into the top two thanks to sound management and the ability to spot a bargain in the transfer market.

That ability was borne out by the outstanding performance of Colin Hendry, who is on loan for three months from Coventry City. The 35-year-old Scotland international scored at one end and made life impossible for the Wednesday striker Efan Ekoku at the other. On the rare occasions that Wednesday ventured into the Bolton half, Hendry and Gudni Bergsson proved an impregnable barrier for the hapless Owls.

The home side were always in control, but they failed to take advantage of the many chances they created, even their opening goal through Dean Holdsworth owed more to luck than good skill.

Gareth Farrelly's long throw was met by Holdsworth at the near post, but his header showed no signs of troubling the Wednesday goalkeeper Kevin Pressman. But the ball looped high into the air before dropping over Pressman and into the net. Holdsworth celebrated, but with the air of an embarrassed man.

There was no such problem for Hendry, who scored his first goal for his new club, powering his header past Pressman after meeting Kevin Nolan's well-placed cross.

With the game just six minutes into the second half, it was clearly a safe three points for Bolton. O'Kane's dismissal, for hitting Alan Quinn, cost them a man but it hardly showed.

Fulham may be uncatchable at the top of the First Division, but Bolton are opening a gap of their own between second and third place. It will take a resilient team to catch them.

webTitle: Liverpool rocked by Riverside revolution

fields.headline: Liverpool rocked by Riverside revolution
fields.trailText:
Middlesbrough 1 - 0 Liverpool
Liverpool rocked by Riverside revolution.
fields.byline: David Hopps at the Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
Three matches into Terry Venables' invigorating arrival upon Teesside and Middlesbrough's goal has yet to be breached. Another obsessive and resolute defensive display, allied to a goal stolen by Christian Karembeu late in the first half, will strengthen the belief that their Premiership status can be maintained.

Venables' shameless emphasis upon defending deep and in numbers, so negating Liverpool's counter-attacking style, contributed to an often dire contest that for the first hour was almost devoid of incident, but his tactical astuteness could not be faulted.

Gérard Houllier's young side was outwitted and the Liverpool manager pronounced himself stunned. "We kept the ball, they kept the result," he said. "They just sat back and waited. I have lost some games in my life but this was one of the strangest."

Houllier's conclusion that Venables was "a very lucky man" was an assessment that left Venables wreathed in smiles. Here was one old fox at least that had survived the Boxing Day hunts unscathed.

Middlesbrough clung on, close to exhaustion. For the home fans the sight of Gianluca Festa being sick on the pitch before the start of the second half was a symbol of their heroic resistance; for Liverpool, a suitable comment on their shortcomings.

If successive victories against Manchester United and Arsenal had convinced Liverpool that their old authority was about to be restored, their self-esteem was surely punctured by a display in which they had neither the wit nor the desire to make good an abundance of possession.

Victory at the Riverside would have put them third, but there were few signs of Champions League shrewdness. Stephen Gerrard was a rare exception, as he sought to rally Liverpool almost single-handedly and it was appropriate that their last attack saw him in the thick of things, desperately seeking an equaliser.

The Cleveland hills were lightly dressed in snow and an overnight frost had left the surface occasionally treacherous underfoot, but the chief betrayal lay in Liverpool's prolonged inactivity. One might have imagined that Liverpool spent Christmas Eve watching Independence Day and were waiting for the Americans to give them a plan of attack.

They were orderly enough, but half chances for Michael Owen and Marcus Babbel apart, they produced nothing of note as their own lack of wit played into Middlesbrough's hands.

Middlesbrough's goal was a blessed relief. Karembeu picked out Curtis Fleming on the right of the area. Fleming's shot possessed enough power to squirm away from Sander Westerveld and Karembeu dashed in to poke home his second Middlesbrough goal.

Venables' most potent attacking gambit has been to shake the complacency from Karembeu and the Frenchman might also have created a goal after 15 minutes when Noel Whelan, 12 yards out and with time at his disposal, pulled his shot across goal. Oh Noel, Noel, Noel...

Owen just had time to spurn two inviting opportunities - a header too high from Gerrard's low cross and a scuffed shot after Emile Heskey had teed him up - before he was replaced eight minutes into the second half by Robbie Fowler.

Fowler has been the subject of a £12m bid from Chelsea, but to accept that, on this evidence, would be a huge risk and his sprint and shot from 25 yards at least drew the Middlesbrough goalkeeper Mark Schwarzer into action.

Gary McAllister's introduction had also brought Liver pool the veneer of a passing game but as much as Gerrard furiously drove his team-mates forward, there were too many under-performers - Nick Barmby, against his old club, prominent among them - for Liverpool to find a solution.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Jansen inspires Rovers revival

fields.headline: Jansen inspires Rovers revival
fields.trailText:
Blackburn 2 - 1 Birmingham
Jansen inspires Rovers revival.
fields.body:
A holiday that will not be remembered with too much fondness by Trevor Francis was concluded here yesterday when a controversial injury-time free-kick allowed the hosts to collect three points and move above his Birmingham team and into third place.

In the wake of Saturday's home draw with QPR it was a result that did little for the St Andrews club's promotion hopes. But given the performance of Blackburn's Matt Jansen, it may yet prove to be a watershed moment in Graeme Souness's reign as their manager.

Jansen had lost his place in recent weeks as Mark Hughes and Marcus Bent arrived to intensify competition for places. If he continues the new year how he ended the old, Jansen will not need to worry about a lack of first-team football again.

The controversy stemmed from a collision between Jerry Gill and Damien Duff which brought Rovers a free-kick which was taken by David Dunn and only half-cleared by Darren Purse and Michael Johnson. The ball broke kindly for the unmarked Jansen who swept in his second goal of the game, his ninth of the season, from 15 yards. The final whistle, seconds later, brought protestations by Birmingham and a hasty departure from Francis, who declined to share his opinions with the media.

"Birmingham will be frustrated at the way they lost; I think they felt Duff went down too easily," said Souness. "I assume that is what the fuss was about. It was a day when we had to grind out the result and the only really attractive part of it was the three points."

Actually Jansen's first goal was the only really attractive part of the contest, stemming from a clearance by the replacement goalkeeper John Filan and which was helped into his path by Mark Hughes.

Jansen skipped over a lunge from Danny Sonner and left Purse and Johnson on the seat of their pants in the penalty area before switching to his right-foot and driving the ball past Ian Bennett. It deserved to settle a dour game.

But Rovers' defence failed to challenge Johnson at Steve Robinson's 88th-minute corner and after a weak attempted stop by Filan, his defender Martin Taylor could only help Purse's header over the line.

webTitle: Georgi relives City's bad old days

fields.headline: Georgi relives City's bad old days
fields.trailText:
Man City 0 - 0 Derby
Georgi relives City's bad old days.
fields.body:
For the returning Georgi Kinkladze, it must have felt as though he had never been away. This was a throwback to inglorious days of old for Manchester City who were jeered off the pitch after perhaps the most comprehensive 0-0 thrashing of the season.

Joe Royle's team have now taken only five points from a possible 30 and with Middlesbrough, Derby and Coventry all showing signs of recovery, City have only goal difference keeping them above the relegation zone. The fans' discontent is becoming increasingly voluble and the players look suffocated by anxiety.

When the crowd's foreboding descends over Maine Road, as it did yesterday, there are few more dispiriting venues to be a home player. The ball is transformed into an object of fear and professionals can be reduced to moments of amateurism.

"It's a confidence thing," said Royle, and for long spells here his players could not have looked more inhibited had they been clad in straitjackets. The middle hour, in particular, must have made his teeth hurt.

It was somewhat paradoxical therefore that the best early chances fell to City and, in particular, the bewildering Paulo Wanchope. "We could have been three up in the first three minutes," blustered Royle, although that was conveniently overlooking the next 87 in which Derby totally overwhelmed their hosts.

"After the first couple of minutes we should have had four, five, maybe six goals," said their manager Jim Smith. "We have thrown the game away."

The best of their opportunities arrived two minutes into the second half when Kinkladze set off on a meandering run from his own half before threading a pass into Deon Burton's path. The striker's shot cannoned against the underside of the crossbar with television pictures, according to a relieved Royle, showing it may have crossed the goalline before bouncing out.

The subsequent debate about action replays would not have mattered, however, if Christie had knocked the rebound into an empty net but his flicked attempt at the dropping ball was negligent.

"From where I was standing, the ball bounced dead on the line," said Smith. "But it was a bad miss from Christie. I thought he was being flashy."

webTitle: Fulham astride the summit while Watford just plummet

fields.headline: Fulham astride the summit while Watford just plummet
fields.standfirst: First Division
fields.trailText:
Fulham 5 - 0 Watford
Fulham sitting pretty while Watford plummet.
fields.body:
Fulham began the second half of their season as if they mean to match the 58 points of the first half and break all records. At noon yesterday they started slowly, gained a penalty and tore Watford apart, with a hat-trick by Barry Hayles at the core of the demolition.

As their captain Chris Coleman said: "It was not the game we thought it was going to be in early November." Then, after 15 games each with Watford unbeaten and a point ahead of Fulham, this had been seen as a summit meeting. But just after Guy Fawkes' Night Watford blew up. They lost at home to Sheffield Wednesday and have now gained one point from eight games. For them summit has become plummet.

It is hard to see how they will pull out of it. New Year resolution would help - shape, organisation and pace in defence, too. Against Hayles and Louis Saha, the two Palmers, Steve and the sweeping Carlton, were repeatedly caught for speed. Ahead of them the formation was fluid (charitably), chaotic (honestly).

Graham Taylor acknowledged his players' loss of form. "They've been hit over the head for seven weeks," he said, "but in the end it's the basics and they've got to do it. We kept it calm for 30 minutes, conceded two bad goals and fell away." Even if confidence picks up, they play Fulham again on January 20.

Fulham typically stuttered at the start. They have fallen behind three times in four games in their march towards the Premiership, perhaps to make it more exciting. "If you let them hit their rhythm, you're in trouble," said Taylor. Watford did and were.

The problem for Watford's defense was not just straight-line speed but quick turns and slick interplay. Darren Ward was caught by Hayles's turn to concede the penalty for Saha. After Hayles had bundled in the second as Saha headed a corner against the bar, Fulham hit their straps as well as rhythm.

Lee Clark and Bjarne Goldbaek crackled behind the front two as Hayles added a tap-in and a header and the £2m Latvian Andreas Stolcers scored his first for the club. A fan waved a chequered flag. Watford could have done with a white one.

Asked how Fulham might do in the Premiership, Taylor was guarded. "They are a very good side," he said before adding: "I think they have three Premiership players." They remained unnamed and are unlikely to be in defence. But the whole lot have the belief in themselves and team-mates that has served Ipswich well.

"Jean Tigana lets us express ourselves," said Coleman, bearing a chocolate brick from Mohamed Al Fayed. The chairman's shop is now stocking a white wine, Domaine La Dona Tigana, too, indicating the manager's "skill, patience and foresight, now available in bottles".

But Tigana thinks football first. "I need 25 players all as capable as each other," he said. Watford could do with even one less incapable than the rest.

webTitle: Curbishley fumes as Hammers run riot

fields.headline: Curbishley fumes as Hammers run riot
fields.trailText:
West Ham 5 - 0 Charlton
Curbishley fumes as Hammers run riot.
fields.body:
West Ham, with Paolo di Canio in irrepressible form, proved far too strong for Charlton and unless their near neighbours wise up fast they could be heading for the big fall. Alan Curbishley knows it and lambasted his normally resolute team afterwards.

For Harry Redknapp and the Upton Park faithful, however, this was a day of pure joy. West Ham's forwards took turns to wear the party hats but, almost inevitably, Di Canio donned the most colourful of all - though he only just shaded the artful Frédéric Kanouté, who scored twice. The Italian set the tone after 12 minutes with a wondrous backheeled goal which went in off a Charlton defender.

After that the party rolled, with a supine Charlton offering little apart from Claus Jensen's midfield endeavours. It was the Hammers' biggest win of the season and gave ample support to Redknapp's assertion that his team can finish high up the Premiership.

Conversely, it was Charlton's heaviest defeat of the campaign, extending their dismal away run to six defeats. Even on the short journey through the Blackwall Tunnel, they can still find no light to illuminate their travels. Curbishley partly blamed himself: "I think someone forgot to tell them it was a local derby."

That was the mildest of his verbal cuts. Charlton's manager for the best part of the last 10 years said: "I don't think I've ever seen 11 Charlton players play so badly. We've had good results here in the past so I've got to take it today, totally smashed as we've been.

"I don't think West Ham had to play out of their skin. If anything, the score flattered us. We've got no excuses today. To put my finger on it would take all afternoon. Anything you want to say about my team today, you can write it and put my name to it."

Redknapp took a more sympathetic view. "I had four attackers out there who can scare the life out of anybody. Kanouté is frightening and Paolo is a special talent. It's a long time since we've had so many good, such exciting players at the club."

Charlton played into the hands of Di Canio, Kanouté and, less frequently, the home debutant Titi Camara. If their extensive repertoire was not enough, Trevor Sinclair provided the best shot of the game, a 25-yard volley that cannoned in off a post for the fourth goal.

The damage had been done much earlier, Di Canio's audacious goal being followed six minutes later by the most eye-catching move of the game. Sinclair delivered a long-range backheel from the touchline that set Kanouté free to play the ball off Mark Kinsella as though the Charlton man was a wall before driving with the outside of his right foot past the bewildered Dean Kiely.

Di Canio set up a routine third goal by outmanoeuvring two defenders to deliver a cross to the far post where Frank Lampard chipped in. Richard Rufus, with a tame header, and Jonatan Johansson spurned wonderful chances to bring some respectability to the scoreline which worsened for Charlton when Michael Carrick's intelligent through-ball sent Kanouté through to stab home a simple fifth goal six minutes from time.

Afterwards, Redknapp indicated that his transfer activity was not over when he confirmed that an exchange deal involving his captain Steve Lomas and Rangers' Italian defender Lorenzo Amoruso was still a possibility. "I like Amoruso, he's a good player and I'd really like to have him here if I could," said West Ham's manager."

webTitle: Brave Hearts battle hard for city pride

fields.headline: Brave Hearts battle hard for city pride
fields.trailText:
Hearts 1 - 1 Hibernian
Brave Hearts battle hard for city pride.
fields.body:
This was the sort of impassioned Edinburgh derby, played on a freezing Boxing Day afternoon, which would have heated up the nether regions of Sir Walter Scott's statue. Hearts and Hibs traded blow and counter-blow before Alex McLeish's side had to settle for two points dropped in their pursuit of Celtic.

Stuffed with festive fuel, a packed Tynecastle bayed as these two sides repeatedly inflicted pressure on each other. Hibs were marginally the better team, though in this match too many attempts at goal were blazed improbably wide. This was not an exhibition of finishing.

For Craig Levine, a young Hearts manager facing a gargantuan task, it was another day of progress. The days of recent years have gone when Hearts ground Hibs into submission to the extent that their city rivals belted six past them the last time they met. Levine has now had two wins, two losses and this draw in his first month in charge, which will ease his anxiety.

Hearts could be grateful to Antti Niemi, their Finnish goalkeeper for saving them a point. Niemi in the right mood is capable of the most extraordinary acrobatics, especially when his team is under siege. His leap and save from Mixu Paatelainen after 54 minutes both kept Hibs at bay and paved the way for his side's equaliser.

Tynecastle is a tight, fraught environment which encourages this sort of rugged encounter. The mandarins of Hearts want to abandon its limited 18,000 capacity but perhaps they also wish to be rid of the combustion the arena injects into every match. For coaches on the touch-line this type of racket is not the place for calming tactics.

The pace here was unrelenting and Hearts lost Kenny Milne after 21 minutes to injury, but one man remained aloof.

Not for the first time, Hibs were served serenely by Franck Sauzée, a French defender in his twilight years, who nonetheless still brings a sure instinct to the bedlam. On a freezing afternoon, Sauzée plodded around in green gloves, his only concession to this match affecting him.

Hearts pounded Hibs without truly troubling Nicky Colgan, a bluntness which allowed Hibs to weather first-half pressure before filching their lead. When the play unravelled once more from a Hearts attack after 41 minutes, green shirts suddenly swarmed towards Niemi's goal. Ulrik Laursen's clever pass slid across Niemi's line of vision for Stuart Lovell to arrive at the far post to prod Hibs ahead.

Gary McSwegan brought Hearts level with typical opportunism after 58 minutes, lashing his shot low from 20 yards in off a post past a startled Colgan.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Week 4: Oahu to Sydney

fields.headline: The highs and lows of Xmas down under
fields.standfirst:
After last week's close shave in Hawaii, Milly clears her head by leaving for Sydney in time for her birthday and the arrival of boyfriend Josh
Hear Milly talk about spending Christmas in the antipodes.
fields.trailText: Week 4: Oahu to Sydney After last week's close shave in Hawaii, Milly clears her head by leaving for Sydney in time for her birthday and the arrival of boyfriend Josh.
fields.body:
Well, this week's report follows on almost instantly from the slightly nasty end of last week - and luckily, everything picked up straight away.

I returned to the Hawaiian hostel feeling pretty glad to have safely escaped the weird guys, when straight away someone asked if I wanted to go snorkelling at Hunama Bay.

Hunama Bay, as most of Oahu, is a pretty touristy spot, but it was still beautiful. We hired a snorkelling set for the day and, conquering my past inability to snorkel without choking on seawater, I enjoyed the afternoon swimming along reefs with a variety of strange and wonderful fish. It felt like my own tranquil world and was exactly what I needed after the night before.

After that we took the bus - the buses in Hawaii are incredibly good value - to Sandy Beach. It was a gorgeous and amazingly empty spot with reasonable surf where we stopped to eat papaya, which I used my Swiss Army knife to slice - never leave home without one!

The evening was kind of a dead loss as my English roommate Boe and me are under 21. We resorted to asking another hosteller to buy us a bottle of wine, which made us both feel like young children again.

I was more than a little glad to be leaving Hawaii. I received an email through the website where someone had dubbed it the "floating rip-off island" - very astute. If you want my advice, do what I should have done and was told to do - get to Honolulu and head straight out again for one of the other islands.

When I reached Sydney - at a sensible time of day for a change - it occurred to me that I'd yet again not bothered to book ahead. In the airport, there was a wall of free phones to various hostels, so I chose the Funk House, because it claimed to have a good atmosphere and I liked the name. Besides, I knew it was only for three days so I wasn't being particularly fussy.

At first the hostel seemed nice, even though it was located in the distinctly seedy Kings Cross area, where the majority of city hostels are. Then I got to know people. I think my major problem is this: I had it so lucky with the people I met in Global Village Vancouver, I just assumed everybody would be like that.

I guess the essential reason for my disappointment is that there are so many British people in Sydney that there isn't that great multicultural feel of Vancouver, and drinking seems to be the one and only pastime of the residents.

Still, as someone has said to me, no one would believe you had it good all round the world. And as I say, without the lows, how can you appreciate the highs??

Christmas Day was spent on Bondi Beach - that night a bunch of us from the hostel went to a party on a boat. I only describe this briefly because although both were kind of fun, it's the people you're with that make any occasion and I felt I didn't have a lot in common with them. Who knows, maybe it was just a bit of Christmas homesickness making me feel that way...

Moving swiftly on, I always think the best thing to do in a new place is to spend a day having a thorough exploration to orient yourself so it feels less alien. So it was that I spent Boxing Day doing just that, after watching the boats line up for the start of the Sydney-Hobart race.

I happened to be sitting on the wharf down on Darling Harbour when a lad came over with a glass of wine, saying it was a present from his boat, which had just finished a private charter. I think the tipsy guests had seen me alone and felt sorry! Anyway, we got to chatting and I ended up sitting aboard La Violenta with this Dutch lad named Bob and his family and friends.

Bob's family sail a boat for various occasions on the harbour, and just the night before they'd taken out a variety of famous English deejays who are in Sydney for New Year's Eve. I think he's just got the best life - living on a boat, and sailing to the Pacific or wherever they pleased. I don't think anything could sound more appealing - if anyone's got a boat in Sydney I'll happily go sailing with you!

The following day I had to be at the airport early to meet my boyfriend Josh who's out here for two weeks, keeping me company. It is good timing as it also happens to be my birthday today, so this is definitely one of those highs that I described earlier.

On the advice of one of the people from the boat yesterday we chose to stay at the Glebe Village Backpackers hostel. It's about 10 minutes out of Sydney, but the home-like atmosphere and attractive surrounds are certainly a step up from Kings Cross. We bought a birthday picnic and ate in the lovely Botanical Gardens and I guess we will go out and celebrate tonight.

So, it's nice to end a week on a real positive note - I'm pretty sure next week will be the same, although I'd better start thinking about doing the dreaded job-hunting thing soon...

Until next week (and the year 2001),
Milly

webTitle: Week 4: California

fields.headline: A Yosemite Christmas
fields.standfirst:
On his first Christmas away from his family, Sam finds himself making up new holiday traditions with two friends in the spectacular glacier-carved valley setting of Yosemite National Park
Listen to Sam calling from Yosemite on Christmas Day.
fields.trailText: Week 4, California On his first Christmas away from his family, Sam finds himself making up new holiday traditions with two friends in the spectacular glacier-carved valley setting of Yosemite National Park
fields.body:
A very Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year to everyone. I don't know about you but I'm spending the holiday season in California.

The journey here took 26 hours and was kind of tiring. The snowstorms around Chicago meant the train was over four hours late before it even reached Glenwood Springs. This was a little annoying but it did give me time to get something decent to eat before boarding. Then we set off into the night with the mournful sound of the train whistle echoing through the valley.

The Amtrak trains are pretty spacious and the seats recline so you can put your feet up. It was quite crowded but most people were up in the lounge car watching a film. In the hushed, semi-darkness of the seating car, I wrapped my coat around me, put on my headphones and quickly drifted off to sleep.

I vaguely remember stopping at Salt Lake City sometime in the early hours but I didn't really wake up until about seven in the morning as the sun was rising over the Nevada desert. All around us was low, flat scrubland but in the distance you could see snow-capped mountains that were just being lit up by the sun.

I had breakfast in the dining car (coffee and pancakes with maple syrup) and then returned to my seat. We spent hours crossing the desert. Every so often you'd see an isolated ranch or a few cattle maybe but that was it all day.

We were allowed out to stretch our legs for 20 minutes in some windswept nowhere town called Sparks and soon after that we began to thread our way up into the Sierra mountains. The snow came down again as we crossed Donner Pass. This deep gorge is named after the leader of a party of pioneers who were snowed in here in the 19th century and had to eat each other. Back on the train, cannibalism was averted by Amtrak giving everyone a soggy, tasteless turkey roll to make up for the delay.

We managed to make up some time and arrived in San Francisco only three hours late. I got a taxi up to my friends Roy and Sallie's apartment. They live at the top of a hill in an old district called Potrero and have a fantastic view overlooking the city. They both made me feel very welcome and gave me my own room - an incredible luxury after staying in 15-bed dormitories.

I spent the first day just sorting out my stuff - doing my washing, catching up on my e-mails, etc. - and taking a look round the area. It's just how I've always pictured San Francisco, with wooden houses lining streets at ridiculously steep angles.

On Saturday, Roy took us on a drive round the city and we went across the Golden Gate bridge to watch the sunset. The view was spectacular with the bay and the lights of the city on one side and the Pacific ocean on the other.

At the last moment, we decided to spend Christmas in Yosemite National Park. We packed the car with provisions and presents and set off on Christmas Eve morning. By mid-afternoon we were in the most amazing setting. Our cabin was in a wooded part of the valley at the bottom of a vertical rock face, almost 3,000 feet high. The little village nearby had everything you could want and we spent a drunken evening in the bar singing carols by the fire.

This was my first Christmas away from my family and it did feel a little odd not doing the usual things. Normally my Christmases consist of lots of time with my family, playing games, eating home-cooked food and going for walks on the Norfolk beaches - as well as visits to the local pub with old school friends (Rob, Steve, Andy, Dan and Joolz - how many tequilas did you have on Christmas Eve then?).

But Roy, Sallie and I made up our own traditions. On Christmas morning we got up and opened presents in bed. I had some too because my girlfriend had posted them on ahead of me. It's very exciting getting letters and parcels when you're away - it's like a small piece of home. My best present was a fold-up knife and fork set (very useful as hostels only seem to have spoons). Sallie gave Roy a handheld GPS navigational system and he spent the rest of the trip telling us how far we had walked and what direction we were pointing in. Then we all called home, thanked people for our gifts and wished everyone a happy Christmas.

It was a beautiful day with clear blue skies. So while most of you stuffed your faces and settled down in front of the TV to watch the afternoon film, I went on a three-hour walk through woods and up the valley to see a waterfall. I saw two coyotes but no bears despite all the signs telling you to keep an eye out and lock away any food.

After that, I felt I'd earned my Christmas dinner, so we went to the village restaurant and had the traditional turkey roast with all the trimmings. Then we went back to the big, cozy chairs and the crackling fire of the bar and played cards into the evening.

Boxing Day was spent walking and driving round the park. I took an enormous number of photos - none of which, I know, will really show you how beautiful it is here. You'll just have to come out to Yosemite one Christmas Day yourselves and see the valley carved by glaciers with its rock sides rising vertically out of the frosty meadow all around you.

I've got a few days to look round San Francisco before I reboard a plane and fly to Fiji on Saturday. I'll arrive at 21.00 on the 31st (my own fault - I forgot that crossing the dateline in this direction means I lose a day). I hope New Year's Eve will be as different and fun as my Christmas Day.
fields.bodyText: A very Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year to everyone. I don't know about you but I'm spending the holiday season in California. The journey here took 26 hours and was kind of tiring. The snowstorms around Chicago meant the train was over four hours late before it even reached Glenwood Springs. This was a little annoying but it did give me time to get something decent to eat before boarding. Then we set off into the night with the mournful sound of the train whistle echoing through the valley. The Amtrak trains are pretty spacious and the seats recline so you can put your feet up. It was quite crowded but most people were up in the lounge car watching a film. In the hushed, semi-darkness of the seating car, I wrapped my coat around me, put on my headphones and quickly drifted off to sleep. I vaguely remember stopping at Salt Lake City sometime in the early hours but I didn't really wake up until about seven in the morning as the sun was rising over the Nevada desert. All around us was low, flat scrubland but in the distance you could see snow-capped mountains that were just being lit up by the sun. I had breakfast in the dining car (coffee and pancakes with maple syrup) and then returned to my seat. We spent hours crossing the desert. Every so often you'd see an isolated ranch or a few cattle maybe but that was it all day. We were allowed out to stretch our legs for 20 minutes in some windswept nowhere town called Sparks and soon after that we began to thread our way up into the Sierra mountains. The snow came down again as we crossed Donner Pass. This deep gorge is named after the leader of a party of pioneers who were snowed in here in the 19th century and had to eat each other. Back on the train, cannibalism was averted by Amtrak giving everyone a soggy, tasteless turkey roll to make up for the delay. We managed to make up some time and arrived in San Francisco only three hours late. I got a taxi up to my friends Roy and Sallie's apartment. They live at the top of a hill in an old district called Potrero and have a fantastic view overlooking the city. They both made me feel very welcome and gave me my own room - an incredible luxury after staying in 15-bed dormitories. I spent the first day just sorting out my stuff - doing my washing, catching up on my e-mails, etc. - and taking a look round the area. It's just how I've always pictured San Francisco, with wooden houses lining streets at ridiculously steep angles. On Saturday, Roy took us on a drive round the city and we went across the Golden Gate bridge to watch the sunset. The view was spectacular with the bay and the lights of the city on one side and the Pacific ocean on the other. At the last moment, we decided to spend Christmas in Yosemite National Park. We packed the car with provisions and presents and set off on Christmas Eve morning. By mid-afternoon we were in the most amazing setting. Our cabin was in a wooded part of the valley at the bottom of a vertical rock face, almost 3,000 feet high. The little village nearby had everything you could want and we spent a drunken evening in the bar singing carols by the fire. This was my first Christmas away from my family and it did feel a little odd not doing the usual things. Normally my Christmases consist of lots of time with my family, playing games, eating home-cooked food and going for walks on the Norfolk beaches - as well as visits to the local pub with old school friends (Rob, Steve, Andy, Dan and Joolz - how many tequilas did you have on Christmas Eve then?). But Roy, Sallie and I made up our own traditions. On Christmas morning we got up and opened presents in bed. I had some too because my girlfriend had posted them on ahead of me. It's very exciting getting letters and parcels when you're away - it's like a small piece of home. My best present was a fold-up knife and fork set (very useful as hostels only seem to have spoons). Sallie gave Roy a handheld GPS navigational system and he spent the rest of the trip telling us how far we had walked and what direction we were pointing in. Then we all called home, thanked people for our gifts and wished everyone a happy Christmas. It was a beautiful day with clear blue skies. So while most of you stuffed your faces and settled down in front of the TV to watch the afternoon film, I went on a three-hour walk through woods and up the valley to see a waterfall. I saw two coyotes but no bears despite all the signs telling you to keep an eye out and lock away any food. After that, I felt I'd earned my Christmas dinner, so we went to the village restaurant and had the traditional turkey roast with all the trimmings. Then we went back to the big, cozy chairs and the crackling fire of the bar and played cards into the evening. Boxing Day was spent walking and driving round the park. I took an enormous number of photos - none of which, I know, will really show you how beautiful it is here. You'll just have to come out to Yosemite one Christmas Day yourselves and see the valley carved by glaciers with its rock sides rising vertically out of the frosty meadow all around you. webTitle: Cold Feet over a fifth series of hit show

fields.headline: Cold Feet over a fifth series of hit show
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The makers of Cold Feet, the ITV comedy drama, have decided that viewers have been subjected to enough middle-class angst.
fields.body:
The makers of Cold Feet, the ITV comedy drama, have decided that viewers have been subjected to enough middle-class angst.

The fourth series will be the last, it has been decided, after the cast, writers and producers opted to quit on a high rather than risk dragging the show beyond its sell-by date.

Mike Bullen, the programme's creator and principal writer, told the Guardian about the decision, ending weeks of speculation in the tabloid press.

There was a danger, he said, that the show would go stale if it continued beyond a fourth series. The present run, which has achieved almost unanimous critical acclaim, ended last night.

Cold Feet's demise is a blow for the ITV network. The programme is one of the network's "blue chip" dramas: it can be held up as an example of quality television in a schedule otherwise dominated by bland, formulaic series such as Heartbeat and Peak Practice, a medical drama.

After a crisis in British television situation comedy, Cold Feet defined a new genre - comedy drama.

It has made household names of actors James Nesbitt, Fay Ripley and Helen Baxendale, and has brought Robert Bathurst, Hermione Norris and John Thomson to prominence. The six play a set of long-time friends, struggling to cope with success and failure in their professional and emotional lives.

It regularly pulls in up to nine million viewers. This month, it was named best comedy drama at the television industry's annual Comedy Awards. Nesbitt was named best comedy actor.

ITV wanted to capitalise on the success of the first two series by substantially increasing its run to 15 or 20 episodes.

But Granada Television refused, delivering just eight episodes instead of the usual six.

One cast member said: "They wanted to turn it into a soap, really, but we didn't want it to go down that route."

The show has also been a success abroad - it is one of the highest-rating series in Australia, it is a hit in South Africa, and was recently sold to the US. It premiered on the cable TV network Bravo this month, after a publicity campaign which involved the distribution of 1,000 red roses at Grand Central Station in New York.

Dedicated fans of Cold Feet will know that the stunt was based on a memorable scene from the first episode, in which Adam (Nesbitt) woos Rachel (Baxendale) naked, but for a single red rose clenched between his buttocks.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Andy
fields.trailText: I'm Andy, also 29 from the UK, and I also entered the Netjetters competition... but was pipped at the post! However, I decided to go travelling anyway and I'm having a great time too. The weird thing is, I flew first to New York, and have now come down for San Francisco for Christmas... and I'm staying with friends. How uncanny is that?!
fields.body:
Hi Sam,

A friend back in London told me about you... looks like you're having a ball! I'm Andy, also 29 from the UK, and I also entered the Netjetters competition... but was pipped at the post! However, I decided to go travelling anyway and I'm having a great time too. Isn't San Francisco great!

Take care: if you're too busy packing, etc. to meet, have a great new year and a wonderful travel experience!

webTitle: Beano publisher may rescue SRH

fields.headline: Beano publisher may rescue SRH
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The privately owned publisher of the Beano has emerged as an unlikely saviour of Scottish Radio Holdings, the media company which is being stalked by rival SMG.
fields.body:
The privately owned publisher of the Beano has emerged as an unlikely saviour of Scottish Radio Holdings, the media company which is being stalked by rival SMG.

Dundee-based DC Thomson, which also owns the Sunday Post, is understood to be mulling an offer for the company after holding friendly talks with Scottish Radio's chief executive, Richard Findlay.

On Friday, DC Thomson disclosed it had increased its holding in Scottish Radio to 8.18% from 6.06%. Neither DC Thomson nor Scottish Radio could be reached for comment yesterday.

Discussions with DC Thomson come after Scottish Radio, owner of Radio Clyde and string of local newspapers in Scotland and Northern Ireland, hired investment bank Goldman Sachs to review its strategic options.

The move, which culminated in Scottish Radio's admission last week that it had received a number of takeover approaches, followed a raid on its share register by SMG, formerly know as Scottish Media Group. In anticipation of changes to rules governing radio ownership, SMG has built a 20.8% stake in Scottish Radio.

Although the government's recent communications white paper contained few specific proposals, most pundits expect it to lead to an overhaul of legislation. Under the existing rules, no company may own more than 15% of the national commercial radio audience.

While SMG has only 4% and Scottish Radio 7% of the national audience, SMG would still face regulatory hurdles in acquiring Scottish Radio because it owns the ITV franchises Scottish and Grampian. At present no company is permitted to own a radio and a TV franchise in the same area.

According to weekend reports, Mr Findlay is looking for an offer of up to £20 a share from DC Thomson. On Friday, Scottish Radio shares closed at £16.95, valuing the group at close to £560m.

DC Thomson is said to have access to up to £2bn in cash and borrowings.

webTitle: Titanic sinks as ITV wins Christmas Day ratings

fields.headline: Titanic sinks as ITV wins Christmas Day ratings
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC paid a fortune for the right to show the blockbuster film Titanic but saw its hopes of beating ITV in the Christmas night ratings war sunk.
fields.body:
The BBC paid a fortune for the right to show the blockbuster film Titanic but saw its hopes of beating ITV in the Christmas night ratings war sunk.

According to early figures, 12.2m people watched the final moments of the three-hour epic, though it averaged 9.9m, making it only the sixth most popular programme of the day. A Christmas special of the comedy the Royle Family only just squeezed into the top 10.

The ITV soap Coronation Street, in its 40th year, was again the favourite programme with 13.7m viewers.

ITV claimed victory for the second year running in the battle for peak-time viewers. Its average audience share between 6pm and 10.30pm was 40.2 % or 9.8m viewers. BBC1 attracted an average of 39.8% or 9.6m viewers.

However, BBC1 did maintain its larger share of the audience throughout the day - 36.5% as against 33.7% for ITV. The satellite and cable channels increased their audience share from 10.5% last year to 15%.

The number of people who watched the 3pm broadcast of the Queen's speech fell from 10.5m last year to 9.8m. Five years ago the combined total was 13.9m.

Last year was the first time in 15 years that ITV had beaten BBC1 on Christmas night, prompting the BBC to invest millions in Titanic. Television industry sources believe the corporation paid £7m over several years for rights to the film.

The 10 most popular programmes were:
1. Coronation Street ITV 13.7m viewers
2. EastEnders 8.50pm episode BBC1 12.1m
3. Who Wants to be a Millionaire? 10.20pm ITV 11.1m
4. ITV News at 10.50pm ITV 10.8m
5. EastEnders 5.15pm episode BBC1 10.1m
6. Titanic BBC1 9.9m
7. Who Wants to be a Millionaire? 8.50pm ITV 9.6m
8 = Emmerdale ITV 9.3m and You've Been Framed at Christmas ITV 9.3m
10. The Royle Family BBC1 8.3m.

webTitle: Austin Powers 3 makers have 007 in their sights

fields.headline: Austin Powers 3 makers have 007 in their sights
fields.standfirst: Plus: Jodie Foster alters premiere schedule for Altar Boys; Austrian hills ring with Sound of Music, at last; Kevin Bacon voted poster boy of US video software dealers; Nepalese cinemas boycott Indian films; and Spielberg and Magic Johnson get stars under their feet
fields.trailText: Plus: Jodie Foster alters premiere schedule for Altar Boys; Austrian hills ring with Sound of Music, at last; Kevin Bacon voted poster boy of US video software dealers; Nepalese cinemas boycott Indian films; and Spielberg and Magic Johnson get stars under their feet
fields.body:
 The first - and for most, best - James Bond, Sir Sean Connery (pictured), is rumoured to be up for a part in the third Austin Powers movie. Columnists at the The New York Daily News report that director Jay Roach has approached the veteran Scottish actor in a bid to persuade him to take on the role of Austin Powers' father. The third in the series of 007 spoofs is due to begin production early in the new year. The prequel will see Austin and Dr Evil (both played by Mike Myers) as rival classmates, with Austin at the forefront of the British fashion and music invasion of the US in the 1960s.

 Entertainment site Mr Showbiz reports that Jodie Foster has withdrawn The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys from January's Sundance Film Festival as it will not be completed in time. Foster co-produced and stars in the movie, which was set to premiere as the centrepiece of the independent film festival - she plays nun Sister Assumpta, overseeing a group of Catholic school boys. Trade journal Variety surmises that the movie's extensive animation has led to the delay in its completion. Instead, festival-goers will be treated to the world premiere of Invisible Circus, which stars Cameron Diaz.

 It wouldn't be Christmas without it, but this is one holiday TV tradition that the Austrians have long been denied. The Sound of Music has never been shown on television on Austrian TV, out of the belief that Austrians would not want to be reminded of their Nazi past. But 36 years after its release, the classic musical has finally received its TV premiere. Viewing figures are not yet available, but a dubbed version of the movie flopped on its release in Germany.

 Kevin Bacon is to receive the 2001 Video Software Dealers Association Video Man of the Year, following the success of Stir of Echoes. The ghostly thriller, which opened in the US in autumn 1999, has since made over $60m (£42m) in video retail - more than three times its box-office takings.

 Movie theatres across Nepal have suspended screening Indian films after an alleged anti-Nepal slur by a Bollywood star, reports the BBC. The ban will remain until the actor, Hrithik Roshan, apologises. Roshan is alleged to have said in a television interview that he hated Nepal and its people. The actor has denied making any such statements. Nepal's Deputy Prime Minister, Ram Chandra Poudel, has appealed for calm as violent protests continued for a second day.

 Steven Spielberg and basketball player Magic Johnson are to be honoured with stars on Hollywood's Walk of Fame. The two are among celebrities whose stars will be added next year to the more than 2,000 that line Hollywood Boulevard. Johnson, although best known as a former Los Angeles Lakers guard, is being honoured in the movie category. In 1995 the sporting hero launched the Magic Johnson Theaters in an attempt to bring multiplex theatres to urban neighbourhoods under-served by national chains.

webTitle: Hague and Woolf clash over prisons

fields.headline: Hague and Woolf clash over prisons
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The Tory leader, William Hague, clashed with the Lord Chief Justice today after Britain's top judge called for politicians to resist the temptation to call for ever greater use of imprisonment.
fields.body:
The Tory leader, William Hague, clashed with the Lord Chief Justice today after Britain's top judge called for politicians to resist the temptation to call for ever greater use of imprisonment.

Lord Woolf argued that many people in prison did not need to be there, and were simply adding to overcrowding, which undermined efforts to rehabilitate more serious offenders. He stressed that serious criminals had to be incarcerated.

"If a person has committed a serious crime, I am strongly in favour of the person receiving serious punishment," said Lord Woolf, who added that the objective of the penal system should then be to make the offender less likely to reoffend on his eventual release."

He added: "Overcrowding of prisons is a cancer which undermines the work of the prisons and the problem is we have people there because of the system who should not be there, who contribute to overcrowding.

"What we have to do is to achieve a situation where our punishments in the community are ones which the public find more acceptable than they do at the moment, because many things can be done so far as offenders are concerned without sending them to prison which actually provide better safeguards for the public than what we are doing at the moment.

"Politicians ... see prison as something which the public feels is an important safeguard and so they will be in favour in the rhetoric that they use of more and more prison, but that actually is not necessarily in the interests of the public," Lord Woolf told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

But Tory leader William Hague took issue with Lord Woolf. He said: "I think that it may be necessary to have more people in prison, in order to deal with the law and order situation in this country," he said. "I don't think it is being dealt with at the moment. Crime is rising, the number of police is falling and everybody around the country knows that it is an increasing problem and it must be dealt with."

Norman Brennan, director of the Victims of Crime Trust, accused Lord Woolf of "joining the liberal brigade" and said weak sentences were partly to blame for high crime rates. He said: "The reason there are many criminals in prison is that judges give out weak sentences that do not act as a deterrent."

"Those who are guilty of serious offences are the types that society rightly needs protection from. The Lord Chief Justice appears to have joined the liberal brigade.

However, the Prison Reform Trust welcomed Lord Woolf's calls for fewer offenders to be jailed and said the public should be more "confident in community penalties". Director Juliet Lyon said: "A crowded prison cannot be either effective, just or humane. We believe that the Lord Chief Justice is right to call for increased public confidence in the use of community penalties. Prison must be kept as an absolute last resort.

Home Office minister Mike O'Brien said Tory tax-and-spending policies would mean reductions in spending on law and order. "It is simply impossible to lock up more people at the same time as cutting spending on law and order as the Tories have pledged to do.

"Tory policies simply do not add up. Under the Tories crime doubled and more criminals got away with it. With Labour crime has fallen 10% and for the first time in years police numbers are rising."

And Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes also challenged Mr Hague's views. "Given that half of all people released from prison reoffend within two years, the argument that prison is an effective deterrent is clearly flawed," he said. "What we need is more effective use of time in prison for those who need a custodial sentence, much more effective help and support on release, and more effective alternatives which make the offender directly accountable to the community and victims, against whom their crime was committed."

Harry Fletcher, of the National Association of Probation Officers, predicted that in the run-up to the general election politicians would vie with one another to appear tough on crime. But he questioned the effectiveness of tough-sounding measures, such as the three-strikes-and-you're-out penalty for burglars, after it emerged that judges had failed to use the power to jail third-time burglars for three years against any offender in its first year.

"Politicians ... see prison as something which the public feels is an important safeguard and so they will be in favour in the rhetoric that they use of more and more prison, but that actually is not necessarily in the interests of the public," Lord Woolf told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. But Tory leader William Hague took issue with Lord Woolf. He said: "I think that it may be necessary to have more people in prison, in order to deal with the law and order situation in this country," he said. "I don't think it is being dealt with at the moment. Crime is rising, the number of police is falling and everybody around the country knows that it is an increasing problem and it must be dealt with." Norman Brennan, director of the Victims of Crime Trust, accused Lord Woolf of "joining the liberal brigade" and said weak sentences were partly to blame for high crime rates. He said: "The reason there are many criminals in prison is that judges give out weak sentences that do not act as a deterrent." "Those who are guilty of serious offences are the types that society rightly needs protection from. The Lord Chief Justice appears to have joined the liberal brigade. However, the Prison Reform Trust welcomed Lord Woolf's calls for fewer offenders to be jailed and said the public should be more "confident in community penalties". Director Juliet Lyon said: "A crowded prison cannot be either effective, just or humane. We believe that the Lord Chief Justice is right to call for increased public confidence in the use of community penalties. Prison must be kept as an absolute last resort. Home Office minister Mike O'Brien said Tory tax-and-spending policies would mean reductions in spending on law and order. "It is simply impossible to lock up more people at the same time as cutting spending on law and order as the Tories have pledged to do. "Tory policies simply do not add up. Under the Tories crime doubled and more criminals got away with it. With Labour crime has fallen 10% and for the first time in years police numbers are rising." And Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes also challenged Mr Hague's views. "Given that half of all people released from prison reoffend within two years, the argument that prison is an effective deterrent is clearly flawed," he said. "What we need is more effective use of time in prison for those who need a custodial sentence, much more effective help and support on release, and more effective alternatives which make the offender directly accountable to the community and victims, against whom their crime was committed." Harry Fletcher, of the National Association of Probation Officers, predicted that in the run-up to the general election politicians would vie with one another to appear tough on crime. But he questioned the effectiveness of tough-sounding measures, such as the three-strikes-and-you're-out penalty for burglars, after it emerged that judges had failed to use the power to jail third-time burglars for three years against any offender in its first year.
