webTitle: Stage set for Middle East drama

fields.headline: Stage set for Middle East drama
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: President Clinton's last chance to achieve peace in the Middle East comes at a crucial time for the Israeli and Palestinian leaders, writes former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown
fields.body:
The curtain is set to rise on an extraordinary Middle East drama. Tomorrow's summit in the Egyptian resort of Sharm el-Sheikh will mark the effective closure of the regional peace process which began seven years ago. Whether it ends in triumph or despair is entirely open to question.

The new summit is President Bill Clinton's last lunge for the prize he always lusted after: a final political settlement between Israel and the Palestinians.

He has tabled a remarkable set of proposals which involve cruelly painful concessions from both sides. Israel would have to give up sovereignty over the holy site in Jerusalem known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as al-Haram as-Sharif, the Noble Sanctuary. Israel would also give up some 95% of its 1967 conquests on the West Bank, and evacuate tens of thousands of Jewish settlers.

The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat also has an enormous bullet to bite. The Americans are calling on him to give up the sacred cow of "right of return" for the 4m-odd Palestinian refugees scattered throughout the Middle East.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, says he will initial the so-called bridging proposals - if Arafat does so. Palestinian officials are more cautious, saying that they need more details before they can consider the putative deal.

Both leaders are facing the most momentous day of their political lives. Both are certain to be condemned and vilified by their own people if they accept the US plan. Yet if there is no deal in Egypt this week, the whole peace process could slither into terminal decay.

There has never been a better or a worse time for a dash for peace. On the plus side, President Clinton is hurling all his diplomatic resources and the prestige of his office into the effort. Barak, too, is staking all on the summit. He needs a peace deal desperately if he is to cling to power in February's prime ministerial elections.

On the minus side, the negotiation is being held against the bloody backdrop of the latest Palestinian uprising, which has claimed some 360 lives in three months. Nerves and emotions have been scraped raw, and on both sides there are militant calls for revenge and resistance.

Ariel Sharon, leader of the rightwing Likud faction in Israel and the man who hopes to take Barak's job in February, says that if he wins he will not honour any agreement achieved at Sharm el-Sheikh. That pledge could backfire on the old warrior, as it confirms him as a fundamentalist obstacle to the peace for which most Israelis hunger.

On the Palestinian side too there are diehards, both Islamist and secular, who are scandalised by the very idea of coming to terms with the Zionist enemy.

For Israelis, the most shocking aspect of the US proposal is the cession of sovereignty over what they call the Temple Mount, the most sacred site in Judaism. The rocky hill is thought to be the site of the First and Second Temples. Only one small fragment of the latter remains: the Western, or Wailing, Wall.

The US idea is apparently that Israel will retain full control of the Western Wall, and of the notoriously sensitive archaeological sites under the Mount, while the Palestinians take control of the hill's surface, on which stand the Dome of the Rock and the al-Aqsa mosque.

But Palestinian spokesmen have demurred, saying they must have control of the whole Haram as-Sharif, including its archeological sites.

This may seem an arcane dispute, but the conflict in the Holy Land has always involved raw and irrational emotion. Jews who believe in Eretz Israel - the Land of Israel which, in the eyes of the more dedicated believers, will one day stretch from the Mediterranean to the Euphrates - will be outraged that an Israeli government is prepared to remove Jewish settlers from the West Bank.

That outrage is echoed among Palestinian refugees who were displaced by the wars of 1948 and 1967. They, their descendants and their many sympathisers, have for more than half a century insisted that the Zionist state must reverse its ethnic cleansing, and allow the right of return.

Such a concession would not just convulse Israel, but obliterate it. In a population of 6m, at least 1m are Arabs, and with Jewish immigration static, the non-Jewish proportion is inexorably rising. The most that Israel is prepared to offer is a right of return to the embryonic Palestinian state of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, with a tiny symbolic trickle of returnees into Israel itself, on compassionate grounds.

webTitle: Prescott demands report into rail fares hike

fields.headline: Prescott demands report into rail fares hike
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, today called for a report into the decision by rail companies to raise fares despite severe disruption on the network.
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, today called for a report into the decision by rail companies to raise fares despite severe disruption on the network.

Passenger groups have described the above-inflation rises of up to 4.9% on new ticket prices, which come in on January 7, as "appalling" and "particularly insensitive".

During a tour of Leeds station - where a £165m regeneration programme is seriously affecting services - Mr Prescott said he had asked the strategic rail authority for a full report into the increases.

But he stressed: "The regulated fares have had a reduction in prices. Many companies are able to offer cheap fares which are unregulated. Some have decided to freeze them, others have decided to increase them. I have asked the rail authority to give me a full report on it. I know it has caused a great deal of concern.

"I have to take a long term view. These railways are going to be modernised. There is £60bn investment, but I know I'm going to get some problems along the way."

The Capital Transport Campaign group said that under the fare-capping system every train operating company could increase the cash price of commuter fares in 2001, even when their performance had become dramatically worse.

The group is particularly incensed that the Silverlink company, which operates out of London's Euston station to north London and the Midlands, has put up prices by 4.3% even though it finished bottom in a recent customer satisfaction poll. "Commuters are not being compensated for the ongoing deterioration in rail services they have experienced," said spokeswoman Cynthia Hay.

First Great Eastern, which operates out of London's Liverpool Street station to Essex and East Anglia, is raising some fares by 3.3%.

"This is a particularly insensitive time to impose a large price rise," said Brian Cooke, chairman of the Rail Passengers Council's Great Eastern sub committee. "For passengers to pay an above-inflation rise at this time seems like a complete smack in the teeth. It is appalling."

Rises at other companies include a 4.9% increase on some off-peak fares on South West Trains, a 3.3% increases on Connex peak fares, and 3.3% increases on Central Trains' off-peak tickets.

Fares have been frozen by East Coast operator GNER and by Virgin on its West Coast main line and CrossCountry services. All these routes have been particularly badly hit by speed restrictions imposed after the Hatfield crash. A rail passengers' council spokesman said: "At a time when compensation is still being paid to passengers, it is particularly insensitive to increase fares. Services on many routes are still disrupted and that may continue for several months yet."

He added: "We welcome the fares freeze that some train companies have adopted and we call on the industry to postpone fares rises until the trains are running normally again."

Mr Prescott, who arrived at Leeds station by car, passed queues of passengers waiting in the cold for buses because many trains were not stopping at Leeds from today until January 1.

Signalling work at the station meant passengers on lines to Wakefield, Huddersfield, Sheffield, Pontefract and the Calder Valley had to get buses to other stations.

Railtrack has stressed that the 17-day work programme, which involves 350 engineers working around the clock, will be completed on schedule for January 2.

The deputy prime minister, who donned a hard hat and fluorescent jacket to inspect engineering work, said: "I want to see people back on the railways. If they are reliable and modern, people will come back. What has been short is the resources. We inherited a mess, there's no doubt about it. What we're doing is getting the long-term investment sorted out."

Mr Prescott said he had also asked for a report into why more than 600 passengers were stranded at Stansted airport last night because rail services into London ended at 7pm and there were no seats on coaches. "It's certainly not integrated and it's not a good example if we want people to use an integrated transport system," he said.

webTitle: What the Middle East papers say

fields.headline: What the Middle East papers say
fields.standfirst: As Israeli and Palestinian leaders brace for tommorrow's make-or-break summit in Egypt, the region's media are prepared for events to take a momentous turn, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: As Israeli and Palestinian leaders brace for tommorrow's make-or-break summit in Egypt, the region's media are prepared for events to take a momentous turn, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The rightwing Jerusalem Post is predictably appalled by the further concessions allegedly being offered to the Palestinians by the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak: "As for the Temple Mount, it appears as if Israel is now prepared to accept Palestinian sovereignty over Judaism's most holy site, relying on some form of understandings to prohibit the Palestinians from digging underneath the mount, the area believed to hold the remains of the First and Second Temples. And under the contours of the American-proposed agreement, Israel's capital, Jerusalem, would be divided, with the Palestinians receiving sovereignty over the Arab neighbourhoods. Given the historical enormity of this decision, the muted sound of protest of opponents to such an agreement is simply stunning."

The main editorial in the more liberal Ha'aretz daily is starkly headed "Decision time". Many Jews in Israel and in the Diaspora, says the paper, will find "unbearable" the proposed transfer of sovereignty at the Temple Mount. A deal with the Palestinians will also involve the evacuation of tens of thousands of Jewish settlers from their homes. But the paper goes on: "The Israeli right, which has recently been heaping sharp criticism on the compromise proposal, has no realistic alternative solution to offer. If Israel decided to reject the American plan it probably would perpetuate the crisis in relations with the Palestinians and the neighbouring Arab states, and deal a mortal blow to the diplomatic, defence and economic interests of Israel."

Ha'aretz also points out that the Palestinian president, Yasser Arafat, faces some cruel decisions: "Clinton's proposal will require the Palestinian political leadership to stand bravely before hundreds of thousands of refugees and tell them it is time to throw away the keys of their homes in Haifa and Jaffa.

Instead of clinging to the dream of return that has passed from father to son, they will have to make do with a real program for rehabilitation."

The pan-Arab website Khaleej Times takes a decidedly gloomy view of the looming summit: "In the trilateral talks, the curtain is falling on two principal characters' stage performance: President Bill Clinton's countdown at the White House has already started and Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak is numbering his days in office. He is hardly in a position to take a firm stand in view of the impending elections in February next. In other words, Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat has to deal with two lameduck leaders. All the three and their aides who are facing the daunting task of hammering out an agreement by trying to bridge proposals aimed at narrowing the still-considerable gaps, have a hawk hovering over their heads in Likud leader Ariel Sharon. Sharon, who is tipped to beat Barak in the elections, opposes any Israeli concessions to Palestinians, particularly over the holy sites in Jerusalem."

The Gulf News in Dubai is surprisingly upbeat about the new administration waiting to take over the White House. The paper's editorial reflects widespread Arab distrust of President Clinton, who is seen as markedly pro-Israel. George W Bush, the leader writer suggests, will be more even handed: "Bush is fortunate in having people like Dick Cheney and Colin Powell on his team. They inspire confidence in the Middle East, much more than Madeleine Albright, or Dennis Ross or even Martin Indyk (all Israeli supporters) ever did. Looked at from here, this is the strength of the new American administration."

webTitle: Charity for blind wins SRB grant

fields.headline: Charity for blind wins SRB grant
fields.standfirst: A charity that helps blind people develop employable skills has become one of the first disability charities to win a substantial SRB grant, writes Laurence Pollock
fields.trailText: A charity that helps blind people develop employable skills has become one of the first disability charities to win a substantial SRB grant, writes Laurence Pollock
fields.body:
A charity which trains blind and partially sighted people has broken through a funding glass ceiling, winning nearly half a million pounds from the government's single regeneration budget (SRB).

The SRB is aimed at regenerating communities with high levels of poverty, unemployment and social exclusion. Local authorities have been some of the biggest recipients.

The award of £473,000 to Action for Blind People (AFBP) in greater London, a charity that attempts to provide blind people with the skills they need to find employment, is thought to be the first case of a disability charity winning a substantial SRB grant. It will allow AFBP to develop a network of partners over the next three years to boost training in Information and Computer Technologies (ICT).

The scheme will build on the rapid development of powerful voice recognition software. There will be an emphasis on educating trainers to ensure the benefits are long lasting.

AFBP already runs a training centre in south London. But the grant will promote outreach to partner organisations around the capital, thus reducing access and mobility problems.

The windfall came almost by chance. "Details of SRB sixth round funding found their way into the office," said Gill Astarita, AFBP's development director. "We realised we could actually use this to start something innovative around overcoming access difficulties."

With just weeks to the June deadline for the bid's submission, a working group frantically got to grips with the SRB criteria, framing how their proposal would tackle economic disadvantage and social exclusion. But AFBP is grateful to officials at the government office of the London region who offered some clues about how a bid should set out. "They showed us where the goal posts were," said Ms Astarita.

Development should start in the spring, and plans to recruit three new trainers and a job search coordinator are well under way. Mike Webster, employment and training manager for London, is making appeals for new partners. The group is aiming for around 25 - about five in each of London's five learning and skills council areas.

Partners will supply premises and administrative support, while AFBP will deliver training and the ICT equipment. The aim is for around 500 people to access training over the three years and for at least 50 jobs to be created. Others may become self-employed. Even where training is not followed with employment, computer training will still tackle social exclusion - a key aim of the SRB funding.

AFBP runs training centres in three other locations in England and would like to expand.

Roughly three-quarters of blind and partially sighted people are unemployed. African and African-Caribbean groups in particular face a double disadvantage because of their ethnic minority status. There is also a greater danger of visual impairment through higher incidence of diabetes and sickle cell anaemia in these groups.

Ibukun Olashore, director of one the new partner groups, the Southwark-based Organisation of Blind African Caribbeans (OBAC), welcomed the opportunity to "train trainers". While there were plenty of knowledgeable IT workers, she said, many were not familiar with access issues for blind and visually impaired people. The partnership represented the chance to take ICT training to a much higher level than OBAC had been able to provide up to now. "The technology is moving so fast and it is very easy to be out of date," she added.

Ms Olashore also highlights the lack of motivation and confidence experienced by those who have lost their sight. Jagdish Tank, now in his 40s, came to live in Britain after sight loss four years ago, ending his involvement with the family firm in Kenya. He has been learning braille and typing with the Haringey Phoenix Group, which offers support and training to the blind and visually impaired.

"Losing my sight was a huge trauma," he said. "It took me quite a while before I could come back to life. I thought I would never get on my feet. I hope that with good IT skills I will be able to get into business or employment."

Tom Stapleton, the group's manager, said he was "very excited" at the prospect of the partnership with AFBP. "We have a number of young people of working age who are anxious to get back into employment," he said. "They are not trained and have no skills - this is where the scheme is going to make a difference."

webTitle: Gun massacre suspect denies murder

fields.headline: Gun massacre suspect denies murder
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in America
fields.trailText: A software engineer accused of murdering seven co-workers at a US internet consulting company was denied bail today after denying seven counts of murder.
fields.body:
A software engineer accused of murdering seven co-workers at a US internet consulting company was denied bail today after denying seven counts of murder.

Michael McDermott, 42, stood impassive as a prosecutor described how the shooter blasted through the offices of Edgewater Technology with 37 rounds from a semiautomatic rifle and several from a shotgun, striking co-workers in their heads and backs as they tried to flee.

"There was very little, if any, missed shots. Most of the wounds went through and through the bodies," said Tom O'Reilly, an assistant district attorney.

"One of [the victims] was underneath his desk. He had been shot numerous times. Another was a young lady slumped over her keyboard of her computer. She had been shot in the back of the head," Mr O'Reilly said.

Some of the four women and three men killed worked in the accounting department, which was recently served with an order from the internal revenue service to begin to cut Mr McDermott's wages to pay back taxes. Last week, he had an angry outburst over the dispute, said one employee, who wished to remain anonymous.

"Everything appears to be targeted at the individuals, rather than indiscriminate spraying of gunfire," said the Middlesex county district attorney, Martha Coakley.

Mr McDermott was scheduled to be charged today in Malden district court on seven counts of murder.

The company had recently agreed to the IRS order but had agreed to wait until after the holidays to start taking out what Mr McDermott owed in back taxes, plus interest, Ms Coakley said.

A person familiar with the IRS order who did not want to be identified said the amount owed was $2,000 (£1,300).

In a statement, the company said Mr McDermott's actions "apparently stem from occurrences in his personal life  There was no way to anticipate his actions or any apparent reasons to restrict his access to the building," the company said.

Ms Coakley said that Mr McDermott did not have a permit for any of the weapons he was carrying. She said he had no prior criminal record.

Police found McDermott sitting silently in the reception area, a body nearby, his weapons within reach. He was arrested without gunfire. Co-workers and neighbours described the former US navy submarine electrician as quiet, surly and quirky.

Defense attorney Kevin Reddington, who has met Mr McDermott since the shootings, was hired by Mr McDermott's family. "Obviously they are very distraught," he told the Boston Herald. "But they are standing by and supporting their son and brother ... Everybody is stricken over the enormity of these circumstances."

Mr McDermott was a software tester who had worked at the company since March, said Mike Stanley, a team projects leader. He said Mr McDermott had recently been arriving at work late and his performance was not as good as it could have been.

Kevin Forzese, who lived upstairs from Mr McDermott in Haverhill, said the suspect had never mentioned money problems. He also said Mr McDermott had mentioned that he collected antique guns, but he had never seen any weapons in Mr McDermott's flat.

Edgewater employs approximately 240 people in Massachusetts, said John Cooley, director of investor relations.

The victims were identified as Jennifer Bragg-Capobianco; Janice Hagerty, a receptionist; Louis Javelle; Rose Manfredi, 49, an accountant; Paul Marceau; Cheryl Troy, human resources director; and Craig Wood, 29, of Haverhill.

webTitle: 309 die as fire sweeps through disco in China

fields.headline: 309 die as fire sweeps through disco in China
fields.trailText: A fire in a department store in central China on Christmas Day killed at least 309 people, most of them Christmas revellers trapped in a crowded disco on the building's fourth floor, officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
A fire in a department store in central China on Christmas Day killed at least 309 people, most of them Christmas revellers trapped in a crowded disco on the building's fourth floor, officials said yesterday.

The fire, in the centre of the Luoyang, began during the evening in the basement of the Dongdu Commercial building, which was being renovated at the time.

It quickly engulfed the entire four-storey structure in smoke and flames, an official in the city government's information office said.

Most of the victims suffocated. The casualties included dancers and building workers involved in the renovations.

In addition to the 309 dead, seven were injured and sent to local hospitals, the official Xinhua news agency reported.

At least 200 people were in the fourth-floor disco and construction workers were on the second and third floors when the fire started.

The disco was privately run, and illegal, officials said.

State media reported that 60 people escaped from the building during the fire.

Henan television showed flames shooting out of smashed windows on the building's first floor. Firefighters sprayed the glass front of the building, which remained largely intact.

One woman was shown hanging out of a window waiting to be rescued.

Firefighters plucked some people, children among them, from the upper floors using a platform mounted on a crane.

Shortly after the fire broke out at around 9.30pm, the dance hall erupted in chaos, the Henan Daily, the provincial government's newspaper, reported.

Firefighters tried to enter the disco but retreated before the thick smoke, unable to discover how many people were inside.

One partygoer, a Mrs Wang - her face black with soot, her hands bloody - said she and five or six others jumped to safety from a balcony.

She did not know if her husband had escaped.

An employee at a cinema across the street said smoke poured from the top and back of the building.

She said that firefighters and police officers were searching the building yesterday, keeping the area cordoned off.

About 750 police and firefighters rushed to the scene and put out the fire within three hours, the Luoyang Evening News said.

The disco was crowded with people attending a Christmas party, according to local media and officials.

Although Christmas is not a holiday in officially atheistic China, it has become a fashionable occasion for parties among the younger urban Chinese.

Henan provincial television said the construction work might have been to blame for the fire, but a government official said only that the cause was under investigation.

Construction materials may have blocked escape routes, contributing to the disaster, and vendors' stalls around the building also hampered rescue efforts.

Twenty years of rapid economic growth has left China with spotty safety regulations and lax enforcement, and fires and building collapses are common.

Henan - China's most populous province - came under criticism in March when 74 people died in a fire in a cinema in Jiaozuo city.

Monday's fire, however, may be China's worst in six years. On December 8 1994, a fire killed 385 people - most of them children - at a theatre in the far western region of Xinjiang. Only one exit door was unlocked when the fire occurred.

In a sign of official concern, Beijing sent a vice-minister, Shi Wanpeng, to Luoyang yesterday to assess the disaster and the local government's response.

The fire occurred just before the Lunar New Year, China's biggest holiday, which this year falls on January 24: a time when Chinese leaders routinely order greater vigilance against accidents. A public security ministery directive yesterday ordered checks on public buildings.
AP

webTitle: Interview with Joe Barbera

fields.headline: Top cat
fields.standfirst: After 60 years of being biffed, whacked and chased round the house, Tom and Jerry are crashing into the 21st century with Mansion Cat.  Duncan Campbell  talks to the man behind the mayhem, Joe Barbera
fields.trailText: After 60 years of being biffed, whacked and chased round the house, Tom and Jerry are crashing into the 21st century with Mansion Cat. Duncan Campbell talks to the man behind the mayhem, Joe Barbera
fields.body:
So what was the Pope saying to you? "He was asking me if he could become a director," says Joe Barbera, looking at the framed photograph of himself greeting the head of the Roman Catholic church, which occupies pride of place amid the Oscars, Emmys and honorary fire- chief helmets that adorn his 14th floor office in Sherman Oaks. "He was a Hollywood fan, I can tell you that."

Alas for the fans of biblical epics and costume dramas, the Pope never made it to Hollywood. Barbera did. And he didn't just make it to Hollywood, he made it in Hollywood. The boy who started his artistic life copying pictures from the Bible, at the Holy Innocents school in Brooklyn more than 80 years ago, went on to become half of one of the most celebrated partnerships in film history. Working with William Hanna, he created an extraordinary menagerie of animated characters including Tom and Jerry, the Flintstones, Top Cat, Yogi Bear, Huckleberry Hound and Quick Draw MacGraw. He has won seven Oscars, eight Emmys and a total of 247 awards around the world. Now, 30 years after the last Tom and Jerry movie, there is to be a new one: Mansion Cat, for which Barbera is acting as consultant and doing one of the voices.

"One nun, Sister Mary Nicholas, she would belt you on the back of the head," says Barbera of his days at the Holy Innocents. He talks in a low Brooklyn growl, with the timing of a stand-up comic. "And my grand mother - she had the fastest hands in the west." He demonstrates how she would deliver a speedy clip to any child that stepped out of line. Whack! Biff! Maybe this is where all those whacks and biffs that characterise Tom and Jerry started.

Barbera will be 90 in March, but he is looking natty and groomed in a black polo shirt, herring-bone tweed jacket and flannels. "You're looking very dashing," says Catherine, who handles publicity for him at Warner Brothers. "What do you want?" he asks with a louche grin. He comes to work every day, driven in his Mercedes by his assistant, Carlton.

Half a dozen of his projects are in storyboard form in his room. He starts running through one of the plots, complete with action, when he suddenly stops and says sotto voce to Catherine in a Groucho-like aside: "He looks like a Disney spy to me."

Walt Disney, of course, looms large over any discussion about the history of animation. Barbera was nearly hired by him when he was a young hopeful cartoonist in New York. He had just seen Disney's Skeleton Dance: "I wrote my first and last fan letter to Walt Disney studios in California and I got an answer right away from Walt Disney himself. He said he was coming to New York and he would call me. The luckiest break I ever had was that he never called. I would have gone over there and disappeared."

They only met once, at a barbecue, and he remembers Disney mainly for his secretive nature and enjoyment of bourbon: "We admired him, but we were way ahead of him in humour."

He explains how his family came from Sicily - "It's not just the Mafia, Sicily has some of the best food, the best architecture" - and how he was born in Delancey Street in the heart of New York's Italian quarter on the Lower East Side. His father was a hairdresser who liked to bet on the horses at the Belmont race track.

The young Joe embarked on a career in a bank. He detested the work and studied art at night at the Pratt institute. His first animation work was on Popeye, as an inker. "I was there three days and I asked one of the other inkers how long he had been doing the job. He said 'three years,' so I quit." After a spell at the Van Beuren cartoon studio he worked for Terrytoons in New Rochelle and was then hired by the new MGM Cartoon arm in Los Angeles.

It was there, in 1937, that he met Hanna, another young animator who had moved with his family as boy from New Mexico to Watts in LA. Sixty years on, they are still friends and collaborators, although Hanna's visits to the studio are less frequent. Those were heady days in the cartoon world. Some Disney animators rebelled against their boss in 1941, went on strike and were sacked. They founded their own studio, United Productions of America, choosing a different, freer style of cartooning than Disney's and producing such characters as Mr Magoo, Howdy Doody and Gerald McBoing Boing.

Barbera and Hanna meanwhile ploughed their own furrow, working for MGM at a Stakhanovite pace. In 1940 they had produced their first Tom and Jerry cartoon, Puss Gets The Boot, and despite some reservations about the characters from their producer, Fred Quimby - "what can you do with a cat and mouse that would be different?" - two stars had been born.

In 1943, Yankee Doodle Mouse won an Oscar and another followed for Mouse Trouble in 1944, for Quiet Please in 1945 and so on through the 40s and early 50s. Every year the game was to try to beat Disney to the award. "It's pretty much the same now," Barbera says. "The only difference is that the women wear less clothes."

He is not impressed by new cartoon techniques. He and Hanna had experimented with live action using Tom and Jerry in a dance sequence with Gene Kelly in Anchors Aweigh as long ago as 1945 and having them join Esther Williams for an underwater ballet sequence in Dangerous When Wet in 1953. After Quimby's retirement in1955, Hanna and Barbera became the production heads for cartooning at MGM. It was the time of the blacklist in Hollywood, but Barbera says he was not touched by it: "It was only the live action writers that were affected. I didn't have any dialogue in my films - I was influenced by Charlie Chaplin, the most brilliant of all."

In 1957, MGM decided to close their cartoon division: the golden era of film cartoons had ended with the arrival of television - "the monster", Barbera calls it. The two friends took Tom and Jerry and formed Hanna-Barbera; they tossed up for whose name should come first. Their first new characters were Rough and Reddy and the prodigious output continued as they accommodated the new television market with the Flintstones, Huckleberry Hound and Top Cat.

In 1975 they revived Tom and Jerry with Grape Ape, a gigantic purple ape. It was clear that the cat and mouse were now less violent. Was this because of public pressure? Barbera says the same argument about violence in films being a bad influence was going on 50 years ago. "Tom and Jerry were never going to kill each other, they were friends. Tom did it to Jerry and Jerry did it to Tom."

Although they survived through the 80s, outside the studios the animation world was changing. In 1991 Ted Turner bought Hanna-Barbera and when Turner merged with Time Warner, Hanna-Barbera became part of the deal. They had to leave their beautiful old studio building to move to the anonymous space in Sherman Oaks. Barbera is a traditionalist and regrets the passing of a more sociable time.

"In those days, our cartoon studio was like a club, people worked there for 25 years," he says. "Now when you finish a job they let you go ... There are too many conferences nowadays, six people trying to settle on an idea."

So what does he think of other cartoon styles? The Simpsons, where Itchy and Scratchy are a form of homage to Tom and Jerry? "I already did that (the family) with the Flintstones but their material is good. I salute them." South Park? "It seems that everyone who doesn't know how to draw has a TV series." He does not think much of the east European cartoon tradition - "there's no warmth" - or the Japanese school - "the violence is unbelievable".

He is married to an Englishwoman - "from Mitcham, does that sound right?" - and has been to lunch once with the Duke of Westminster. "He has his own airfield, you know." He met the Duke's children, "the little princes" as he calls them and was flattered to discover that the Duke's dog was named Scooby Doo. He would cross the Atlantic by Concorde. One occupational hazard was that the pilots would always ask him to draw a cartoon for them: "Thank God I quit flying."

He has a home in Studio City where the previous night he had been taking part in a karaoke evening, doing a bit of Dean Martin. There's also a villa in Palm Springs, complete with pool and tennis court.

But he says he will keep coming in to work until he drops. "I don't know that I love to work but I love to have new ideas." He tells how Sun Microsoft had invited him to talk to their salespeople and explain how he came up with the idea of the Jetsons and the world of the future. "I told them 1,000 years from now or a million years, the problem is always going to be parking." He had also come up with the idea of the treadmill, now an integral part of the LA home, 35 years ago, he says.

The new Tom and Jerry, the seven minute Mansion Cat, contains much of the old mayhem, albeit with objects that were not available when the pair first commenced hostilities in 1940 such as a video machine, a remote control, a waterbed. It contains a Hitchcockian homage to Joe and Bill: a photograph of them appears inside the mansion. Joe has only been the consultant on the film and provides the voice of the mansion's owner, but he says the formula that he and Hanna created in the 30s still holds good: "The secret is the story."

Before we part, he mulls over the idea of a story about the events of the US election as a potential for an adventure, although George W and Al does not have quite the same ring to it as Tom and Jerry. He politely suggests lunch at his house, makes a joke with his assistant, Lois, and says farewell. Tomorrow he will be back in the studio with another idea. That's all, folks.

 Cartoon Network UK presents the world premiere of the new Tom & Jerry cartoon Mansion Cat as part of the 24 hour Tom & Jerry marathon on New Year's Day from 5am.

The Simpsons, where Itchy and Scratchy are a form of homage to Tom and Jerry? "I already did that (the family) with the Flintstones but their material is good. I salute them." South Park? "It seems that everyone who doesn't know how to draw has a TV series." He does not think much of the east European cartoon tradition - "there's no warmth" - or the Japanese school - "the violence is unbelievable". He is married to an Englishwoman - "from Mitcham, does that sound right?" - and has been to lunch once with the Duke of Westminster. "He has his own airfield, you know." He met the Duke's children, "the little princes" as he calls them and was flattered to discover that the Duke's dog was named Scooby Doo. He would cross the Atlantic by Concorde. One occupational hazard was that the pilots would always ask him to draw a cartoon for them: "Thank God I quit flying." He has a home in Studio City where the previous night he had been taking part in a karaoke evening, doing a bit of Dean Martin. There's also a villa in Palm Springs, complete with pool and tennis court. But he says he will keep coming in to work until he drops. "I don't know that I love to work but I love to have new ideas." He tells how Sun Microsoft had invited him to talk to their salespeople and explain how he came up with the idea of the Jetsons and the world of the future. "I told them 1,000 years from now or a million years, the problem is always going to be parking." He had also come up with the idea of the treadmill, now an integral part of the LA home, 35 years ago, he says. The new Tom and Jerry, the seven minute Mansion Cat, contains much of the old mayhem, albeit with objects that were not available when the pair first commenced hostilities in 1940 such as a video machine, a remote control, a waterbed. It contains a Hitchcockian homage to Joe and Bill: a photograph of them appears inside the mansion. Joe has only been the consultant on the film and provides the voice of the mansion's owner, but he says the formula that he and Hanna created in the 30s still holds good: "The secret is the story." Before we part, he mulls over the idea of a story about the events of the US election as a potential for an adventure, although George W and Al does not have quite the same ring to it as Tom and Jerry. He politely suggests lunch at his house, makes a joke with his assistant, Lois, and says farewell. Tomorrow he will be back in the studio with another idea. That's all, folks.  Cartoon Network UK presents the world premiere of the new Tom & Jerry cartoon Mansion Cat as part of the 24 hour Tom & Jerry marathon on New Year's Day from 5am.

webTitle: Peace on earth: not in 2000

fields.headline: Peace on earth: not in 2000
fields.standfirst: From the US election fiasco to the farce of the global climate change talks, Simon Tisdall looks back on the year in international news and prescribes a course of treatment
fields.trailText: From the US election fiasco to the farce of the global climate change talks, Simon Tisdall looks back on the year in international news and prescribes a course of treatment.
fields.body:
For those who believe in human progress, much of what happened around the globe during the first year of the new millennium may have proved discouraging. If the world is viewed as a psychoanalyst might view a patient, then a course of urgent therapy is definitely required.

On a superficial, political level at least, the most powerful countries in the world showed worrying signs of regression. Despite eight largely peaceful years of unprecedented prosperity, the United States managed to saddle itself with a new rightwing administration determined to imperil the nation's well-being through tax cuts favouring the rich, build more missiles, disregard environmental concerns, and ignore the UN. George W Bush's team, inheriting unmatched global power, seems distinctly disinclined to embrace the concept of shared global responsibility.

The manner in which the Republicans won the White House, involving highly dubious if not downright fraudulent poll machinations in Florida and the intervention of a politicised Supreme Court, also cast a shadow over America's supposedly exemplary democracy.

The Bush administration may find it difficult in future to lecture people like Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe on the conduct of free and fair elections after this unimpressive showing.

In Russia, a tired and emotional Boris Yeltsin finally shambled off the presidential stage last spring, leaving the spotlight to his protege, Vladimir Putin.

Mr Putin's approach to his new job also appears rather backward-looking. At home, he has quickly brought his skills as a former KGB officer to bear. The independent media that flourished after the end of the Soviet era have come under particular pressure to toe the line. Moves to reduce the powers of regional governors seem intended to reverse the decentralisation of power begun under Mr Yeltsin. Mr Putin is even trying to restore the old Stalinist era national anthem.

Abroad, Mr Putin is devoting much time and energy to revitalising former Cold War alliances between Russia and states like China, India, Iran, Iraq, Libya, North Korea and Cuba. Some suspect he may also harbour ambitions to reassert Russian dominance in central Asian republics like Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan.

Meanwhile, Mr Putin is threatening a good old-fashioned arms race if the US proceeds with plans to build a national missile defence system.

China in 2000 remained a mystery to itself and others. On the one hand, market force capitalism continued to make strides in the coastal regions, internet usage spread, and the country moved towards membership of the World Trade Organisation.

That will potentially complete the process of opening China to the world that began with the opium trade and the unequal treaties of the 19th century.

On the other hand, China's Communist leaders frequently relapsed into the language of past eras in threatening Taiwan's rulers, for example, with obliteration should they continue to block reunification with the mainland. Chinese defence spending is rising rapidly as that of more developed countries falls.

At home, the regime showed no real sign of relaxing its neo-colonial grip on Tibet, improving its human rights record, curbing executions, or ending its indefensible persecution of religious worshippers of every persuasion.

Having disposed of the Soviet Union, as they see it, the new Bush team in Washington has identified China as the next big strategic competitor and potential adversary. This old thinking seems to be shared in Beijing where some military analysts predict war with the US within the next decade or two.

If that all seems pretty gloomy, then look at what happened in the Middle East during 2000. The year began with high hopes that a new government in Israel would manage a hattrick of peace deals with the Palestinians, the Syrians and the Lebanese.

By the end of the year, those hopes were in tatters, thousands had been killed or injured in fierce fighting in the occupied territories, and the Israeli government had in effect fallen. New elections due next February may return the unreconstructed right to power under general Ariel Sharon.

As these regressive events unfolded, Arab world hostility to the West reached new heights, a global oil price crisis loomed, and dictators like Saddam Hussein of Iraq exploited the tension to flout UN sanctions and threaten renewed regional mayhem.

To cap it all, there was a resurgence of terrorist activity with attacks on US and British targets in Yemen and, perhaps, in Saudi Arabia. Some of this was blamed on Islamic radicals based in Afghanistan where, far from improving, the political, security, and humanitarian situation deteriorated rapidly during the year.

In respect of longer term global issues, 2000 also proved to be a serious disappointment. International talks to implement the 1997 Kyoto accord on curbing global warming ended in abject failure.

Attempts to reform and advance an equitable, rule-based world trade system in the wake of the WTO's Seattle fiasco got virtually nowhere.

And despite the UN's grandiose Millennium Summit in New York last September, war, famine and epidemics continued to exact a rising toll in Africa and elsewhere.

There were some bright spots for progressives, of course. The Yugoslav dictator, Slobodan Milosevic, was finally toppled by a peaceful revolution in Belgrade, possibly bringing to an end a decade of war and horror in the Balkans.

North and South Korea held an unprecedented summit that raised hopes of a lasting settlement in the peninsula. Britain did the decent thing and sent troops to Sierra Leone to help end a horrific civil war and bale out the beleaguered UN peacekeeping mission.

And the EU finally agreed to enlarge to reunite the continent, formally inviting up to 12 east European and Mediterranean countries to start joining the community from 2003.

Perhaps the world will do better in 2001 despite the many ominous portents. Key flashpoints to watch, in no particular order, are Kosovo, Kashmir, Palestine, Taiwan, Afghanistan, Indonesia and Iraq.

But with an economic downturn predicted in the US, with possible knock-on effects in Asia and Europe, things could yet get much worse all round. Better stick with the therapy!

webTitle: Comment: No nukes in India

fields.headline: No nukes
fields.standfirst:
Contrary to what we've been told, Indians are far from keen on their government's nuclear programme

Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: Contrary to what we've been told, Indians are far from keen on their government's nuclear programme.
fields.body:
When I was in Delhi, recently, I was invited to dinner at the home of General Chhachhi. He is a tall Sikh gentleman, who began his career fighting for the British in Burma, fought in all India's wars, won many medals for bravery, and ended up with six stars. The other guests, all from Pakistan, included two more retired generals, the head of a medical institute, a leading newspaper columnist, two trades union organisers, and a number of a key figures from the women's movement. They had come to India to attend an anti-nuclear convention and were being entertained by their fellow Indian peace activist, General Chhachhi.

The nuclear tests that were carried out in India in May 1998, closely followed by Pakistani tests, are widely assumed to have been popular. CNN showed pictures of jubilant Indians and Pakistanis, looking much as though they were celebrating a victory in a Test match. The tests seemed to mark the final demise of secular, humane India, the India of Gandhi and Nehru, of non-violence and tolerance. It was the coming to power of the Hindu nationalist party, the BJP, that led to the tests although the institutional momentum of the Indian Atomic Energy Commission was also an important factor.

Someone at the party said that the RSS, the rightwing movement close to the BJP, had killed Gandhi twice - once in 1948 and once 50 years later - with the tests.

But the BJP triumph was shortlived. Anti-nuclear groups sprang up all over India, much as in Europe in the early 80s. Opinion polls show that more than 70% of the population is opposed to the development of nuclear weapons and the popularity of the BJP has not increased.

Last year, there was a march from Pokharan, the test site, to Sarnath near Varanasi where Buddha lived and preached, to coincide with the first anniversary of the test, which had taken place on Buddha's birthday. Some 30-40,000 people took part, including 80-year-old Gandhians, veterans of the independence movement.

Some 600 people came to the anti-nuclear convention last month from all parts of India, as well as delegations from Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh. They included villagers and people from tribal areas directly affected by the nuclear programme and activists from Kashmir fearful of the consequences of nuclear proliferation. A south Asia committee was also established.

The Indian government has an array of justifications for the tests. The demonstration of a nuclear capability is supposed to counter China and to establish India as one of five great powers on the Eurasian continent in the 21st century (the others are the EU, Japan, Russia and China). Yet the tests, at least initially, isolated India internationally and the sanctions and loss of international confidence contributed to a slowing of India's rapid rate of growth of the early 90s. Subsequent improvements in the US-India relationship are seen to have more to do with Indian achievements in both software and democracy.

The tests were supposed to expose the hypocrisy of the nuclear powers, who have pressed India to join the non-proliferation regime and to sign the comprehensive test ban, while failing to disarm themselves. Yet India and Pakistan's tests have merely contributed to American propaganda about the risks of proliferation.

The threat of an increase in nuclear weapons is supposed to stabilise the subcontinent, to provide a form of deterrence in the region. Yet the existence of nuclear capabilities has not halted the various conflicts in the region and it did not prevent a fourth Indo-Pakistan war in Kargil last year. (A ceasefire has been declared in Kashmir but it is unlikely to hold.)

India can never establish its status through nuclear capabilities. The cost of becoming a nuclear power is the real risk of war, as well as the ongoing cost in terms of the economy and democracy. Far from raising India's status, its threat to increase its nuclear capability helps to entrench the ideology of a world pecking order based on nuclear weapons - and this is an order in which India will always be inferior.

India's comparative political advantage lies in the tradition that the BJP and the RSS are trying to kill. The south Asian anti-nuclear movement could become an inspiration for global disarmament. This is the only way that the hypocrisy of the nuclear weapons powers can be effectively challenged - from below by the anti-nuclear movements, not from above by competitive armament.

Mary Kaldor is a professor at the LSE. The Indian Coalition for Disarmament and Peace: natcom2000@fnmail.com

webTitle: Hollywood actor Jason Robards dies

fields.headline: Hollywood actor Jason Robards dies
fields.standfirst: Obituary
fields.trailText: Jason Robards, the veteran stage and screen actor who won Oscars for his roles in All the President's Men and Julia, has died. He was 78.
fields.body:
Jason Robards, the veteran stage and screen actor who won Oscars for his roles in All the President's Men and Julia, has died. He was 78.

Robards died at the Bridgeport hospital in Fairfield, Connecticut. The hospital did not reveal the cause.

Despite his prolific film work, Robards stayed loyal to the theatre. "The theatre has kept me alive, and it's allowed me to work at my craft," he said in 1997.

He won a Tony award for his performance in The Disenchanted.

Robards was best known to modern movie audiences for his portrayal of the editor of the Washington Post in All the President's Men, the story of the Watergate scandal.

In 1997, he played the tyrannical land baron father in A Thousand Acres, the film adaptation of Jane Smiley's Pulitzer-prize winning novel. The film featured Jessica Lange, Michelle Pfeiffer and Jennifer Jason Leigh as his daughters.

Robards, who was known as a classical actor, shunned the notion of "method; acting and actors who look for motivation for their stage work. "I look at the words," he said in a 1993 interview. "All I know is, I don't do a lot of analysis. I know those words have to move me. I rely on the author. I don't want actors reasoning with me about 'motivation' and all that bull. All I want 'em to do is learn the goddamn lines and don't bump into each other.' "

Robards was born Jason Nelson Robards Jr on July 26 1922, in Chicago, the son of Jason Nelson Robards Sr, a prominent actor. Despite his father's prolific career in more than 170 movies, the young Robards showed no interest in acting.

After graduating in 1939, he went on active duty with the US naval reserve as an apprentice seaman. While serving in the Pacific, Robards read some plays by O'Neill and told his father he wanted to try his hand at acting. At his father's urging, Robards enrolled in the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in 1946.

In 1953, director Jose Quintero gave him the male lead in Victor Wolfson's American Gothic, which opened at the off-Broadway Circle in the Square. He earned his first critical acclaim in May 1956, when he appeared in The Iceman Cometh at the Circle in the Square, again under Quintero's direction.

Robards was married four times - including once to Lauren Bacall - and had six children. In his later years, he lived with his wife of more than 30 years, Lois, in what he once called "a quiet life on the water" in Fairfield, Connecticut.

After a car accident in 1972, Robard's face had to be surgically reconstructed.

Robards suffered bouts of depression and was at a heavy drinker. He said he gave up alcohol in 1974.

webTitle: Leader: House price rises aren't good for all

fields.headline: Through the roof
fields.standfirst:
House price rises aren't good for all

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: House price rises aren't good for all
fields.body:
House prices will rise by 4% next year, the Halifax predicts today. It is just the sort of news to impart a warm, seasonal glow: the two thirds of us who are owners need only sit on our sofas and watch our wealth multiply. It did in 2000. This year house prices rose on average by 6%, which given the low levels at which prices in general are rising, represented a nice little earner. Compared with stock markets, it is a painless way of accumulating capital.

But because house price inflation generates so many winners, at least until the next downturn or credit crunch, we must not lose sight of the losers. House prices rise because demand exceeds supply yet in housing there are all sorts of reasons for restraining building. Some are excellent, such as the desire not to concrete over landscape and environment. But at the end of this truncated supply chain are large - growing - numbers who lack decent housing. (It is, however, good news that fewer people are sleeping rough. The government, roofless tsar and all, deserves the credit extended to it yesterday by the director of Shelter for its initiatives on this front.)

In between the homeless and those enjoying the fruits of house price inflation are large numbers who might move but will not or cannot. If it were cheaper to rent or buy in the capital some of them might become civilian employees of the Metropolitan Police. As it is they are in short supply, said commissioner Sir John Stevens yesterday, and the deficit is forcing police officers into the back office away from the front line. London has special problems with housing for there the flip side of above-average growth in prices has been a crisis of affordability. Building by council and non-profit landlords has nowhere near kept pace with demand - how could it when land has been inflating in value? The result is seen in complaints by the public services at not being able to recruit and retain the people they - we - need.

The government has taken some small steps to encourage subsidised building in London. What it has not done is re- examine the fundamentals in what is, compared with other countries, a skewed property market. Adjusting stamp duty, Gordon Brown made house purchase slightly more expensive for high-value dwellings but has so far given no sign of wanting to tackle property tax - which is surely the key to a fairer spread of this peculiar kind of wealth.

Building by council and non-profit landlords has nowhere near kept pace with demand - how could it when land has been inflating in value? The result is seen in complaints by the public services at not being able to recruit and retain the people they - we - need. The government has taken some small steps to encourage subsidised building in London. What it has not done is re- examine the fundamentals in what is, compared with other countries, a skewed property market. Adjusting stamp duty, Gordon Brown made house purchase slightly more expensive for high-value dwellings but has so far given no sign of wanting to tackle property tax - which is surely the key to a fairer spread of this peculiar kind of wealth.

webTitle: Time for the provinces to fight back?

fields.headline: Time for the provinces to fight back?
fields.trailText: It is an awesome, self-sufficient powerhouse that looms over the regions and plays to no one's rules but its own. But is London sucking the life out of the rest of the country? Hywel Williams believes it is time for the provinces to fight back
fields.body:
Earth in 2000 - it seemed - had nothing to show that was more fair. It was London's year. Heritage had always been good for local trade, but now there was a dramatic edge of elegant modernity to gratify the locals and attract the visitors. Suddenly this was a renaissance city, an affair of courtyards and galleries, of walkways, avenues and towers which revealed new vistas and perspectives to feed the mind and delight the spirit. Forgotten buildings were reborn and new ones rose from the ground. London had made it new and the shock of the modern had arrived by the banks of the Thames.

Londoners still had to contest with the tube, of course, as their daily via dolorosa. But however battered by infrastructure, they knew as they looked above ground that they were privileged to be part of a phenomenon. 2000 was one of those years in urban history when one city held the world's attention. Even the one failure - the Dome - was so monstrous that it could only have happened in the city which was the one and only place to be.

The scale of the success dazzled but also bewildered - so out of pro portion, it seemed, with what went on anywhere else in Britain. It was all heady stuff, and London was certainly good for London. But was it good for Britain as a whole?

London now stretches from Chelmsford in the east to Reading in the west, from St Albans in the north to Crawley in the south. Oxford and Brighton, Colchester and Milton Keynes are its suburbs. All who live within this area are Londoners. They earn more money, exercise sharper wits, lead faster lives and live in more expensive houses than their fellow Britons. Go beyond this domain and you're out of it. What you may gain in manners you will lose in edge and pace. The differences between Londoners and the English are now as great as those between the British and the Italians. This is not a city. It is a nation.

London works harder and longer than England. But the work ethic which is its tribute to residual protestantism is twin to its hedonism. London always did drink more than England - first gin, then beer and now wine. It also swears more, with that violently exhaled "fuck", the product of the extra aspirant peculiar to the word's London pronunciation.

Provincial laments about London recur in English history. The "great wen" was thought to be a spectacularly sinful consumer of goods and gratifier of appetites. But its most important consumption has always been that of people, whom it draws within its maw and turns to its own use. Hence the lament of the London-Welsh preacher that Paddington station was the most sacred spot on earth because it was where the Welsh deposited their souls on arrival. It has always been seen as a foreign place - and one that is out of synch with the English nation's temper, whose most tempting self-image is one of rural withdrawal and gentrified order.

Once there were towns medium and large that mediated between these two extremes of Arcady and Babylon. But their importance in politics and culture has died. The county towns are now just a part of the English countryside. Leeds and Sheffield, Birmingham and Newcastle contribute little to the outside world's view of what England is and does.

Middlemarch is the last great English provincial novel, and George Eliot is now almost as dead as Queen Anne. Arnold Bennett is remembered - if at all - as an omelette invented at the Savoy, not as the voice of the Potteries. Our literary voices are London ones. Muriel Spark's tone is never that far a cry from Kensington and Beryl Bainbridge is more Camden than Scouse. Martin Amis's characters display the Londoner's self-conscious enjoyment of low motive. Julian Barnes's are discoverable only under the auspicious constellations of SW and N. The cardiganed angst of Anita Brookner's heroines is a peculiarly north London condition. Literature enforces London nationalism.

Like all nations, ever since Upper and Lower Egypt started the game, London has its "north-south divide". It has its national symbol in the Eye - a suitably pagan appropriation of Fortuna's wheel for a very secular place - and a worthy necropolis in the Dome. It has an assembly and a healthy tradition of radical rioting. But the nation is more interested in money than in politics. GLC abolition came and went while life flowed back into the boroughs, London's constituent cities of Clerkenwell and Chelsea, Islington and Lambeth.

London is more tolerant of eccentricity, of differences of race, faith, colour and sexuality than the rest of England. But it is a tolerance which is born of indifference. We rub shoulders - and so we have to get on with things rather than introspect.

The nation is international without being particularly outward- looking. It can afford to indulge its own form of provincialism. Here you can eat and forget that most of England remains a gastronomic dump. We're gratified to have 200,000 French citizens here - and some believe the Europhobic press, which sees them all as economic exiles from taxation rather than the jobbing waiters they more often are.

London is the central imaginative, commercial and political fact of modern England. But London as nation is also a European disaster.

There's no continental equivalent for the way London looms over the country in which it finds itself. "Over-centralised" France has always been something of a comforting Euro-sceptic myth, especially after the decentralisation of the 80s. Rhetorical emphasis on national unity - like republican injunctions of fraternity - were only necessary because the reality was so different.

Paris's influence has been cultural and intellectual. But the lives lived in Lyons and Bordeaux, Rennes, Tours and Avignon show not only models of bourgeois civilisation which have disappeared from the English provincial town, but also a diffusion of power and influence. England, the country that united earlier and more completely than any other European one - and did so under the aegis of an imposed Protestant uniformity and a dominant capital - is a European oddity.

In Germany, ancient forms of imperial free cities, the Freistädte, lurk beneath modern Länder and a myriad civic forms of autonomy bloom. In Italy, Rome is a home for the spirit and the bureaucrat, but Turin is one for intellectuals and Milan is the capital of the catwalk and of capitalism alike. Madrid was an Iberian Canberra invented by Philip II at the artificial heart of his country - but in Barcelona, Vigo and Bilbao ancient liberties are revived in the regionalised peninsular experience.

In continental Europe the city-state tradition is alive and kicking. Sometimes that tradition has taken an imperial form (Venice) and an occasionally despotic one (Florence). But by and large it has looked back to a more ancient model, to Athens and Rome - and to republican traditions of participation which made sense because the political unit was small enough.

England offers no parallel to these survivals from an old world renewed. Its regions are not authentic provinces. Wessex and Mercia are dreary units of diminished local government - not cultural forces that attract loyalty. Offa's memory moves no West Midlands dissidents. East Anglia is just a TV franchise and, apart from the terrible sound of Peter Pears wailing in the Aldeburgh marshes, is not a cultural experience. And London in all its national but anonymous vastness can offer no political space - only room to consume.

London is not just bigger - and more conceited - than any other European capital. It is also immeasurably more powerful financially. The euro cannot work if the world's largest foreign exchange market stays outside. Breaking the euro will also be the breaking of Europe. But a wrecked Europe is also the ruination of London.

Europe needs the London nation but cannot accommodate it. That nation's rootless, shiftless sense of adventure makes it an impossible partner in the imagined safety zone of "European integration". To the settled political-historical differences we must add London's present mood of capitalist glee and cultural pride in which it imagines itself to be an imperium receiving tribute from every subject race. The conceit is not just foolish - it has all the elements of a "necessary" tragic conflict: irreconcilable opposites, hubris, ignorance and collision ending in waste.

Berlin, Rome, Paris and their sisters can all handle "Europe". London, seeing it as either a threat or an irrelevance, can't or won't. This is the only capital in Europe which sees itself as an awesomely self-sufficient power exercising a dominion of homogenised taste, central government and financial power over the benighted provinces.

But in post-Maastricht Europe the English regions and cities are now offered not only money but also a constitutional model. There's the prospect of a prestige which they lost in Britain's late imperial 20th century but can regain in the Europeanised England of the 21st century. The provincial elites can confront the metropolitan elites and look beyond them to the European ones. Here lie the seeds of a major conflict of allegiances and powers: not only a regional renaissance but also a capital counter-revolution.

"Provincial" can now mean "European" - not obscure. Yorkshire, Cornwall and Devon can join Rhne-Alpes, Catalonia and Lombardy in the recognition that we are all Euro-regionalists now. But metropolitan London, so long the beneficiary of a feudal dominance over England, will seem self-centred and even small-minded when its self-interest separates it from England.

The journey towards the recognition that the Midlands need not be sodden and unkind will be a bumpy one. But it is more realistic to see here the pattern of an inescapable conflict. England's great cities - the Manchester of the Manchester Guardian and the Birmingham of the Chamberlains - were once civic jewels. But the tradition is decayed - the victim of centralism in both its Old Labour and its rebarbative Thatcherite forms.

The European regionalism which may revive those cities as power-houses does stand in an awkward relationship to the English experience. Continental Europe is a place of shifting boundaries. Alsace- Lorraine transferred from France to Germany and to France again, Poland partitioned, Trieste suspended between the Hapsburg dynasty and the Italian state: all sum up a continuous European story of treaties made and broken, of loyalties transferred and boundaries rendered ambiguous. Where nothing is constitutionally fixed for ever, it makes sense to have multiple allegiances.

Now for the first time in English history since the civil war there is the prospect of the provincial powers distancing themselves from the capital and seeing London as the problem, not the solution. Europe wants to show the regions that they have more in common with each other than they do with London. Stand by, then, for the rise of the English-European region - and for the London backlash.

webTitle: South MPs warn of 'prosperity crisis' as more jobs force up home prices

fields.headline: South MPs warn of 'prosperity crisis' as more jobs force up home prices
fields.trailText: Labour MPs in southern England have started lobbying government ministers to stop creating new jobs in their constituencies, warning of a crisis in prosperity. By Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Labour MPs in southern England have started lobbying government ministers to stop creating new jobs in their constituencies, warning of a crisis in prosperity.

The lobbying has centred on the Thames Valley corridor where demand is pushing up house prices and leading to hundreds of vacancies in key public sector jobs, such as teaching, nursing, policing and bus driving.

MPs report an increasing number of complaints from constituents about a crisis of prosperity, including trans port congestion, massive public sector recruitment problems and excessive housebuilding.

Thames Valley MPs are opposing new investments until more is done to ease the cost of housing.

News that southern MPs are lobbying against extra jobs has surprised ministers, such as the environment minister, Chris Mullin, representing northern cities blighted by joblessness and boarded-up unsaleable homes.

It has also strengthened the hand of ministers, including the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who are pressing for Labour's election man ifesto to contain a clear commitment to a stronger regional policy.

Mr Prescott wants the manifesto to promise to set up elected regional assemblies in areas where there is clear local support for them.

House prices have more than doubled in less than four years in parts of the Thames Valley. Two-bedroom terraced properties are selling for £120,000, far beyond the means of most public sector workers on a salary of £20,000 or £22,000.

The crisis in house prices and travel congestion has already led Jane Griffiths, Labour MP for Reading East to oppose the Meteorological Office relocating to her constituency from nearby Bracknell. She told MPs last week: "We do not need those jobs. New jobs that come into the local area do not necessarily bring benefits with them".

Martin Salter, the neighbouring MP for Reading West said yesterday: "I am deeply worried that when Cisco Systems moves to the area with 5,500 jobs where the company will find the labour and what it will do regional house prices.

"Companies are buying up whole streets of terraced properties for executive homes.

"We are confronting nega tive unemployment along the Thames Valley corridor.

"The labour shortage is so great that corner shops are paying £6 an hour and the local Burger King is offering £5.85 an hour, the equivalent of a semi-skilled job in the North".

David Rendel, the Liberal Democrat MP for Newbury has echoed these fears, pointing out that by the time the new Vodaphone headquarters in his constituency is completed there will be 14,000 more jobs in West Berkshire than people to do the jobs.

Latest projections suggest employment demand is likely to increase by a further 6% by 2006 in the south east, especially in high tech, highly skilled jobs.

Ms Griffiths warned of a possible nightmare scenario in which schools work only a four day week, the streets remain unpoliced, patients lie on trollies for lack of nurses and there are no buses for lack of bus drivers.

Ms Griffiths and Mr Salter claim the crisis is such that the local council is offering to put teachers up in temporary accommodation. Ms Griffiths has received repeated letters from head teachers complaining they are unable to find sufficient numbers of primary school staff, most of them cit ing the lack of affordable housing. Figures by the Royal College of Nursing show the three month vacancy rate has risen by 30% - almost one third - in the south east. She also claimed that some firefighters are travelling from as far as Dorset to work in Reading.

The excess congestion is also forcing public sector bus companies to reduce the number of journeys by as much as 10%. Southern bus firms are in a wages war to retain staff.

Ministers hope this month's £250m starter homes initiative for as many as 10,000 key workers will ease the housing crisis. Rendel has warned that the plan may as help as few as 14 key workers per constituency per year.

Regional MPs are also lobbying the Home Office to give local police forces greater discretion in the use of extra government money designed to boost recruitment.

The Home Office has insisted the money earmarked in a new crime fighting fund must be used solely for salaries, but local MPs want some of the money to be siphoned off to help police buy homes. The proposal has the support of the Berkshire police, but has so far been vetoed by the Home Office.

webTitle: Hunting ban row takes to the street

fields.headline: Hunting ban row takes to the street
fields.trailText: The biggest event in the fox hunting calendar went ahead amid bitter scenes yesterday as thousands of protesters turned out to jeer and heckle riders at Boxing Day meets across the country. Rebecca Allison and Patrick Wintour report
fields.body:
The biggest event in the fox hunting calendar went ahead amid bitter scenes yesterday as thousands of protesters turned out to jeer and heckle riders at Boxing Day meets across the country.

Emotions ran high on both sides of the political divide less than a week after MPs voted heavily in favour of a second reading of the government bill banning fox hunting in England and Wales.

The national debate was most fiercely played out in Maldon, Essex, where members of the hunting lobby and protesters took up positions on opposite sides of the narrow high street in a face-off lasting several hours.

Traffic was diverted from the usually quiet town centre as two small armies of more than 500, hemmed in by crash barriers and police, taunted each other as they waited for the local hunt to pass through.

Protesters waved placards showing pictures of brutalised foxes as they declared "moral war" on the hunting lobby.

One activist, a hunt saboteur for 20 years, said the feeling was one of "now or never". The 53-year-old professional who declined to be named, said: "This is our finest hour. If we do not get a ban now, I do not believe we ever will. Hunting isn't the cruellest thing going on. It is the tip of a huge iceberg but it is the easiest thing to get banned. It has got to go.

"It would be a moral victory and it would open the floodgates for further essential reform. This is crucial for animal rights. It is a war. There is no other word for it. It is not a class war, it is a moral war."

Laina Cracknell, executive committee member of the League Against Cruel Sports, said she believed the bell was finally tolling for hunting and was confident that an absolute ban was the only was forward.

But, across the road, the Countryside Alliance poured scorn on the "excessive boasts" of animal rights activists, dismissing any suggestion of defeat and insisting thousands of people across the UK had shown themselves committed to securing hunting's future.

Liz Mort, spokeswoman for the pro-hunting group, said: "We are very buoyant and optimistic and we are certainly looking forward to hunting in the next millennium. There are few protesters compared with the numbers of supporters."

An hour-long standoff escalated into an emotional frenzy as the men and women of the Essex Farmers & Union Foxhounds hunt approached Maldon high street. Horses and hounds appeared bewildered by the deafening noise as they were corralled between the two camps, while immaculate riders greeted supporters, smoked cigarettes and enjoyed cups of wine before the day's exertions.

Police later confirmed that there had been one arrest after hunters and horses were pelted with missiles, including eggs, during their 15-minute appearance in Maldon.

Protesters also targeted a meet of the Holcombe Harriers near Bolton, Greater Manchester, and a further 120 activists descended on the Spooners and West Dartmoor hunt's meet in Tavistock, Devon. At the Duke of Beaufort's estate in south Gloucestershire, police estimated there were about 1,500 hunt supporters.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, recently offered the hunters a glimmer of hope that the government might be prepared to back down, when he came out against an outright ban, declaring his support for a compromise which would allow the option of tighter licensing of hunts.

But the bill is certain to meet passionate opposition in the Lords where peers will be allowed to vote on three options.

The Conservative leader, William Hague, is also under backbench pressure to give a commitment to make repealing a ban a top priority if re-elected.

Mr Hague was warned last week by the former agriculture secretary Douglas Hogg that he would "have to look over his shoulder" if he did not give a clear commitment.

He told MPs he was not speaking for himself, but some of his colleagues in saying: "If we get back in with a majority and the bill is passed, we will do our utmost to ensure that hunting is lawful once again."

The bill will reach the Lords near the end of February. Discussions have already started on the best sequence of voting to ensure that the Lords get a proper chance to support for their preferred option. It is expected the Commons will vote for an outright ban early next month. The Lords will then be given the option of voting for the ban, a licensing authority or self-regulation.

The hunting bill presents three options:

A complete ban on hunting with hounds - put forward by the RSPCA, the League Against Cruel Sports and the International Fund for Animal Welfare under the umbrella group Deadline 2000

Statutory regulation - based on the premise that hunting with dogs should be allowed to continue only on a licensed basis with an enforceable code of conduct - put forward by the cross-party middle way group

Self-regulation - put forward by the Countryside Alliance

MPs are to vote on the three options in January

Bill will then go into standing committee, to be completed by February 8

Expected to go to House of Lords by end of February
