webTitle: Taken for a ride

fields.headline: Taken for a ride
fields.standfirst: Rural England was the biggest loser from bus privatisation, but can government subsidies now reconnect isolated villages? Chris Arnot goes in search of an answer
fields.trailText: Rural England was the biggest loser from bus privatisation, but can government subsidies now reconnect isolated villages? Chris Arnot goes in search of an answer.
fields.body:
It's just before one o'clock on a Friday lunchtime and I'm outside a pub called the Swan in the Staffordshire village of Brewood, fervently hoping that this is the right place to catch the bus. If I miss this one, there's not another for two hours, 20 minutes. There is no physical manifestation of a bus stop and the bend I'm standing on is decorated with double yellow lines. But the locals assure me that this is the spot and, sure enough, the single-decker 880 grinds to a halt here at 12.54 precisely: bang on time.

There is one other passenger. Caroline Starkey runs a nursery at Codsall, terminus of this comparatively new service from Stafford. "Before it started, I had to get a lift to Albrighton, catch a train to Wolverhampton and then catch a bus to my home in Wheaton Aston," she says.

"And if the train was delayed and I missed the bus, there would be a two-hour wait for the next one." She is delighted to have a direct route between work and home, but ponders: "I don't know how long they'll be able to keep it going unless more people use it."

She has a point. Only three more passengers get on between here and Stafford, almost an hour away. So it comes as a surprise to learn from the county council that this route has one of the best returns in terms of passenger numbers among any of those opened locally as a direct result of the government's rural bus subsidy grant.

There had been even more empty seats on the outward bus to Brewood that morning. I met an elderly woman who travelled only as far as the outskirts of Stafford and a sixth-former who got on at a village called Acton Trussell and got off again, 10 minutes later, at Penkridge. For most of the 55-minute journey, I was ferried about in splendid isolation, having spent just £1.60 for what amounted to a lengthy taxi journey into the heart of rural middle England. We splashed down narrow lanes, past flooded fields and into the high streets of villages whose ancient cores are now hemmed in by swathes of new housing with double garages and one, two, sometimes three cars parked on their drives.

I'd come to Staffordshire to see what it's like for the 30% of rural folk who don't have access to a car. On their behalf, the government has set about trying to patch up the threadbare service bequeathed by its predecessors. The subsidy grants brought in two years ago have initiated more than 2,000 new services and the recent rural white paper committed another £130m over the next three years.

"But while they're shovelling money in one door, a whole lot of services are going out of the other," warns Stephen Joseph, director of pressure group Transport 2000. "Companies like Stagecoach and First Group have been cutting back because economics have turned against them. We've heard a lot about truckers, but bus companies have also had to pay the price of rising oil prices."

Not entirely, mind you. On rural routes, they get 36p a litre back in the form of fuel duty rebate. But in return they are expected to meet strict timetables, or face hefty penalties from local traffic commissioners. Fines of up £200,000 are not unknown, which may have helped convince shareholders that the margins from running country services are just not enough. Under terms laid down by the 1985 Transport Act, companies have to give just six weeks' notice before de-registering a service.

Which may explain why the government's long-term forecasts are on the cautious side. The rural white paper sets a target of raising from 36% to 48% the number of households living within walking distance of an hourly or better bus service within the next 10 years. Whether we shall be anywhere nearer to the much-vaunted integrated transport system by then remains to be seen. Certainly there's not much evidence of it yet, if Staffordshire is anything to go by.

The initial signs were good. My bus stop, I had been reliably informed, was right outside Stafford railway station. But although the smart new shelter harboured timetables for several routes, there was nothing to suggest that the 880 might stop here. So I went back into the station and asked at the information desk. Judging by the blank expression that greeted me, I might as well have been asking about flight times from Heathrow. Come to think of it, details about planes might have been more forthcoming as the operating company here is Virgin Trains. Other private companies deal with buses. The fact that passengers might want to use both doesn't seem to have registered.

At least the driver of a rival company's bus, called Arriva, tried to be more helpful about the possible whereabouts of the 880. "I think I've seen it start here," he said, "but I'm not too sure. If it doesn't turn up, get one of ours at 10.40. Get off at Coven and you can catch a Warstone's bus to Brewood. You might have to wait a bit, mind you."

Luckily, there was no need. The 880 pulled up on the dot of 10.35. The county council assures me that timetables for the service have now been installed at its new bus shelters. Meanwhile, members of its transport committee have to decide this month whether or not to subsidise another route in the north of the county due to be de-registered on January 21. It's a classic example of the scenario put forward by Joseph whereby private money is going out of one door as fast as public money is coming in the other. Unless Staffordshire chooses to add to the £1.6m it already puts into rural buses, that route through the county's sparsely populated northern moorlands will simply wind up.

"The government has decreed that its grants can't be used to subsidise routes that were there in the first place," says Joseph. "The money has to go towards opening new routes. So it's capital funding with no extra revenue funding. That's down to local authorities and there are great variations between them. The mechanisms to make the system work nationally are rather remote. There's no equivalent of Ofsted."

So what is needed, I suggest, is a body called Offbus.

"That's right," Joseph agrees. "Unfortunately, it's an accurate description of what too many rural people still are."

webTitle: Irritating buzzwords of the year

fields.headline: Whasssuuup with this? It's an irritating buzzword, innit?
fields.trailText: Michael Quinion, lexicographer and scholar of language, finds it hard to work out which of the favourite British buzzwords of 2000 vexed him most. Was it "WHASSSUUUP?" or was it "political football"? The first had been around for months, thanks to the Budweiser TV ads.
fields.body:
Michael Quinion, lexicographer and scholar of language, finds it hard to work out which of the favourite British buzzwords of 2000 vexed him most. Was it "WHASSSUUUP?" or was it "political football"? The first had been around for months, thanks to the Budweiser TV ads.

But then in the closing weeks of the year "political football" - a platitude which he hoped had died in the 1970s - suddenly came back into currency.

That was thanks to William Hague's reference to the Damilola Taylor murder. "It's one of those cliches which makes me want to throw things at my radio every time I hear it," Mr Quinion said.

The collection has been compiled in separate batches by Nigel Wilcockson, editor of the New Penguin English Dictionary, and his staff, and by Mr Quinion, a contributor to the Oxford English Dictionary, former assistant editor of the Oxford Dictionary of New Words and founder of the popular website World Wide Words.

The Penguin list will be used as a shortlist for the next edition of its dictionary. It contains one word - "upspeaking" - which is thought to be the dictionary world's first recognition of a new speech habit which has swept the world in little over 20 years since it began in a valley in California. Mr Wilcockson defines the habit as "finishing your sentences with an upward inflection, as if asking a question rather than making a statement".

Penguin staff were excited to hear Jamie Oliver using the word "pukka" in its original anglicised sense of "first rate" or "excellent", after almost a century in which phrases like "pukka sahib" had been used as terms of mockery against the former British empire.

Another phrase, "innit?" was revived by the white rap comedian Ali G after first being put on people's lips by Harry Enfield's character Stavros as a satire on poor English-speaking on late 1980s television.

In vogue

Watercooler TV
Television programme obsessively discussed in offices

Chad
Waste material removed from punched cards

M-commerce
Trying to sell things via mobile phones

Scooby Doo
Rhyming slang for clue, as in "I don't have a Scooby Doo")

Domestic goddess
As in Nigella Lawson

B2B/B2C
Business-to-business and business-to-consumer business

Mommy-hacking
Parents' efforts to track or restrict kids' internet/email activities

Economy class syndrome
Blood clots caused by long-haul flights

Useful link
Michael Quinion's website: www.worldwidewords.org

webTitle: Sperm donors face loss of privacy

fields.headline: Sperm donors face loss of privacy
fields.trailText: The government is about to relax strict rules of confidentiality protecting the identity of sperm donors to allow their children to discover key facts about their genetic origins. By John Carvel
fields.body:
The government is about to relax strict rules of confidentiality protecting the identity of sperm donors to allow their children to discover key facts about their genetic origins.

Yvette Cooper, the public health minister, will produce a consultation paper early in the new year which will spark a public debate on changing the regulations guarding the anonymity of people donating sperm, eggs or embryos.

She does not want children to have a right to learn the identity of their biological parents. Such a prospect would deter donors who might reasonably fear they could be pursued by large numbers of unknown offspring seeking emotional or financial support.

But the government will consult on a range of options that could allow the children of "gamete donors" to build up a picture of the biological parent's characteristics.

The least radical option would allow disclosure of non-identifiable information about the donor's background, education, occupation, interests and characteristics such as hair colour.

This option is likely to include details of the biological parent's racial background.

A second more far reaching option would extend to information that could come closer to identifying the donor, including medical history and family health records. Although this would not be a direct breach of anonymity, it might provide clues that could allow the child to track down a biological parent.

A third option will be to give the donor an opportunity to choose to provide a name and address at the time the donation is made that would be available to the child on request.

More than 11,000 children have been born by donor insemination since 1991 when the human fertilisation and embryology authority was set up to license fertility clinics and keep records of all sperm and egg donors.

Under present regulations children over 18 can be told - after appropriate counselling - whether or not they were conceived by donor insemination. The same applies to children over 16 who want to get married.

But in neither case can any information be given about the background or characteristics of the donor.

Ms Cooper will reassure past donors that there is no question of changing the law retrospectively and their anonymity will remain protected.

Doctors and infertility support groups are concerned that relaxation of the confidentiality rules could discourage potential donors, who are paid on average £15. But there is evidence of confusion and insecurity among children who have been told they were conceived by artificial insemination, but denied further information about their biological parent.

Liberty, the civil rights organisation, is bringing a test case under the Human Rights Act on behalf of a brother and sister conceived through donor sperm insemination demanding the right to know details of their father.

Adam and Jo Rose, now in their 30s, argue that the law banning disclosure of information about sperm donors is a breach of article 8, the right to respect for private and family life.

A Department of Health official said: "Our proposals are responding to an increase in numbers of gamete donors raising questions of whether people should have the right to know their genetic background. Ministers know this is a sensitive issue and we will need full consultation with interested parties and individuals."

webTitle: Gunman kills 7 at net firm

fields.headline: Gunman kills 7 at net firm
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in the US
fields.trailText: A 42-year-old gunman armed with an AK47 rifle, shotgun and semi-automatic handgun yesterday shot dead seven of his fellow employees on their first day back at work after Christmas at the offices of an internet consulting company.
fields.body:
A 42-year-old gunman armed with an AK47 rifle, shotgun and semi-automatic handgun yesterday shot dead seven of his fellow employees on their first day back at work after Christmas at the offices of an internet consulting company.

"I'm shocked, totally shocked," said Nancy Pecjo, an employee of the firm, Edgewater Technology, in Wakefield, a middle-class dormitory town about 10 miles north of Boston, Massachusetts. "It's a great company, a wonderful company."

Police took away the gunman, named as Michael McDermott, who had entered the building carrying a bag and three weapons, and then systematically walked through the office shooting dead seven colleagues in different areas of the building.

He was found sitting in the lobby of the building, near the body of one of his victims. Officers, who disarmed and subdued him, dismissed earlier reports that there was a second attacker after a search of the area had been completed.

"It's workplace related," said John McEvoy, an assistant district attorney in Middlesex County, though he would not indicate more about the motive. The gunman had been working for Edgewater since last March, although the spokesman declined to say whether the killings related to unconfirmed reports of lay-offs. Edgewater's website says it wants to hire 120 more staff next year.

"Mr McDermott is going to be charged with seven counts of murder," said Mr McEvoy. "There are no other victims. There are no other shooters. I'm not going to comment on what was said or his condition. He was armed and had to be subdued. He was sitting in the lobby when they [the police] arrived. He was heavily armed."

McDermott was reported to have shot some of his victims at close range.

Pam Davies, a waitress at the nearby Grill Express coffee shop, said: "I was behind the counter and looking out the front window and people were just running with panic on their faces. They all came running in and said, 'Pammy, there's a man in there and he's shooting.' I said, 'You're kidding me.' They said, 'There's a man there, a big man.'"

As many as 250 people were working in the Harvard Mills complex, a three-storey red brick former factory that houses several hi-tech companies. Edgewater ,which also has offices in Alabama, Arkansas, Minnesota and New Hampshire, creates software systems for internet commerce. Its clients include American Express and the United States postal service.

The firm, with annual revenue of about $20m, has about 100 employees at Wakefield, up to 40 of whom were at work at the time of the shooting.

Mark Brownson, an insurance agent who had been listening in on police radio, said: "We heard there was a suspect running around, 6ft 2in, with a couple of firearms. Employees were running out of the building. Police were pulling up and ducking behind cars preparing for the situation. It was pretty crazy."

Edgewater's website says it wants to hire 120 more staff next year. "Mr McDermott is going to be charged with seven counts of murder," said Mr McEvoy. "There are no other victims. There are no other shooters. I'm not going to comment on what was said or his condition. He was armed and had to be subdued. He was sitting in the lobby when they [the police] arrived. He was heavily armed." McDermott was reported to have shot some of his victims at close range. Pam Davies, a waitress at the nearby Grill Express coffee shop, said: "I was behind the counter and looking out the front window and people were just running with panic on their faces. They all came running in and said, 'Pammy, there's a man in there and he's shooting.' I said, 'You're kidding me.' They said, 'There's a man there, a big man.'" As many as 250 people were working in the Harvard Mills complex, a three-storey red brick former factory that houses several hi-tech companies. Edgewater ,which also has offices in Alabama, Arkansas, Minnesota and New Hampshire, creates software systems for internet commerce. Its clients include American Express and the United States postal service. The firm, with annual revenue of about $20m, has about 100 employees at Wakefield, up to 40 of whom were at work at the time of the shooting. Mark Brownson, an insurance agent who had been listening in on police radio, said: "We heard there was a suspect running around, 6ft 2in, with a couple of firearms. Employees were running out of the building. Police were pulling up and ducking behind cars preparing for the situation. It was pretty crazy."

webTitle: Guardian Christmas charity appeal

fields.headline: Giving a vital helping hand to the needy
fields.trailText: Guardian Christmas charity appeal: A blaze of publicity, especially at Christmas, brings charities much needed income. But too often donors never get the chance to ask how the cash is spent. This week we caught up with the groups that featured in last year's appeal
fields.body:
Ockenden International

This charity promotes self-reliance for refugees and other displaced people. Working with refugees, survivors of wars and the internally displaced, the organisation's aim is to help restore self-sufficiency.

Often the charity works with families where the heads of the households are women, and where there are disabled or very young children. Frequently the people needing help are among the most vulnerable in society.

Ros Taylor, the charity's fundraising manager, said: "The £50,000 we received from Guardian readers after last year's Christmas appeal was used as quite a big contribution towards a pilot programme in Adjumani, northern Uganda, one of the main areas where the Ebola virus has struck."

Adjumani is an area where many Sudanese refugees flee to in order to escape the war in southern Sudan.

Agnes Aldino, one of the women we heard about last year, had seen her youngest child die from malaria in a shanty town near Port Sudan. She has not seen her firstborn, who lives in northern Uganda, for 15 years. Another of her daughters lives with relatives in the south of Sudan where the civil war grinds on.

Agnes's husband has vanished, and now only Viola, another daughter aged 13, is staying with her.

Their beds take up most of the small shelter they occupy on the edge of the desert where temperatures soar to 45C and sand storms rattle the flattened cooking oil drums which serve as walls.

For Agnes, 35, the choices have been stark. Some women go into prostitution to provide for their families. After arriving in Port Sudan she chose a business almost as risky in a strict Islamic society - brewing alcohol.

"My condition was very bad," she says. "I was brewing and selling spirits made from date palms. The police used to catch me and send me to prison for three months at a time.

"But I needed to make the money to eat and feed Viola. I didn't have anyone to help me. When I was in prison I used to leave Viola with neighbours but I couldn't continue doing that."

She came to the attention of Ockenden's team of workers helping refugees to learn new trades.

A year on and thanks to a loan from Ockenden International, Agnes is involved in handicrafts and has a small catering business of her own selling tea and coffee in a market place.

She is also able to give help to other women, and more importantly she earns an income for her family which is not likely to land her in jail.

(Ockenden International: 01483 772012)

The Fairtrade Foundation

A total of £50,000 was raised last year, as a result of the Guardian Christmas Appeal, for the Fairtrade Foundation, a charity that helps impoverished farmers in developing countries get a fair deal and cover the cost of their crop production.

The donated money went towards the charity's communications programme, boosting by 25% the number of consumers aware of the Fairtrade mark and now buying at least some of their goods as Fairtrade products.

The Guardian last year highlighted the need for fair trade in the four Windward islands that supply Britain with many of its bananas.

Last year, Renwick Rose who lives in St Vincent, had been trying to persuade the big supermarkets to offer Fairtrade bananas.

She said: "When you buy a cheap banana [one sold on the conventional market] you are unwittingly participating in the exploitation of labour. There is blood, sweat and toil behind that banana.

"Fairtrade does not ask you to pay more - just what it costs."

One year on, farmers' products from these islands appear in UK shops with the consumer guarantee label awarded by the Fairtrade Foundation to companies buying on the alternative, fair trade, market.

Julia Powell, the group's communication director, said: "There's no doubt that that kind of publicity in the Guardian helped to put pressure on the supermarkets who in turn put pressure further down the line.

"Already on St Vincent a few hundred farmers are generating an extra £1,000 a week from the sales to the UK market and that is going in a separate fund which all four islands will decide how to spend to improve conditions generally.

"It means [farmers] are earning around a third more than they would have been getting - though they are having difficulties even covering their costs, let alone making an income."

Phil Wells, of the Fairtrade Foundation, says there are at least 500,000 farmers around the world probably benefiting from the charity's work. "But very many farmers - the bulk of the small farmers around the world - are suffering terribly still."

(Fairtrade Foundation: 0207 4055942)

Friends for Young Deaf People

A partnership that helps deaf people become active members of society, Friends for Young Deaf People wanted to provide a family coordinator to work with parents of deaf babies.

Through last year's Guardian Christmas Appeal, the charity was able to highlight the lack of services available for parents of newly diagnosed deaf babies.

Therese Wilson, FYD's head of marketing and fundraising, said many parents the charity sees have just discovered the disability in their baby, deafness that sometimes has occurred after meningitis or measles. Whatever the cause, the impact is always the same - shock and bewilderment.

"If you are hearing parents, it's a ghastly shock," said Ms Wilson. "And there are not that many services available to advise parents on how to cope. Parents ask themselves how are they going to communicate with their child.

"How will their baby learn to speak and read? They are really terrified for their child's future.

"Even basic questions such as how you tell your children you love them or how deaf children tell you they are thirsty, seem enormous problems at first.

"But all these problems can be overcome and there are tried and tested mechanisms for teaching your child to sign. You do build up a rapport with them. But you need the confidence to know that it will be all right.

"That's what FYD plans to give these parents."

(FYD: 01342 323444)

The Family Welfare Association

Publicity, said Helen Dent, chief executive of the Family Welfare Association, has over the past year pumped up their annual fundraising by £50,000, thanks to the Guardian Christmas Appeal for 1999.

This has meant more money for giving directly to poor families living in Britain.

One case she remembers well was that of the Iraqi mother of three who fled Saddam Hussein's regime.

She is now living in Wales but has been waiting two years for the outcome of her asylum application. With her husband missing, presumed dead, she is struggling to support three children aged 11, 13 and 15.

She is not allowed to work and besides finding it difficult to adapt to the new culture in the UK, still fears she may be deported back to Iraq.

Although this family gets 90% of income support benefit, they are living at 10% below subsistence level and they are not entitled to other benefits normally allowed those on full income support.

They receive £105 a week out of which they pay water rates, gas, electricity and laundry bills, and bus fares to school.

It leaves just £50 a week for food and clothing.

The charity stepped in provide cash for compulsory school uniforms, without which the children would not have been able to attend lessons and continue their education.

Ms Dent said: "Sadly, this case is typical. We are hearing so many stories about asylum seekers living in severe poverty here and it's difficult keeping track of all the cases.

"This Iraqi family were struggling but by refugee standards were fortunate. Normally, most refugees live on 70% of the income support rate, barely enough to survive on. It is not as if they have a choice. Many families, like these Iraqis, cannot go back to their country because they would be killed.

"While there is never going to be enough money given by Guardian readers or other organisations to deal with such issues, we feel we can provide some help to tackle these ongoing problems."

(Family Welfare Association: 0207 2546251)

webTitle: Council's goal is to end street soccer

fields.headline: Council's goal is to end street soccer
fields.trailText: Boys - and grown men - who kick footballs on street corners in Liverpool while dreaming of scoring the winner at Anfield or Goodison may soon be shown the red card. David Ward reports
fields.body:
Boys - and grown men - who kick footballs on street corners in Liverpool while dreaming of scoring the winner at Anfield or Goodison may soon be shown the red card.

New by-laws proposed by the Liberal Democrat-controlled city council would ban street football, the traditional nursery for soccer talent, from "roads, footways, forecourts or grassed areas".

Members of the community safety committee have ordered a report on how a ban could be implemented. But the move has already been condemned as "bureaucracy gone mad" by the former Liverpool skipper, Tommy Smith, who learnt his skills on the terraced streets of Kirkdale.

Councillors plan to open up school yards and create kick-about areas in public parks to children no longer able to play in the streets. "We get a constant stream of complaints from residents who are plagued by children playing football outside their homes," said Vera Best, a councillor. "It's often a source of very real hardship for people, who can be afraid to challenge rowdy gangs of teenagers. Sometimes there are even groups of men playing in the street. You can imagine the nightmare for pensioners who have balls kicked at their walls or windows at all hours of the day and night.

"There have been some very nasty cases of pensioners being intimidated. This is a very real problem and one we cannot simply ignore."

But Mr Smith, a former England international, said the proposals would damage professional and amateur soccer in Liverpool and prevent players of the talent of Robbie Fowler and Steve McMannaman from developing their skills.

"This is a crackpot idea, petty bureaucracy gone mad," he said. "The back streets of Liverpool are the real breeding ground for natural talent. It's no use saying all the kids can join clubs or schoolboy leagues - that happens as they get older."

webTitle: Leader: Adoption is no easy option

fields.headline: Reshuffling families
fields.standfirst: Adoption is no easy option
fields.trailText: Adoption is no easy option
fields.body:
The prime minister said last week that he wanted to see a large expansion in the number of children being adopted, 40% more by 2005. Such children are mostly in care. They number some 60,000 and of them 65% are placed with foster families; more than 6,000 are in residential homes. Such care is no longer as institutional as it once was. Local authority and voluntary homes are now on a more human scale with about 10 children per home. Children have more space and choice. In many such homes the staff work heroically against a background where there are far more rigorous safeguards against abuse. Serious institutional elements remain: in the physical state of the homes, the lack of privacy, the absence of continuity of care akin to a parent. For some children life is grim, with staff who do not listen and give young people no sense of being valued. Children living with foster parents have a better chance of a decent life, but many suffer moves that are far too frequent.

Anyone familiar with the catalogue of failure in helping children in care will endorse the Blair government's belated reforms. The state has proved to be a hopeless parent. Until recently it ignored children once they turned 16, remained indifferent if they became pregnant, refused to intervene when they became homeless. Of all vulnerable groups, none has been treated more shabbily than children in care. Up to one in four girls leaving care is pregnant, three out of four have no qualifications, eight out of 10 have no job to go to. Is it any wonder that one third of young people in prison and one half of homeless single people were previously in care?

Yet ministers have been too ready to embrace simplistic equations. They have put together the 2,300 children in care waiting to be adopted and the 1,300 families waiting to adopt a child. But many of this latter group are not looking for the older children who form the population in care. In an age when single women look after their own children, there are far fewer babies for adoption - only 4% of adoptions involve children under five years of age, let alone five months. There is an over-supply of families looking for a child aged under five and an under-supply of those wanting older and less easy to manage children. Modern adoption is no longer a one-off process. Adoptive parents need long-term support to help look after their often badly traumatised children. There was not enough readiness to face reality when Tony Blair spoke last week. No one mentioned that one in five adoptions breaks down. For children aged nine or over on adoption, the failure rate is up to 40%.

Yet ministers did identify areas where progress can be achieved. There is a twentyfold variation in adoption rates between local authorities. New national standards will help identify poor performers. A recent study showed the number of adoptions could be increased by 700 if all local councils could be brought up to the level of the top quarter. Speedier decisions will reduce the damage which children suffer when they are shuffled from one foster family to another: 18% have experienced three placements on adoption, and 14% six. By the time a child has been in care for 18 months, it has an 80% chance of remaining there for at least four years. The new plan requires councils to finish their assessment within six months, and find a family within a further six months.

Ministers must accept the net of potential adopters has to be widened. If more adoptions are to be achieved, then single, unmarried couples in stable relations and gay people will be needed.

webTitle: Readers' letters

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: It was good to read about the work of the commission for health improvement or CHI (Dream teams, December 13), but one thing you failed to point out was that just as we welcome one excellent national NHS watchdog to the scene, the government proposes abolishing the local watchdogs known as community health councils (CHCs).
fields.body:
Watchdog warning

It was good to read about the work of the commission for health improvement or CHI (Dream teams, December 13), but one thing you failed to point out was that just as we welcome one excellent national NHS watchdog to the scene, the government proposes abolishing the local watchdogs known as community health councils (CHCs).

The commission would be the first to admit that its in-depth look at each NHS trust every four years is no substitute for the ongoing local monitoring and the information gleaned from comments and complaints collected by CHCs. Indeed, even these reviews benefit substantially from the provision by CHCs of locally acquired data.

Exposure of scandals is very often sparked by groundwork by local CHCs. They have been instrumental in helping the victims of Rodney Ledward and the Alder Hey debacle achieve some sense of justice. And, working as I do for a CHC, I am acutely aware of how many potential injustices are avoided thanks to skilled support for patients and families by CHC staff, and independent scrutiny of services by voluntary CHC members.

If the government has its way, abolition will take place in March 2002. It is hard to see how the proposed "patient forums", serviced by staff of NHS trusts themselves, or the so-called hospital "Pals" employed to smooth things over at reception desks, can offer anything near as potent as CHCs. Wouldn't it make sense if their role was retained, possibly as a national network linked to CHI?

Peter Walsh
Carshalton, Surrey

Benefit bungle

Your article on Norman McKillop-Concannon describes an appalling administrative failure on the part of the relevant local authority and its housing benefit sub-contractor (Bedtime story, December 20).

The resentment felt by him, and presumably many others, is understandable and needs addressing.

It occurs to me that their experience of maladministration may be one that could be examined by way of a joint action in the courts. Such attention would do much to focus the minds of those responsible and, hopefully, provide recompense to those tenants and landlords who have suffered.

Cyril Bezant
Birmingham

 It is timely you raise the operation of the "independent" social fund run by the DSS. The Commons social security committee has announced an examination of the role, practice and future of the fund. Write to the committee at 7 Millbank, London SW1P 3JA by January 19. I believe a cash limited, unjust loans system should be replaced with rights to benefits.

Tom Lamb
Middlesbrough

Write to Guardian Society,119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email: society@theguardian.com

Please supply your full address.

fields.headline: Front to back
fields.trailText: Innocence of youth
fields.body:
Innocence of youth A schoolboy who went to South Tyneside magistrates court while on work experience with a firm of solicitors ended up in the dock when an usher mistook him for a defendant.

Metro, 6.12.00 (Heather Gould, Newcastle upon Tyne)

Last bus A member of the Keighley bus museum in Yorkshire had his last wish granted when his coffin was carried in a 1956 Daimler bus to the funeral.
Bradford Telegraph and Argus, 29.11.00 (T Holderness, Bradford)

Chad line Americans trying to find out more about chads, the holes punched in ballot papers in the controversial presidential election, deluged the website of St Chad's church in Lichfield, Staffordshire.

webTitle: Round-up of the year's environmental events

fields.headline: Deep end
fields.standfirst: John Vidal and Paul Brown mop up events from a year  that brought increased global warming, severe flooding and  the damp squib of climate talks
fields.trailText: John Vidal and Paul Brown mop up events from a year that brought increased global warming, severe flooding and the damp squib of climate talks
fields.body:
It started with the popping of millions of natural champagne corks, and ended with an RSPB warning that sales of plastic corks were rising so fast that the world's cork forests would be uneconomic and in danger of being cut down within 15 years, with terrible consequences.

In between, there was record rainfall, record floods, record deaths from the human form of BSE, record low fish catches in the North Sea, record melting of the icecaps, record numbers of rats in Britain and record emissions from the environment secretary following the collapse of the climate talks in the Hague.

All the indications are that 2000 was another ecologically disastrous year, with further incremental deterioration of vital resources and eco-systems. Worldwide desertification, the result of a combination of unsustainable farming and global climate change, was found to be advancing quickly and menacing far more people than previously thought. Global deforestation continued apace, with approximately 10.2m hectares lost - a slight improvement on previous years - and there were yet more weather-related disasters around the world.

Worryingly, the first global survey of groundwater pollution showed that a toxic brew of pesticides, nitrogen fertilisers, industrial chemicals and heavy metals is fouling fresh water in deep aquifers everywhere. In addition, the ozone hole got bigger and coral reefs were in ever deeper crisis.

And 2000 wasn't too kind to people, either. Wealth and natural resources were concentrated into ever fewer hands as most countries dogmatically pursued the path of economic liberalisation and privatisation. International trade made competition tougher and environmental protection measures were further eroded.

The patenting of life forms continued at a dizzying pace, world debt grew, despite some notable write-offs in Britain, and the technological gap between rich and poor grew. The number of children with no access to education reached about 125m and, while there are no official figures, the numbers now trying to flee deep poverty and environmentally unsustainable regions is thought to be growing.

The nuclear industry began the year badly with a severely critical assessment of safety at Sellafield, and Japan demanding that nuclear fuel with falsified documents be returned. By the end of the year, the government had still not produced its green paper on what to do with nuclear waste and the growing mountain of plutonium no one wants. Next year might see the decision to bring reprocessing to an end as customers get increasingly edgy about the cost and would prefer to store spent fuel.

The international protests against globalisation, which is more and more blamed for the world's woes, increased in depth and intensity. More than one million people worldwide took to the streets in 2000. After the shock of Seattle at the end of 1999, protests in Prague, London and 24 other countries made headlines, but there was little sign of significant reform of the World Trade Organisation, let alone a shift in the trajectory of economic growth.

Resource wars, or conflicts fuelled by landgrabs or mining, were an ever present part of African life. All over South America, the Philippines and elsewhere, oil, mining and logging companies are locked in dispute with indigenous peoples.

But the continuing industrial revolution, which has got the world into such a mess, showed more cracks as sustainable initiatives grew. On a micro-level, Britain got its first offshore commercial wind and wave power stations, and there were record global sales of solar roofs and devices. As a sign of the times, the defection of many coal, oil and car corporations from the Global Climate Coalition, which long maintained that global warming did not exist, was significant. There was real evidence, too, of many companies finally getting to grips with energy saving, pollution control and environmental remediation.

Western architects and designers are becoming more environmentally-aware and some of the most ecologically advanced buildings were commissioned in 2000, many as a result of millennium or lottery cash which helped many communities' conservation efforts. The landfill tax continued to shower environmental groups with cash.

There was more good news. Chernobyl was finally closed 14 years after the nuclear disaster polluted vast areas of the Ukraine and killed or physically affected more than 30,000 people. Against that, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development decided to finance two new reactors in the Ukraine to keep western nuclear companies in business.

Sales of organic food continued to power ahead in the west as more farmers switched their methods and sustainable agriculture in many countries was further developed. Fair trade initiatives also increased.

Meanwhile, industrial GM food production, although continuing to expand in developing countries, met further resistance. US farmers and grain processors began to get cold feet over the technology, with some US analysts predicting significant falls in North American plantings in 2001. Monsanto is now under new management and talking like the Body Shop, but its opponents are not convinced.

But there was much to cheer for the greens. In the US election, Ralph Nader collected 2m votes; in Europe, several high profile environment ministers stood firm against US and British climate change proposals. The Greenpeace 18 were acquitted of criminal damage after destroying part of a GM maize crop in 1999. And big dam builders and the governments who support them were deeply embarrassed by a major report showing how economically and socially destructive they can be. Britain has yet to decide whether to withdraw support for the controversial Ilisu dam in Turkey.

It was also the year that Tony Blair made his first green speech and his advisers deigned to meet a Green party delegation. Blair executed a smart u-turn on GM crops, admitting in February that they could pose a health risk and that protesters' concerns were legitimate. Meanwhile, Prince Charles brewed up a philosophical storm by calling for more reverence of the natural world, arguing that the only way to avoid environmental catastrophe was for humankind to rediscover a sense of the sacred. The scientific community, predictably, reacted with scorn.

On a political level, groups such as Friends of the Earth, the Association for the Conservation of Energy and old people's charities lobbied hard - and won the battle - for a Warm Homes Act which will increase the insulation of houses. The pesticides tax (long delayed) is in the wings and the climate change levy introduced by Gordon Brown in the spring budget comes into force in April. Previously impregnable bastions of government like the Treasury, which has long ignored environmental priorities, are widely thought to be beginning to thaw like the icecaps.

The greatest British success was in biodiversity. It was, says Plantlife, a fine year for the long campaign to make law the Countryside and Rights of Way Act, despite some serious hiccups. As well as giving walkers access to great swathes of long denied upland areas, it will also give increased protection to important wildlife sites in England and Wales. The future of similar sites in Scotland, however, is unclear. And the government is now required to consider biodiversity conservation in all its policies and actions after the Rio Convention was applied in England. While the government's Biodiversity Action Plan did aid the recovery of some very threatened species (the otter, for example), progress towards the plan's policy and habitat restoration targets was painfully slow.

Even in the realm of agricultural policy, we saw the diversion of £1.6bn of EU subsidies into more wildlife-friendly farming, delivered through the Agenda 2000 reforms of the Common Agricultural Policy. But all the while, impending climate change, compounded by habitat fragmentation, threatened to spoil the party.

And there was more good news in the countryside. A comprehensive audit of the British countryside by the Natural Environment Research Council found the tide of environmental degradation going out. As a nation, we are planting more broadleaf trees, maintaining and reviving our hedgerows and stone walls, improving the biological quality of our rivers and expanding our fens, wetlands and bogs. It was testimony to the intense pressure put on government by conservation groups in the early 90s and proves that if money is made available, then conservation can work.

Other campaigns took off. Mobile phone masts, incinerators, patenting, roads and new airports all raised our temperatures and rose up the environmental agenda. The Heathrow Terminal 5 will be a major test of government, as will countryside issues such as hunting and housing.

But 2000 will be remembered mostly for global warming and the heralding of George W Bush as US president. One scientific report after another showed that the world was significantly heating up, and linked the phenomenon directly with human influence. The US was widely cast as the villain in the Hague talks for resisting taking domestic action, but the message barely reached the ears of the American people, who are largely ignorant of climate change or of America's role in it.

How America under Bush will respond to the failed talks in the Hague, and how it uses its international power in so many trade and economic forums, will define the global environment for the next 10 years. The champagne to welcome 2001 should be kept on ice - assuming, of course, that it's not melting and that the bottle still has a natural cork.

webTitle: The Punch and Judy show lives on

fields.headline: Beadle mania
fields.standfirst: Its PC credentials are well out of date, but Carol Davis finds the Punch & Judy show in Liverpool is still a knockout after 150 years
fields.trailText: Its PC credentials are well out of date, but Carol Davis finds the Punch & Judy show in Liverpool is still a knockout after 150 years
fields.body:
The engraving of central Liverpool shows the Victorian scene in minute detail. St George's Hall, that grand neo-classical building with its mighty columns testifying to the city's shipping wealth, stands opposite the main railway station, prime entrance to the city for those sailing to the New World. And at the centre of the scene, frozen in time like the passing horsedrawn tram beside it, is the familiar Punch & Judy booth and its transfixed crowd.

Although this scene, with its top-hatted gentlemen and ladies in bonnets, is from another world now, the Punch & Judy show survives remarkably intact. The master showman in the gaudy booth was one "Professor Codman", puppeteer and performer who handed on his skills to his son and grandson, and down the family line to the present day.

The Codman family is celebrating 150 years of what they now call The Original Codman's Victorian Punch & Judy Theatre, in a show which has been faithfully passed down to the fifth and sixth generations. As each child learned the skills at his father's and grandfather's knee, the shows have remained faithful to the way they were a century and a half ago.

"As a youngster, the whole thing was magic," reflects the present, fifth-generation Prof Codman, 72-year old Ronald Richard Codman. "It was the clackety-clack of the sticks and the clickety-clack of the crocodile's jaws that fascinated me, and the Punch & Judy show has never really lost its appeal. It's in my blood. The show is a part of my family's roots."

The first Prof Codman, Richard, was a Norfolk man who learned puppeteering skills from his father and set up his own show in 1850, combining the skills of woodcarver, puppet showman and musician with work in the Norfolk fields when demand for entertainment was slack. He travelled west in a horse-drawn caravan, taking with him the original puppets and theatre and putting on shows as he went, arriving in Liverpool in 1860. He asked the city council for a site, and was given a prime one - an open, cobbled square known as The Quadrant, between the market and what is now Lime Street station.

The Punch & Judy show quickly became a local institution. Prof Codman would play pan-pipes to summon an audience, and once a sizeable crowd had gathered the shows would run continuously through the day. The master showman would finish an hour-long show - timed by gas flares, used for illumination, which lasted 60 minutes - and duck out of the booth to let an assistant begin the next show without pause.

Richard Codman taught his son, Richard, who taught his son, Richard, father of the present Prof Codman, who is teaching his own son, Robert Richard. They became an institution in the city in its shipping heyday. Prof Codman would stride around town in his frock coat, with his waxed moustache and performing dog, Toby. At one performance inside St George's Hall in the 1920s, the show was in danger of being overwhelmed by the 1,000 children who turned up - the only solution being to have father and grandfather doing shows back to back.

But the tradition nearly died with the present Prof Codman. His perfectionist father was reluctant to start the long process of teaching him the skills, and when the nine-year-old Ronald "borrowed" a booth without permission to do a show at his school, he was unable to set it up. His father walked in, face like thunder, to see his young son attempting a show on top of some hastily-propped blackboards.

When Ronald did learn, it was a long haul. He recalls: "My father was a fierce critic, and would say: 'That's no good. Your voice isn't right.' He was doing it to make me perform better, and he admitted: 'I want you to be almost better than I am.'"

His grandfather was just as ferocious. "He'd mutter: 'He's doing it too quickly.' But life is faster now, and my show lasts about 25 minutes. Audiences just wouldn't watch for an hour these days."

Other things have had to change too. The performing dog, Toby, who bites Punch's nose, has long been considered unsuitable. The Punch puppet beloved of Victorian fairgrounds specialised in a knockabout humour that went well with the walking panoply of fire-eaters and jugglers. The Victorian show was fairly bawdy, and successive Prof Codmans appeared in music hall in a show that would be too risque today.

So it is with trepidation that the present professor performs some of the more controversial scenes. A quietly-spoken man with a gentle manner, Ronald does regular shows at the Museum of Liverpool Life, running through the history of the show and asking mildly whether he should do the hangman scene. The response is overwhelming: "Yes!" He gazes at the audience for a moment, steps into the booth and is transformed. The pace is fast and furious, as Punch thumps Judy, thumps the beadle, tackles the judge, then takes on the hangman, tricking him into putting his head into his own noose.

"Some people think Punch & Judy was originally a morality play, but I think it was always entertainment," says Ronald. "Punch always gets away with everything, and people like to see him hit a figure of authority over the head and get away with it. Children love it because it is slapstick fun and pure fantasy. As one child put it: 'I like it because they're not real.' But this is also living history, and anyone who thinks Punch & Judy is just for kids has got it wrong. It's for adults, too - and it's part of our folklore."

Punch lines

The origins of the Punch &Judy show may date back to Roman times, and some believe that the show is based on the Punchinello figure who has grown into different traditions throughout Europe.

The modern tradition may be based on Pulcinella, a professional comedian who performed in Italy in the 17th century. Later, Punch became a marionette and, by the 18th century, glove puppets of Punch & Judy were popular, along with the Baby, the Beadle, Toby the Dog, the Crocodile and the Hangman.

 The Museum of Liverpool Life is on 0151-478 4080.

A quietly-spoken man with a gentle manner, Ronald does regular shows at the Museum of Liverpool Life, running through the history of the show and asking mildly whether he should do the hangman scene. The response is overwhelming: "Yes!" He gazes at the audience for a moment, steps into the booth and is transformed. The pace is fast and furious, as Punch thumps Judy, thumps the beadle, tackles the judge, then takes on the hangman, tricking him into putting his head into his own noose. "Some people think Punch & Judy was originally a morality play, but I think it was always entertainment," says Ronald. "Punch always gets away with everything, and people like to see him hit a figure of authority over the head and get away with it. Children love it because it is slapstick fun and pure fantasy. As one child put it: 'I like it because they're not real.' But this is also living history, and anyone who thinks Punch & Judy is just for kids has got it wrong. It's for adults, too - and it's part of our folklore." Punch lines The origins of the Punch &Judy show may date back to Roman times, and some believe that the show is based on the Punchinello figure who has grown into different traditions throughout Europe. The modern tradition may be based on Pulcinella, a professional comedian who performed in Italy in the 17th century. Later, Punch became a marionette and, by the 18th century, glove puppets of Punch & Judy were popular, along with the Baby, the Beadle, Toby the Dog, the Crocodile and the Hangman.  The Museum of Liverpool Life is on 0151-478 4080.

webTitle: Review: Harry Potter day

fields.headline: Wizard idea potters out of steam
fields.standfirst:
Review: Harry Potter Day
Radio 4
fields.trailText: It was, the Radio 4 announcer told us, "an extraordinary radio event". For the first time on British radio, an unabridged novel was to be read from beginning to end. Boxing Day and all the network's traditional programmes were swept on to long wave to clear the schedules for eight hours and 20 minutes of Quidditch, broomsticks and some very wizard wizardry. Yesterday was renamed Harry Potter Day.
fields.body:
It was, the Radio 4 announcer told us, "an extraordinary radio event". For the first time on British radio, an unabridged novel was to be read from beginning to end. Boxing Day and all the network's traditional programmes were swept on to long wave to clear the schedules for eight hours and 20 minutes of Quidditch, broomsticks and some very wizard wizardry. Yesterday was renamed Harry Potter Day.

Broadcasting Harry Potter and The Philosopher's Stone in its entirety did at least give anti-climactic Boxing Day a new lease of life with Stephen Fry's hugely engaging reading of JK Rowling's first Potter tale on in the background. Atmospheric, funny, and richly evocative, Fry's version will be hard to better.

There's no doubt that to broadcast the novel is A Good Thing, as part of Radio 4 controller, Helen Boaden's aim to attract younger listeners to speech radio. She has a dream of twentysomethings of the future looking back fondly to Boxing Day 2000, when they listened to the radio.

But to simply play tapes that are already commer cially available - the only difference being that you don't get Fry telling you when to turn the tapes over - and to do so in an extravagant half-day wodge, with a repeated Rowling Desert Island Discs for dessert, doesn't make a "radio event".

As a means of encouraging children to tune in, a daily dose of Potter over several weeks, with child-friendly programming on either side of each broadcast, would surely have been more effective. But that wasn't Rowling's wish. In its entirety or not at all was the deal on offer.

The station did its best to break the day up into manageable segments, though. But eight and a half hours was too long to sit still. My guinea pigs - children of nine and 11 - loved the idea, started enthusiastically but were fidgety after an hour, and suggested (illegal) taping as they zoomed off on their shiny new bikes.

I don't think television would try such a venture for a young audience and it hardly has the image problem speech radio has with many youngsters.

In the end, the day was still something of a let-down. What we heard was undoubtedly a great reading of a book that we are potty about, but presented in a way that ensured very few children will have listened to the whole thing.

Those twentysomethings of the future that Boaden dreams of, might be meeting up to reminisce about the time they gave up on Potter day and played with their new toys instead.

webTitle: The best driving music scene

fields.headline: The best driving music scene
fields.standfirst: Meet the Parents
fields.trailText: Meet the Parents
fields.body:
The hapless Greg Focker (Ben Stiller) and his prospective father-in-law Jack Byrnes (Robert De Niro) are driving to the nearest town for groceries. They sit in silence, as Jack slips on a tape of Puff The Magic Dragon. Tapping his fingers to the music, he turns to his passenger.

"You like this, Greg?"

Greg nods enthusiastically.

"Yes, I do. Yes I do. Big fan."

Softly, Jack begins to sing along. He beams contentedly.

Greg joins in, then stops self-consciously.

"Great song."

"Yeah," Jack grins. "One of my favourites."

"Hey, what about those people who thought this was really about a dragon?"

Jack turns, confused.

"What do you mean?"

A look of panic flashes across Greg's face.

"Oh, you know... the whole smoking thing?"

"No, Greg, I don't. I don't know. Why don't you tell me?"

"Ah... some people, ah... think that to... um, 'puff the magic dragon' really means to smoke a... um, marijuana cigarette."

Jack is baffled.

"But Puff's just the name of the boy's magical dragon..."

"Right. Right."

They drive on in silence. Jack suddenly turns to Greg, suspicion in his voice.

"Are you a pothead, Focker?"

See also: Jerry Maguire, Thelma And Louise, Repo Man

Don't see also: Doc Hollywood

Pointless trivia: Robert De Niro's childhood nickname was "Bobby Milk" - on account of his pallor.

webTitle: Capitalist Russia salutes the communists' tune

fields.headline: Capitalist Russia salutes the communists' tune
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The government hopes to make it more acceptable by adopting a new set of lyrics.
fields.body:
The music of the Soviet anthem was formally adopted by President Vladimir Putin yesterday for Russia's national anthem, in time to be performed at the state's New Year celebrations.

With Russians getting ready to mark what most of them accept as the beginning of the new millennium, he signed a series of laws reintroducing a peculiar mixture of conflicting symbols from the past.

They make the national flag the pre-revolutionary tricolour of white, blue and red stripes, the state coat of arms the tsarist two-headed eagle, and the anthem the music selected by Stalin.

A red flag similar to that flown by the Soviet army during the second world war was chosen as the army's banner.

The reinstatement of such pregnant symbols of the Soviet era coincided with an opinion poll showing that the communist past still evokes great affection and loyalty.

The 1,500 questioned voted Vladimir Lenin man of the century and put his successior Josef Stalin in second place, despite the growing awareness of his responsibility for the death of millions of Russians by arbitrary execution and in prison camps.

Andrei Sakharov, the human rights advocate and Nobel prizewinner, came third.

The government's search for new symbols has been controversial. When earlier this month parliament approved the package of compromises, designed to twist together the communist "red" and tsarist "white" strands of the country's past, society was split.

Many influential writers, film-makers and musicians expressed disgust at the revival of the Soviet anthem, which they said marked "a moral victory for old communists". Boris Yeltsin, who abandoned the piece in 1991, was among the critics of its revival.

But the stirring music composed by Alexander Alexandrov in 1943 won out: in one poll 49% of those asked loved it, while only with 15% preferred the piece by Glinka chosen to replace it.

The government hopes to make it more acceptable by adopting a new set of lyrics. A small presidential committee was set up yesterday to study the options already on offer, and it will probably run a contest to find new verses.

Mikhail Mikhalkov, the author of the original text, which paid tribute to the "unbreakable" Soviet Union, has already written new words to account for its breaking. Loaded with religious imagery in the place of communist symbolism, it is believed to be Mr Putin's choice.

This is his third rewrite - he removed the reference to Stalin in 1977 -and the thought of it being adopted has further dismayed those opposed to Alexandrov's music.

Anthems for all

How the words changed

 Mikhail Mikhalkov's 2000 version of the anthem:

Verse one:

With strong wings spread out above us,

The Russian eagle completes its flight,

And the symbol of the fatherland - the tricolour flag,

Guides the people of Russia towards victory

Chorus: Glory to our free fatherland,

The century-old union of brother nations -

The people's wisdom handed down from our ancestors!

Glory to the motherland! God is watching over you!

 The 1943 version:

Verse two:

The sun of freedom shone through the storm,

And it was great Lenin who showed us the way.

Stalin reared us to be loyal to the people

And inspired us to work and great deeds*

Chorus: Glory to our free fatherland,

Bulwark of the peoples in brotherhood strong.

O Soviet banner, the banner of the people,

May you lead us from victory to victory!

*In 1977 the Stalin lines were replaced with: To a righteous cause he [Lenin] roused all the peoples / Inspired them to work and to great deeds

webTitle: Obituary: Allan Smethurst

fields.headline: Allan Smethurst
fields.trailText: The Singing Postman with a distinct Norfolk voice
fields.body:
The Singing Postman, Allan Smethurst, who has died aged 73, was well known in the late 1960s for his Norfolk dialect songs such as Hev Yew Gotta Loight, Boy? and Moind Yer Hid, Boy.

Born in Lincolnshire, he moved with his mother and stepfather to Sheringham, in Norfolk, at the age of 11. A George Formby fan and self-taught guitarist, after joining the post office in 1953 he began to write comic, yet closely observed, songs about rural life, which he sang in a heavily accented Norfolk voice. The subject matter ranged from the village cricket match and the ladies darts team to mass-produced food (Oi Can't Git A Noice Loaf).

Superficially, these were quaint parodies, but they were popular in East Anglia itself, an indication that Smethurst's compatriots identified with this affectionate portrait of their idiosyncrasies. The Guardian's Dennis Barker called him "a bookishly melancholy folk-satirist".

Smethurst first found a regional audience through appearances on BBC Radio Norfolk's Wednesday morning magazine show. The presenter, Ralph Tuck, the owner of a family firm of seed merchants, gave him the sobriquet "the Singing Postman", and, when record companies showed no interest, financed the pressing of 100 copies of a four-song vinyl disc in 1964. It was distributed in East Anglia, and sold more than 10,000 in four months. The regional press breathlessly announced that the Singing Postman was outselling the Beatles and the Rolling Stones in Norfolk record shops.

By now a national celebrity, the Singing Postman was soon signed by EMI's Parlophone record label, toured and made television appearances, ranging from Top Of The Pops to the Des O'Connor Show. In 1966, he received the Ivor Novello award for best novelty song.

Smethurst's act was distinctly non-showbiz. He had buck teeth and horn-rimmed spectacles, and performed his songs with a cheap acoustic guitar, while wearing a full postman's uniform with peaked cap.

Record royalties and appearance fees multiplied his income dramatically from his £12 a week postman's wages. But he found it hard to cope with the demands of the entertainment industry. He suffered from stage fright and took to whisky to calm his nerves, later admitting that his consumption rose from a miniature before going on stage to half a bottle a day.

By the late 1960s his career was over. He made a court appearance charged with assault after a domestic incident, and arthritis made playing the guitar difficult. He fought his alcoholism and attempted a comeback in 1977, but by 1980 he was a virtual recluse, living in the Grimsby Salvation Army hostel that was his home until his death.

But the Singing Postman did not entirely disappear from popular consciousness. His best known song, Hev Yew Gotta Loight, Boy?, was recorded by Rolf Harris, and by the comedy punk group Splodgenessabounds. Then in 1994, an enterprising advertising agency chose it as the soundtrack for an Ovaltine commercial. Tony Palmer, of the Caister-based Anglian Music, also undertook a re-release programme of more than 80 of the Singing Postman's recorded songs on a series of seven CDs, the last two of which were issued last week.

Allan Smethurst, singer and songwriter, born November 19 1927; died December 22 2000

webTitle: Comment: Catholic heir to throne might still be unacceptable

fields.headline: A defender of the only faith
fields.standfirst:
A Catholic heir to the throne might still be unacceptable

Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: A Catholic heir to the throne might still be unacceptable
fields.body:
"Establishment" has cropped up more than once in the Guardian's Republican campaign; and generally (including in pieces by people who should have known better), the argument has centred upon the Church of England. But "establishment" is primarily about the state, about government and about the principles and visions upon which government is based; and only then about a particular church - in England since the 16th-century reformation, the Church of England.

In Europe since the Emperor Constantine in the early fourth century, in England since kings began to be Christian two or three centuries later, government has in principle looked to the Christian faith as its ultimate point of reference, vastly though the meaning and extent of this "looking" has changed in every generation, down to our own. So to think about "establishment" is to think about what kind of state we want in this country, what kind of public life, and what ultimate accountability for those who carry the honourable responsibilities of government.

Our present arrangements are on the whole striking for their tolerance: of the wide range of Christian traditions, of other faiths, and of almost every sort of belief and behaviour. This tolerance, the hard-won fruit of centuries of struggle in parliament and elsewhere, arguably owes a good deal to the "broad-church" character of the Church of England as it has evolved down the centuries - and as it has been influenced by participation in this process. Those who wish now to arrange things otherwise will be wise to consider whether a British or English state of the future, coming out of our particular history yet consciously turning away from it, and based only in a set of purely secular principles, will be as resiliently tolerant of other secular philosophies or practices, let alone of religious faith of whatever kind.

Until the reformation it was simply to "the church" that the crown looked for the maintenance of this point of reference - the point of reference not only of its actions and decisions, but also of its dignity, of its standing; because, according to Christian faith, government has the God-given calling of representing God's care for his creation, God's regulation of human society for the welfare of humankind. Since the reformation, the crown in parliament has continued to recognise its responsibility to sustain the church that seeks to sustain the faith upon which its government is ultimately based. Where the one church is divided into many, this has necessarily meant that a particular church has carried the responsibilities - and, yes, received the privileges, though today the former predominate! - of especially representing to government at every level the Christian faith to which in principle it looks.

It will not do to requote the Prince of Wales speaking of being "defender of faith" - as if there were such a thing as "faith" that exists unsupported by, not lived within, the ways of a particular faith community. I'm confident that Prince Charles knows, because in his life he tries to demonstrate, that he will best show his respect for and "defend" this country's range of religious practice by honouring and practising the faith in which he stands himself.

And this is why it is worth pausing before raising a hue and cry around the Act of Settlement, admittedly embarrassing though it is in today's vastly changed ecumenical conditions, for which I thank God. I should prefer to be free of the difficulties that it presents - but to be free of them through the Christian unity for which I long. But until then, and precisely because of the public clarities of doctrinal and disciplinary formulation that I sometimes wistfully admire in the Roman Catholic Church, it remains the case that a Roman Catholic marriage of the heir to the throne would in time have implications for the government of this country that for very many people, and for me, might not be as acceptable as the present arrangements. Nor am I prepared to place at risk, for this rather quixotic cause, the constitutional relationships between the countries of the UK, or between those of the Commonwealth.

But the main question is: "What kind of state, what kind of country?" The UK is still a country, and the Queen's government still a government, whose ultimate reference points are Christian, and then religious, albeit today in an attenuated sense.

 The Rt Rev Michael Scott-Joynt is Bishop of Winchester.

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: We are all threatened by global warming

fields.headline: Stormy weather but no sign of a thaw in frozen attitudes
fields.standfirst:
It's an incontrovertible fact: we are all threatened by global warming

Special report: the weather
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: It's an incontrovertible fact: we are all threatened by global warming
fields.body:
What will historians say about the year 2000? They will see only one question of consequence: this year global warming became an incontrovertible fact, visible to all citizens and yet the west did nothing. The Hague summit collapsed while the minimalist Kyoto protocols remained unsigned by the world's greatest carbon dioxide emitter which elected (or rather, selected) a new president not only born and bred on oil, but who was set upon the US throne by oilmen's money.

Savage fires, the worst ever, raged unchecked across drought-ridden US landscapes last summer, West Nile fever broke out in Boston. The ice cap was found full of water and holes, polar bears started to die and persistent floods swept across Britain. Yet on neither side of the Atlantic did green issues register more than a small blip on political screens. Green parties across Europe fell into decline. The British prime minister did make his first ever green speech under some duress saying: "The environmental challenge continues to grow and become more urgent."

But not urgent enough, neither to the people nor to their governments. Historians will compare us to Noah's antediluvian citizenry. The geraniums in my window boxes, even the lobelia, still bloom luxuriantly on Christmas day while squirrels who should be asleep eat from the bird table, as it rains and rains. Yet still the strange weather has not moved from nature notes to mainstream politics.

After Kyoto there was a concerted corporate denial of global warming. The biggest oil companies - Exxon Mobil, the giant of them all - spent large sums assembling "scientists" to attest that it was all nonsense. But in the three years since, the climate has changed yet faster than predicted. The Met Office's advisers have just revised their predictions upwards by two degrees, expecting temperatures to rise by six degrees this century. Water levels will rise by seven metres, wiping out every major coastal city in the world.

This is no unimaginable futuristic abstraction: children now born will see all this come to pass. A six- degree increase produces a heat human beings have never known: the last time it was that hot, dinosaurs roamed. There is more carbon dioxide in the atmosphere now than there has been for 20m years. Six of the 10 hottest years have been in the 1990s, the other four in the late 1980s. There has never been a climate change so sharp or fast, with no time for adaptation.

So how, British historians will ask, did this play in the election of 2001? Hardly at all, beyond a Tory pledge to abolish the new climate change levy on industry, the government's only creative contribution to global warming. Why the lack of alarm and political salience? Parties who dare not speak of the value of taxation dare suggest no sacrifices, not even for survival. We may have reached the limits of democracy.

But if the ballot box can't save us, perhaps the market can. Global insurers are beginning to worry. They will be bankrupt sooner rather than later by predicted calamities in fire, flood and storm. A 10% increase in average windspeed yields 150% more damage. If insurers go bust, so do pension funds and the whole stock market. Recent British floods showed how quickly property becomes uninsurable. How long before that is true of New York, London and all the coastal cities where global capitalism resides? The economic cost of natural disaster is rising by 12% a year: vulnerable Florida alone has a trillion dollars of insured assets, enough to bring everything crashing down.

The commercial carrot works as well as the stick. The market is at last waking up to the profits in renewable energy. German, Dutch and even the US governments are investing in the race to bring down the costs of wind and solar power. Britain is barely a player: BP has moved its solar factories to Europe where there are grants, while the UK is unlikely to hit its 2010 target of 10% renewable energy. Instead our government just invested £1bn in North Sea oil exploration, when £200m could make UK solar power a winner. Labour has commissioned just 100 solar roofs, compared to the German government's 100,000 and a US government plan for one million.

A solar roof costs five times more to install than burning fossil fuels, because of the high cost of production. But the price is about to tumble in Germany as volume reduces unit price: the UK will end up importing panels for lack of government action. A trial solar roof on a terrace house in Richmond now feeds surplus electricity into the national grid: no more functionless roofs should ever be built from now on. The DTI dithers instead of kick-starting a huge new manufacturing industry, employing thousands. Architects are conservatively slow to use solar cladding that costs no more than most other cladding for office buildings, with free energy for ever.

With less government inertia there are attractive solutions to global warming that don't have to mean wearing the hair shirts that have made the green movement flounder as a political force. Economists, including the Economist, predict renewable energy is about to become the next revolution. Bigger than mobile phones, bigger than computer manufacture. But if Labour doesn't move fast, foreign markets will cash in while we import from them. If Labour dare not talk the politics of global warming, at least they could get the economics right.
