webTitle: Obituary: Victor Borge

fields.headline: Victor Borge
fields.standfirst: Pianist who made an art of self-parody
fields.trailText: Pianist who made an art of self-parody.
fields.body:
Victor Borge, who has died aged 91, was not the first comedian to have contrived his act from sending up or mutilating serious music. But he did it with more style than anyone else, in a way which had more widespread and long-lived appeal. He continued to play his piano, or hilariously failed to play his piano, on tours of the United States, where he mainly lived, and Europe, from where he originated, well into his 80s.

Borge always claimed that his deadpan humour succeeded because it was simple and drawn straight from life. If so, its simplicity was that of genius, of being able to impose a thread of distorted but impregnable logic on to almost any set of circumstances.

"What," one TV interviewer asked, "are you doing next?" "I guess I'll be going straight to the bathroom." Another interviewer asked why he had bought a farm in Portugal. "Someone," he replied, "had to buy a farm in Portugal." Even the ageing process was turned into a dismissive aside: "It is so much better than the alternative."

Borge the comic, whose command of the piano was (on stage) liable to grotesque accident, so that a simple piano stool could narrowly escape being a disaster area, turned even his imperilled past as a Danish Jew into the humour of mock conceit: "Only Churchill and me knew how dangerous Hitler was. Churchill was trying to save Europe, and I was trying to save myself."

Born in Copenhagen, Borge was the son of a violinist with the Royal Danish Philharmonic. His mother introduced him to the piano from the age of three, and he made his stage debut at the age of eight. There was one great problem which he had to face in his early career - the quality of the on-site pianos he had to play. Some were dreadful, so he developed tricks for playing them not taught by conventional teachers. Out of that situation came his humorous movements and asides, always in a distinctive, unctuous, throwaway voice.

By the outbreak of the second world war, Borge was a reasonably successful pianist and musical satirist in Denmark, well known for his guying of Hitler and other Nazis. When the Germans invaded Denmark, newspapers reported that his name was at the head of those destined for extermination. Fortunately for Borge, two Russian diplomats who had been amused by his act smuggled him aboard an American ship bound for Finland, from where he caught the last boat out to the free part of Europe.

Once in New York, however, Borge was handicapped by not knowing a word of English. He studied it in cinemas on 42nd Street, watching the same films round and round until he made some sort of sense of what the characters were saying. Being asked to read lines for the warm-up of a radio show led to him being invited to do the same sort of job on air for the Bing Crosby Kraft Music Hall. He understood hardly anything of what he was reading, but his ruptured English made him a success with listeners. He liked to recall that he was nominated second-best radio comedian of the year.

Out of this grew his mature act, in which language and logic tortured one another to breaking point. On the west coast, he made music and comedy records for the US war effort, and afterwards developed a repertoire of 15,000 jokes or routines, from which he could make a selection to suit any audience.

He devised variations on an early performance, when he had been trying to play seriously. Not trusting his memory, he stuck sheet music inside the piano lid, only to find that in performance it was peeling off around him like leaves in a storm. The counterpoint between his lugubrious dignity and the bizarre things that befell him - like being blasted off his piano stool by a soprano's top note, then producing a safety belt from the stool - could be hilarious.

Borge made a unique and highly lucrative niche for himself. He hired his own orchestra for his tours of the US and Canada, and had a 22-acre ranch and pool in the San Fernando Valley, California. His first marriage ended in divorce, and his second marriage, in 1953, was to his manageress, Sanna (who died in September). But when his ex-wife was occupying the ranch, he had to become frugal, setting up a large poultry farm in Connecticut so that he could have a stately home that made a profit.

In the 1970s, when more boisterous sorts of comedy became fashionable, he seemed to falter, complaining that the tabloids called him a has-been. During a London visit, he was touchingly grateful that broadsheet critics praised the show. He invigorated his act by introducing as partners a succession of attractive young women.

By the 1980s, Borge had got his second wind and looked like going on for ever as an international touring artist. By the 1990s, his initial suspicion of television - he thought his material too narrowly-based for constant TV exposure - had disappeared entirely. He continued touring, with a sell-out audience at the Barbican for his 1992 tour of the US, Australia and Britain.

His work for good causes, including Thanks To Scandinavia, a scholarship fund to commemorate Scandinavian efforts to help victims of Nazi persecution, earned him honours in several countries. But bringing laughter pleased him even more than honours. "The shortest distance between two people is a smile," was one of his favourite sayings, and there was always something life-affirming about his studied, quiet, intellectually devious humour.

He is survived by a son and daughter from his first marriage, and a son and two daughters from his second.

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: When the Diary Awards panel had the annual lunch in the  salon privé at the Savoy, the event turned out to be even livelier than usual.
fields.body:
When the Diary Awards panel had the annual lunch in the salon privé at the Savoy, the event turned out to be even livelier than usual.

Suffice it that without Boris the Jackal Johnson on the door, I dread to think ... Anyway, many thanks to a mixed panel. From the old guard was Paul Johnson, Rizla Rosie Boycott and the Rev Steve Chalke, who said grace ("Lord, we give thanks for the simple fare Taki-George is about to serve us ... oysters, stuffed carp, roast swan and chocolate soufflé; and various rare wines, including a Château d'Yquem, 1871"), while the debutantes were Home Office minister Barbara Roche and Wildean Tory wit Dr Liam Fox. Once T-G had served the nuts and port, we moved to the business in hand.

 Diary Personality of the Year was keenly contested. Rosie Boycott proposed her proprietor Richard Desmond, and Liam Fox seconded him. However, Paul Johnson dissented. "Anyone who condones the degrading filth that man publishes," raged my sane and rational friend, "deserves to be taken upstairs to have his pants pulled down and his bottom spanked." At this Paul hurriedly left the room, and in his absence the award went to compromise candidate Frank Dobson, whom Barbara cited for relegating Susan Kramer to fourth in the mayoral election. "Oooh," said Dobbo when we rang to inform him, "you ama... No, I can't. I'm too chuffed to speak. I love you all."

 The William Rees-Mogg Crystal Ball was a three-way fight. Mark Steyn's prediction of a George W landslide won support, as did Telegraph cricket writer Lord Michael Henderson's dismissal of England's chances in the Karachi Test. But the prize stayed in-house, the Diary winning easily for its revelation in May that Gordon Brown had split up with Sarah Macaulay. Two days later, following denials, we called for a polygraph to be sent to the Treasury, and we repeated the separation endlessly until the moment of their wedlock.

 For Editor of the Year, Liam Fox proposed Piers Morgan for two brilliant Mirror front page exclusives - Mr Tony's passion for singing fish Bigmouth Billy Bass, and the BBC leaflets on how to use the turnstiles - bearing an eerie likeness to items already printed here. But Rosie Boycott disagreed. As a Spare Rib founder, she said (proposing Janet Street-Porter) she never tires in the fight for "my sisters". Janet wins for presiding, from the hairdresser's, over the novel incident in which several IoS staff threatened to injunct their own paper over a column in which Salman Rushdie attacked them by name.

 The Rev Moon Halo for Spiritual Leadership went to Middlesbrough MP Stuart Bell, onetime sub-porn novelist ("Do you think he'd make a columnist?" Rosie muttered) turned ecclesiastic commissioner - an honour Stuart justified in July when police questioned him over the fracas that followed his wife pranging her BMW into a neighbour's van. "Unlike Our Lord, who was also in trouble with the authorities," Rev Steve pointed out, "Stuart got off without being charged."

 It was at this point, as we began debating Press Release of the Year, that the Jackal had to make his first foray to the table. On noting Taki-George saying: "More port, love?" in a strong Nicosian brogue, Barbara Roche mistook him for an asylum seeker and asked to see his papers. T-G, a karate black belt, reacted strongly. Not as strongly as the Jackal, however, and particular thanks to Liam Fox for keeping us amused with his Irish jokes until T-G and Barbara returned, patched up, from the A&E department of St Thomas's. News of further awards tomorrow.

webTitle: Going underground: Christmas TV

fields.headline: Going underground
fields.standfirst: Christmas TV
fields.trailText: Christmas TV
fields.body:
Let me urge you with word and gesture to steer clear of swamps. Two fine actors vanished before my appalled eyes within a couple of hours on Boxing Day.

In that rollicking Victorian twaddle Lorna Doone (BBC1), Carver Doone, as blackhearted a villain as ever shot a bride at the altar, sank slowly into the swamp until only his double-barrelled eyes were left blazing. This everyday story of West Country folk was enlivened by Michael Kitchen playing Hanging Judge Jeffreys in a Brando-esque whisper as quite a nice old thing really.

In The Sleeper (BBC1), Elizabeth Spriggs, big and bovine, was pushed into a slurry pit by her acidic step-sister Eileen Atkins, crying, as she sank slowly below the slime: "You killed my Mummy!" This is a gripping business. You feel yourself in the safe hands of people who know what they are about. As family Christmasses go, the gruesome Moons in their storm-lashed failing farm take some beating.

Which brings me to Peggy Butcher and her baseball bat. You would think that any mother who has been spared the company of three children, two with no hair and one with no septum, would think she had been let off lightly. But not Peggy in EastEnders (BBC1). Undiscouraged by the bloodstained recollection of previous years, she planned another intimate soiree ("My family all together!") No one came. So, armed with the baseball bat which every convivial hostelry keeps handy, Peggy smashed the joint up. Queen Victoria, one was shocked to see, was the first to get it in the neck. An element of refurbishment is indicated in the new year.

In Coronation Street (ITV), the only person having an unqualified bonanza was Martin Platt - in bed with a brunette drinking duty-free bubbly from Dubai. Let us try to be happy for him.

I have been wondering why ghost stories go so well with Christmas when, according to Hamlet, there are no ghosts at Christmas. Though he was a fine one to talk. Perhaps whatever it is that prowls and snuffles in the darkness is attracted by the roaring human warmth. As Archdeacon Haynes said, "I find I absolutely shrink from the dark season." Archdeacon Haynes came to a very odd end in the first of Christopher Lee's Ghost Stories For Christmas (BBC2). Odd is an understatement of classic proportions, but then MR James is a very understated writer. Nothing is explicit. It is all done with hints and atmosphere and our own imagination. We frighten ourselves to death.

When he was Provost of Kings College, Cambridge, he would read one of his ghost stories to friends and colleagues every Christmas Eve. I doubt if any of them walked home alone. Apparently Christopher Lee actually knew MR James when he was at Eton, and may be imitating him, as schoolboys usually can, in these readings. His manner is measured and cool and circuitous. His voice is ironic and velvety. The room is warm, the wine is red, the young undergraduates hardly seem to breathe as they listen.

Archdeacon Haynes, the one who is to die so oddly, is a haunted man: "I get an uncomfortable impression going to my room that there is... company... of some kind." Most of us do at Christmas.

Wyoming has a fossilised allosaurus they call Big Al, though, being a mere 30ft-long youngster, he is more your Medium-Sized Al. A Walking With Dinosaurs Special (BBC1) reconstructed a feasible life-story on the evidence of this unusually complete skeleton. He seems to have been an unlucky lover ("Although he has a torn arm, ripped claw and smashed ribs, he has escaped having his throat torn out") and a clumsy hunter ("He broke his middle toe in the fall and it is now badly infected"). I need hardly mention that most of his friends fell into swamps. The precise pathology is in Big Al Uncovered tonight (8pm, BBC1). Poor little chap. The first law of predation is to stay strong. There is no second law.

Caroline Aherne and Craig Cash pulled the BBC's tail like a cracker in The Royle Family At Christmas (BBC1) The family clubbed together to give Jim Royle the best present he could possibly imagine. Better than anything Roger, his filthy-rich in-law, possessed. "Sky! Sky TV! Two hundred channels! Roger, my arse!"

So, armed with the baseball bat which every convivial hostelry keeps handy, Peggy smashed the joint up. Queen Victoria, one was shocked to see, was the first to get it in the neck. An element of refurbishment is indicated in the new year. In Coronation Street (ITV), the only person having an unqualified bonanza was Martin Platt - in bed with a brunette drinking duty-free bubbly from Dubai. Let us try to be happy for him. I have been wondering why ghost stories go so well with Christmas when, according to Hamlet, there are no ghosts at Christmas. Though he was a fine one to talk. Perhaps whatever it is that prowls and snuffles in the darkness is attracted by the roaring human warmth. As Archdeacon Haynes said, "I find I absolutely shrink from the dark season." Archdeacon Haynes came to a very odd end in the first of Christopher Lee's Ghost Stories For Christmas (BBC2). Odd is an understatement of classic proportions, but then MR James is a very understated writer. Nothing is explicit. It is all done with hints and atmosphere and our own imagination. We frighten ourselves to death. When he was Provost of Kings College, Cambridge, he would read one of his ghost stories to friends and colleagues every Christmas Eve. I doubt if any of them walked home alone. Apparently Christopher Lee actually knew MR James when he was at Eton, and may be imitating him, as schoolboys usually can, in these readings. His manner is measured and cool and circuitous. His voice is ironic and velvety. The room is warm, the wine is red, the young undergraduates hardly seem to breathe as they listen. Archdeacon Haynes, the one who is to die so oddly, is a haunted man: "I get an uncomfortable impression going to my room that there is... company... of some kind." Most of us do at Christmas. Wyoming has a fossilised allosaurus they call Big Al, though, being a mere 30ft-long youngster, he is more your Medium-Sized Al. A Walking With Dinosaurs Special (BBC1) reconstructed a feasible life-story on the evidence of this unusually complete skeleton. He seems to have been an unlucky lover ("Although he has a torn arm, ripped claw and smashed ribs, he has escaped having his throat torn out") and a clumsy hunter ("He broke his middle toe in the fall and it is now badly infected"). I need hardly mention that most of his friends fell into swamps. The precise pathology is in Big Al Uncovered tonight (8pm, BBC1). Poor little chap. The first law of predation is to stay strong. There is no second law. Caroline Aherne and Craig Cash pulled the BBC's tail like a cracker in The Royle Family At Christmas (BBC1) The family clubbed together to give Jim Royle the best present he could possibly imagine. Better than anything Roger, his filthy-rich in-law, possessed. "Sky! Sky TV! Two hundred channels! Roger, my arse!"

webTitle: Random views: What theatre-goers are watching

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What theatre-goers are watching
fields.trailText: What theatre-goers are watching
fields.body:
Jill Furnish:

"I find there's a lot of rubbish on these days. I used to love the fact that there was good-quality British drama on TV. Plays like The Singing Detective by Dennis Potter and Mike Leigh things like Nuts In May. You don't get that many good plays on now. It's all films with big Arnie in. The Christmas schedules are terrible."

David Kingston:

"There was this institution in the 70s, the Monday night movie. I remember that. I don't think I've watched a lot since. I watch the news and I like the breakfast news on BBC1 because I think it's intelligent, but I prefer Radio Four's Today programme. I hate watching TV with my wife - she just talks through everything, muttering inanities. She likes that awful thing with the large lady, The Vicar Of Dibley, which I just can't bear. What would I rather watch instead? Something with Fenella Fielding."

Nigel Marris:

"It's not something I'm very interested in, I'm afraid. I like to read and listen to the radio - no, not Radio One. I'm not a pop tart, ha ha! I don't like the Posh-Becks culture in this country, all this celebriarchy - none too good for the soul. I must say, I do rather have a pash for that Nigella Lawson, I think she's smashing. Yes, she's a bit posh, but she's more posh than Posh, if you see what I mean. Oh, and I like Art Review or whatever it is on Sunday night. Germaine Greer is fantastic. I can't bear that Paulin man."

Carrie Hodgkinson:

"I like Casualty and Ground Force, and some films. I like watching TV programmes because they relax me. I like EastEnders because I think the storylines are very good. It's all battles between good and evil. I have rung up for Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?, I must admit, but I didn't get on and I can't ring up again - far too embarrassed.

 Sin Pattenden spoke to people at the National Theatre, London

webTitle: The might of advertising...and low-fat spreads

fields.headline: The knives are out
fields.standfirst: Can eating margarine instead of butter prevent heart attacks? As two low-fat spreads battle for market share,  Martin Kelner reports on how some fancy publicity may change our breakfast habits for good
fields.trailText: Can eating margarine instead of butter prevent heart attacks? As two low-fat spreads battle for market share,  Martin Kelner reports on how some fancy publicity may change our breakfast habits for good
fields.body:
What I know about margarine - low fat spreads in general, if I am honest - could be written on the back of a very small Ritz cracker, but I do know a good ruckus when I see one, and there is one going on in the marge business right now. It's a real Pepsi-Coke style confrontation with two big multi-nationals locked in battle for control of the nation's toast. The big news in margarine, in case you missed it, is the development of spreads containing plant extracts said to lower your cholesterol level, and significantly reduce the risk of heart disease. This is a radically different claim from the one Flora used to hit us with in the 70s, when Terry Wogan simply said it would help fight the flab.

Technically the new spread is a nutroceutical, occupying the middle ground between food and drug. It actively does you good, they say, like carrots might help you see in the dark, or oysters give you a bit of a leg up in the boudoir. The jury is out on the carrots, but while reporting from the front line of Britain's margarine war, I managed to check out the claims of the oysters as well.

I should tell you how I got involved. It starts, I suppose, with Carol Vorderman, who for the past two years has been hawking a spread called Benecol, developed in Finland, and marketed by Johnson and Johnson. In July this year, Benecol was joined in the supermarket by Flora pro-activ from Unilever which, in what was described as a classic example of "ambush marketing", promptly signed a deal to sponsor Countdown. So now when Miss Benecol tots up the numbers, she is endorsed by a rival spread. A real low blow for the plucky Finns.

Flora, of course, denies that its endorsement of Countdown is intended as an attack on Benecol. It says it just wants to reach the show's audience.

It's a dirty war, all right, but the stakes are high. Given that heart disease is by some distance the biggest cause of premature death in the western world, these new margarines are more or less the present-day equivalent of Dr Ehrlich's magic bullet.

The plant extracts - stanol esters in Benecol, extracted from trees, and sterol esters from sunflowers in Flora pro-activ - inhibit the absorption of LDL cholesterol (low density lipoprotein, the fatty plaque that clogs arteries) into your body. The best available medical evidence - and over the past 15 years these spreads have been clinically tested more often than any weight-lifting athlete - is that three weeks of spreading a little on your toast at breakfast and tea time will lower your LDL cholesterol by 10-15%.

The challenge for the marketing people is to convey this message to people like me who would not recognise low density lipoprotein if it were to knock on their front door and offer to clean the car.

Vorderman is one solution. She is reported to have cost Benecol about £500,000, and the company thinks it has a bargain. If you want people to know your product is the result of some pretty brainy work by blokes in labs wearing white coats, but want to go easy on the science, what with people being a little resistant to that kind of thing in the middle of Family Fortunes, conventional wisdom says that Vorderman should open your batting.

But Unilever reckons conventional wisdom is talking through its hat, and that the public appetite for Vorderman might be waning. Maybe, the argument goes, she has been a little too busy renting out her good name: washing powders, financial services, maths primers, miracle marge, they can't all be the best thing since - or on - sliced bread.

I am discussing these matters on a cruise ship in New Orleans harbour. Strictly speaking, it probably was not necessary to fly me out here business class for this, but the American Heart Association's scientific sessions are underway, there are 44,000 heart specialists in town, and Flora pro-activ are putting on a bit of a show they would like some influential press people to see. They have invited a couple of magazine writers, a chap from the Sun, another from the Independent, and me. I think they found my name on a list of Britain's most easily influenced journalists.

We go to a symposium entitled Plant Sterols: from Research to Practice, at which various professors run through their research, which we are invited to follow in an inch-thick sheaf of scientific documents with titles such as Modulation of Plasma Lipid Levels and Cholesterol Kinetics by Phytosterol Versus Phytostanol Esters (I give that one to the guy from the Sun). At a question and answer session afterwards, a determined interrogator persists with questions about the safety of the plant extracts in Flora pro-activ, and is referred to the documents on independent tests. "He's probably from the competition," whispers one of the Flora people, "a plant." In the circumstances, an unfortunate choice of word.

This is a fun war, and I am fully behind Unilever's strategy to win hearts and minds. It has used celebrities - Wogan, Richard Wilson, Alan Titchmarsh (always the same names: when is Keith Richards going to get a margarine ad?) - but has decided this time to rely on the soundness of the science. Thanks to this, I can put the key question to Professor Ernie Schaefer MD, of Tufts University school of medicine, Boston. If I spread enough of the margarine on my bread, I ask, will I live forever?

No is the answer, but changes in our diet, says Schaefer, are the key to beating the scourge of heart disease. "Between 1940 and now, life expectancy in the United States rose from 60 to 75, largely because of changes in diet," he tells me. "These new margarines can help further that process, which is very encouraging - if you don't mind being old."

So who is winning the margarine war? The suspicion is that Vorderman's vast fee from Johnson and Johnson, and the rather smaller amount it cost Unilever to fill me with jazz and seafood in New Orleans, are only necessary because the spreads are identical. Even Matthew Hill, Flora's European marketing manager, admits both products work in precisely the same way.

He says pro-activ is cheaper than its rival though (£1.95 against £2.49), and tastes better. On this last point I am afraid I cannot offer an opinion. At least not until Benecol flies me to Bali or somewhere equally exotic to taste its stuff.

webTitle: The theatrical hits and misses of 2000

fields.headline: The long and the short of it
fields.standfirst: It has been a year of marathons and miniatures; of much outstanding new writing but too many complacent revivals.  Michael Billington  rounds up the hits and misses of 2000
fields.trailText: It has been a year of marathons and miniatures; of much outstanding new writing but too many complacent revivals. Michael Billington rounds up the hits and misses of 2000
fields.body:
It was a year of theatrical extremes, of long days and short nights. Marathons proliferated. After seeing Peter Stein's 18-hour Faust in Hanover, the Peter Hall-John Barton Tantalus in Denver and Michael Boyd's Henry VI trilogy in Stratford, I thought of claiming overtime. Against that, there were numerous short, interval-free plays that had you out of the theatre in as little as 45 minutes: Dublin Carol, Life x 3, Far Away, Mr Kolpert, Bash, even the Almeida's Tempest.

What does all this tell us? That theatre is rapidly changing, and that audiences shun routine and crave something special. It may take the form of a day-long event - the shared experience of watching together from morning to night forges a sense of community. But the profusion of short plays also implies that audiences are happy to have a short, sharp theatrical shock, an intense experience as a prelude to dinner. To reverse Brecht's dictum, first come the morals, then the bread.

What is healthy is that playwrights no longer feel bound by the 150-minute rule - the idea that you have to eke out your material to fit a standard length or to boost profits at the bar. The interval, we have discovered, is a social rather than an aesthetic convention. Equally, if it takes you four hours to make your point, as it often does Eugene O'Neill, no one, except a critic who has to file a review on the same night, is really going to object. Form follows function, as architect Louis Sullivan said. A play's length should be determined by artistic vision rather than managerial diktat. Never mind the width, feel the quality.

But how good were this year's new plays? No towering masterpieces have emerged but it was a year of solid accomplishment, not least at the Royal Court, which staged an impressive 16 premieres after its February reopening. When people abroad ask how they can stimulate new writing, I always answer that they need a theatre dedicated solely to that purpose. The Royal Court no longer enjoys a monopoly on new writing, but it still remains a powerhouse. Particularly striking this year was the quality of the work coming out of the Court's Theatre Upstairs - The Force of Change, Mr Kolpert, Fireface, 4.48 Psychosis and Far Away. Especially impressive was David Eldridge's Under the Blue Sky, in which teachers' sexual confusion was set against a background of cosmic violence in three interlinked scenes. Here was a young writer making the leap from promise to achievement.

In radically different ways all the plays staged by the Court suggested that there is a malaise in society today: from David Hare's idea of addiction as a substitute for conviction in My Zinc Bed to Caryl Churchill's Far Away with its vision of Armageddon. But, without straitjacketing writers, I feel it might be profitable if they wrote to a specific brief. This year I even suggested to the Royal Court that, given the likelihood of a renewal of Labour's mandate next year, now might be a good time to examine Blair's Britain. Some argued that plays are too much a matter of personal gestation to be arbitrarily conceived; elsewhere I detected flickers of interest. My point is that playwrights may need a nudge to address not just their subjective unease but the state of the nation at large.

But it was a lively year all round for new writing. Marie Jones's Stones in His Pockets and Gary Mitchell's The Force of Change suggested that Belfast is a real source of energy. Joe Penhall's Blue/Orange, though it sometimes stretched credibility, was the National Theatre's best new play for a long time. And, on all sides, young women writers made their mark: Zinnie Harris with Further Than the Furthest Thing, Helen Blakeman with Normal and, most astonishing of all, Joanna Laurens with The Three Birds at the Gate. Having missed the opening, I went to Laurens's play as a civilian rather than as a critic and was bowled over by her re-telling of the Tereus and Philomel myth - in particular by her bold poetic diction with its coinages, inversions and dislocated rhythms. I'd say she is the most original theatrical voice to have emerged since Sarah Kane.

What new writing most needs at the moment, as David Hare recently suggested, is for dramatists to recognise that "the external universe may be richer and more suggestive than the inside of their own heads". Correspondingly, what the classic theatre needs is to realise that there are more than 50 golden oldies - half of them by Shakespeare - doomed to endless, eternal revival. At this stage of history, is there any crying need for yet another production of The Seagull? Far more interesting this year were the attempts to explore theatrical byways. The Royal Shakespeare Company gave us George Bernard Shaw's dottily engrossing Back to Methuselah, and the Orange Tree presented a multiracial, pleasurably fantastic Arms and the Man. The Oxford Stage Company toured Somerset Maugham's The Circle, proving he was more than just a boulevard cynic. The Nottingham Playhouse, much livelier under director Giles Croft, shook the dust off JM Barrie's Dear Brutus. They showed him to be one of the eeriest theatrical talents of the 20th century.

Lazy thinking, as much as underfunding, is the British theatre's biggest enemy - in particular an ignorance of the repertory that simply assumes audiences want the same old stuff endlessly recycled. My plaudits go to theatres that offered something original. That includes the Gate for its season under Mick Gordon dubbed Loves Work, devoted to the byzantine irregularities of passion. But I'd also nominate Birmingham Rep, where director Bill Alexander ended a difficult few years with a season including Indhu Rubasingham's startling version of The Ramayana. This spiritual odyssey, based on a Sanskrit saga, would have had critics flocking if it had come from abroad. And where else but Glasgow Citizens would you expect to find a piece like Mae West's The Pleasure Man, which was ramshackle but gaudily watchable?

In an ideal world, the National Theatre would be leading the way in extending the repertory. The one really adventurous choice this year, apart from the new plays by Penhall and Harris, was the Pinter-Proust Remembrance of Things Past, which was a genuine distillation of a great novel rather than a mere reduction. But, dipping into Kenneth Tynan's letters recently, I came across a memo he wrote in 1967 to Olivier, during his period as the National's literary manager: "What the National Theatre does has become a matter of public acceptance rather than public excitement." For all the National's solid successes, that's rather how I feel; and 2001's revival of My Fair Lady, however dazzling, isn't going to solve the problem.

The initiative has passed to other theatres. To the Royal Court. To the RSC, which, a few duff shows aside, had a tremendous year with its Stratford history cycle, dominated by Steven Pimlott's revisionist Richard II. And to the Almeida, which gave us cunningly paired Shakespeares in Shoreditch, Nicholas Wright's clever Cressida in the West End and a mixed bag at its base, of which the prize exhibit was Pinter's feisty double-bill of Celebration and The Room. I read suggestions that Ian McDiarmid and Jonathan Kent are getting tired of doing questing, international seasons on a relatively paltry subsidy of £450,000. Isn't it about time grants were related to achievement instead of barnacled custom?

But one can't sum up British theatre in 2000 without saying something about the quality of the acting. Inevitably if Simon Russell Beale plays Hamlet or Michael Gambon takes on Davies in The Caretaker you expect them to be brilliant, and so they were. But I was struck this year by the excellence of work from less familiar, and even totally unknown names. It was heartening to find Paola Dionisotti picking up an Evening Standard award for her display of stubborn tenacity in Further Than the Furthest Thing. But Conleth Hill and Sean Campion, now en route for Broadway, deserved a special joint award for their miraculous double act in Stones in His Pockets. I also find myself remembering Sheila Hancock's love-awakened teacher in the David Eldridge play at the Court, Sean Caffrey's duplicitous dourness as the RUC detective in The Force of Change, Catherine McCormack lending style and tremulous sensitivity to the mysterious outsider in All My Sons at the National and - not least - a young actress called Jenny Jules who swept through Alice Childress's Wine in the Wilderness at the Tricycle Theatre with gale-force energy.

As ever, the British theatre brims with talent. And, as always, one hopes that in the year ahead it will be matched by a sense of risk and adventure on the part of our theatre directors. All too often that descends into a nervous populism. Writing in 1903, Chekhov condemned exactly that kind of pandering to familiar tastes claiming: "It's a question not of reducing Gogol to the people's level but of raising the people up to his." Exactly. And a bit more of that idealism wouldn't come amiss in 2001.

Michael Billington's top 10

The Force of Change at the Royal Court. Gary Mitchell's passionate thriller.

Under the Blue Sky at the Royal Court. Sex among the teachers: a compassionate play by David Eldridge.

Stones In His Pockets at the Duke of York's. A celebration of acting in Marie Jones's firecracker about Irish movie extras.

The Three Birds at the Gate. Stunning debut piece from Joanna Laurens. Philomel loses her tongue but a writer finds her voice.

The Caretaker at the Comedy Theatre. Michael Gambon in Pinter's classic.

Richard II at the Barbican. Steven Pimlott's brilliant start to the Shakespeare history cycle: Samuel West and David Troughton in prime form.

A Doll's House at the Lyceum, Edinburgh. Triumphant Norwegian import: Ibsen's Nora as domestic prostitute.

Tantalus, on tour through UK from January. The Greek myths unfold in John Barton's 10-play cycle. Unforgettable.

Faust, currently in Berlin. Peter Stein's superb version of Goethe's masterpiece.

The Ramayana at Birmingham Rep. Magic-packed treatment of a Sanskrit saga.

My point is that playwrights may need a nudge to address not just their subjective unease but the state of the nation at large. But it was a lively year all round for new writing. Marie Jones's Stones in His Pockets and Gary Mitchell's The Force of Change suggested that Belfast is a real source of energy. Joe Penhall's Blue/Orange, though it sometimes stretched credibility, was the National Theatre's best new play for a long time. And, on all sides, young women writers made their mark: Zinnie Harris with Further Than the Furthest Thing, Helen Blakeman with Normal and, most astonishing of all, Joanna Laurens with The Three Birds at the Gate. Having missed the opening, I went to Laurens's play as a civilian rather than as a critic and was bowled over by her re-telling of the Tereus and Philomel myth - in particular by her bold poetic diction with its coinages, inversions and dislocated rhythms. I'd say she is the most original theatrical voice to have emerged since Sarah Kane. What new writing most needs at the moment, as David Hare recently suggested, is for dramatists to recognise that "the external universe may be richer and more suggestive than the inside of their own heads". Correspondingly, what the classic theatre needs is to realise that there are more than 50 golden oldies - half of them by Shakespeare - doomed to endless, eternal revival. At this stage of history, is there any crying need for yet another production of The Seagull? Far more interesting this year were the attempts to explore theatrical byways. The Royal Shakespeare Company gave us George Bernard Shaw's dottily engrossing Back to Methuselah, and the Orange Tree presented a multiracial, pleasurably fantastic Arms and the Man. The Oxford Stage Company toured Somerset Maugham's The Circle, proving he was more than just a boulevard cynic. The Nottingham Playhouse, much livelier under director Giles Croft, shook the dust off JM Barrie's Dear Brutus. They showed him to be one of the eeriest theatrical talents of the 20th century. Lazy thinking, as much as underfunding, is the British theatre's biggest enemy - in particular an ignorance of the repertory that simply assumes audiences want the same old stuff endlessly recycled. My plaudits go to theatres that offered something original. That includes the Gate for its season under Mick Gordon dubbed Loves Work, devoted to the byzantine irregularities of passion. But I'd also nominate Birmingham Rep, where director Bill Alexander ended a difficult few years with a season including Indhu Rubasingham's startling version of The Ramayana. This spiritual odyssey, based on a Sanskrit saga, would have had critics flocking if it had come from abroad. And where else but Glasgow Citizens would you expect to find a piece like Mae West's The Pleasure Man, which was ramshackle but gaudily watchable? In an ideal world, the National Theatre would be leading the way in extending the repertory. The one really adventurous choice this year, apart from the new plays by Penhall and Harris, was the Pinter-Proust Remembrance of Things Past, which was a genuine distillation of a great novel rather than a mere reduction. But, dipping into Kenneth Tynan's letters recently, I came across a memo he wrote in 1967 to Olivier, during his period as the National's literary manager: "What the National Theatre does has become a matter of public acceptance rather than public excitement." For all the National's solid successes, that's rather how I feel; and 2001's revival of My Fair Lady, however dazzling, isn't going to solve the problem. The initiative has passed to other theatres. To the Royal Court. To the RSC, which, a few duff shows aside, had a tremendous year with its Stratford history cycle, dominated by Steven Pimlott's revisionist Richard II. And to the Almeida, which gave us cunningly paired Shakespeares in Shoreditch, Nicholas Wright's clever Cressida in the West End and a mixed bag at its base, of which the prize exhibit was Pinter's feisty double-bill of Celebration and The Room. I read suggestions that Ian McDiarmid and Jonathan Kent are getting tired of doing questing, international seasons on a relatively paltry subsidy of £450,000. Isn't it about time grants were related to achievement instead of barnacled custom? But one can't sum up British theatre in 2000 without saying something about the quality of the acting. Inevitably if Simon Russell Beale plays Hamlet or Michael Gambon takes on Davies in The Caretaker you expect them to be brilliant, and so they were. But I was struck this year by the excellence of work from less familiar, and even totally unknown names. It was heartening to find Paola Dionisotti picking up an Evening Standard award for her display of stubborn tenacity in Further Than the Furthest Thing. But Conleth Hill and Sean Campion, now en route for Broadway, deserved a special joint award for their miraculous double act in Stones in His Pockets. I also find myself remembering Sheila Hancock's love-awakened teacher in the David Eldridge play at the Court, Sean Caffrey's duplicitous dourness as the RUC detective in The Force of Change, Catherine McCormack lending style and tremulous sensitivity to the mysterious outsider in All My Sons at the National and - not least - a young actress called Jenny Jules who swept through Alice Childress's Wine in the Wilderness at the Tricycle Theatre with gale-force energy. As ever, the British theatre brims with talent. And, as always, one hopes that in the year ahead it will be matched by a sense of risk and adventure on the part of our theatre directors. All too often that descends into a nervous populism. Writing in 1903, Chekhov condemned exactly that kind of pandering to familiar tastes claiming: "It's a question not of reducing Gogol to the people's level but of raising the people up to his." Exactly. And a bit more of that idealism wouldn't come amiss in 2001. Michael Billington's top 10 The Force of Change at the Royal Court. Gary Mitchell's passionate thriller. Under the Blue Sky at the Royal Court. Sex among the teachers: a compassionate play by David Eldridge. Stones In His Pockets at the Duke of York's. A celebration of acting in Marie Jones's firecracker about Irish movie extras. The Three Birds at the Gate. Stunning debut piece from Joanna Laurens. Philomel loses her tongue but a writer finds her voice. The Caretaker at the Comedy Theatre. Michael Gambon in Pinter's classic. Richard II at the Barbican. Steven Pimlott's brilliant start to the Shakespeare history cycle: Samuel West and David Troughton in prime form. A Doll's House at the Lyceum, Edinburgh. Triumphant Norwegian import: Ibsen's Nora as domestic prostitute. Tantalus, on tour through UK from January. The Greek myths unfold in John Barton's 10-play cycle. Unforgettable. Faust, currently in Berlin. Peter Stein's superb version of Goethe's masterpiece. The Ramayana at Birmingham Rep. Magic-packed treatment of a Sanskrit saga.

webTitle: Country diary: Wenlock Edge

fields.headline: Country diary
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Today is Saturnalia, apparently. The Roman midwinter festival of wild debauchery and unruliness. Like the pagan solstice, Christmas and festivals in other cultures which have to survive, physically and emotionally, through the long nights and cold weather of winter, Saturnalia seems like a good idea. Corresponding with the old English yule, Saturnalia was a temporary abandonment of social restraints in memory of Cronos. Cronos the emasculator, deposed by Zeus, was the head of two ancient cults - the barley and the oak, both using the sickle (for harvesting barley or cutting mistletoe) and both demanding human sacrifice. The Latin Cronos was called Saturn, and his statue carried the crow's beak sickle for castrating his enemies. Cronos/Saturn was associated with the crow, as was his Celtic counterpart, Bran.

Today, all is eerily quiet. A thick, freezing fog crept in during the early hours and stayed all day. Nothing seemed to be having any fun. Even the tribes of Cronos and Bran - the ravens, rooks and jackdaws which during the very few recent rain-free days have been holding communal orgies in the fields and even preparing nests in the treetops - are sitting the fog out.

I'm on the search for holly and ivy for decorations, and this too is linked with Saturn. Holly was his club, ivy the symbolic nest of the goldcrest. And yule is the festival for "holly boys" and "ivy girls". I listen out for these spirits but hear only the rumble of a stream in the valley. In this cold fog anything could be happening - out of sight, lost from time, free from the constraints of the visible world, imaginations run wild.

webTitle: A quick one: The panto season

fields.headline: A quick one
fields.trailText: The panto season
fields.body:
Did you know that Cinderella had been on stage for more than a 100 years before Buttons turned up? Or that Aladdin's widowed mother had been around for 73 years before she acquired the name Twanky. Were you all aware that it was Cilla Black who restored the Female Boy to the London Palladium in 1971? Have you realised that I have found a book about panto and am now arbitrarily copying bits out of it?

Pantomime has evolved over more than 200 years into something very British and very weird. As with Lionel Blair, foreigners are generally amazed when the genre is explained to them. For my French friend Monique, it is confirmation of her suspicion that all Englishmen are secret homosexuals who want to dress up in skirts and wear make-up.

My own experience in this form is limited to a brief season in Copenhagen where I gave my dame. The audience mainly comprised of earnest academics keen to deconstruct this strange phenomenon. They would arrive an hour early to read an information pack explaining the history and conventions of the show. While I paraded around in a big frock duetting with the Sheriff of Nottingham, bearded sociologists scribbled away. They were an enthusiastic audience though, if a bit slow. When I got to the line, "oh yes it is", I had to wait 30 seconds while they consulted their notes to work out the correct response - but it came in a big Danish roar.

I'm not really a panto man. The thing that annoys me about it is that the bar is often not open during the second half. I was surprised then, a while back, when I was asked to write one for Julian Clary. I decided it would be interesting to do something radical, I came up with "King Lear - The Panto". It struck me that there are structural similarities between the great play and Cinderella, who is obviously Cordelia. Regan and Goneril are the ugly sisters. The Fool is Buttons. Admittedly, King Lear as Baron Hardup was stretching it a bit, but I presented my proposal with enthusiastic optimism. Julian's people said they'd get back to me. That was eight years ago. I note that Julian is starring in Cinderella at the Theatre Royal in Brighton and I'm sure he's brilliant. He was right to reject King Lear - The Panto. It would have been terrible. Blow winds and crack your cheeks, missus.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: What's on radio
fields.body:
Every month some 50,000 people around the world read about the delights of an English county that many will never have seen. For 60 years The Dalesman (11.0am, Radio 4) has been recording the changing history of the Yorkshire Dales through words, paintings, drawings and photographs. The lure of this eclectic mixture has made it Britain's bestselling regional magazine. Harry Gration browses through its record of a world that has moved in two generations from deepest isolation to tourist trap.

The world's most advanced catamaran hit the worst sort of headlines when it was abandoned in mid-Atlantic a couple of weeks ago. Earlier the sea trials of Team Philips had to end abruptly after it shed 40ft of its carbon fibre bow. The Race (9.0pm, Radio 4) tracks the development of skipper Pete Goss's £4m yacht, originally intended to beat all comers in circumnavigating the globe within 70 days on wind power alone.

webTitle: How eight year-olds grow up  fast

fields.headline: Daddy, you are the weakest link. Goodbye
fields.standfirst: From Barbie and Scooby Doo to PlayStation and Anne Robinson in one year: eight-year-old Maddy is growing up fast, sighs dad  Paul Morley
fields.trailText: From Barbie and Scooby Doo to PlayStation and Anne Robinson in one year: eight-year-old Maddy is growing up fast, sighs dad  Paul Morley
fields.body:
The year 2000 was a year of great change for my eight-year-old daughter Madeleine. It was the year she rejected the colour pink. For years one to seven, it had been her out-and-out favourite colour. Then one day, she suddenly groaned as we went on one of our regular walks, the one down the Barbie aisle in the local Woolies. She suggested that we didn't walk down the Barbie aisle any more as it was far too pink. She had to cover her eyes. It made her sick. It clearly reminded her of her silly over-pink youth, and as she raced off to look at some PlayStation games, I realised that I had, yet again, for about the 36th time this year, lost my little baby. How long before one of our regular walks would be to the local body-piercing parlour?

In 2000, Maddy also distanced herself from Pokemon and Potter, showing the first signs of a snobbery I could approve of. Pretty shoes and dresses became a thing of the 90s. The boys in her class started to become, you know, boys. School was work rather than play. Saturday morning TV switched from Live & Kicking to Ant and Dec. The Simpsons replaced the Rugrats. The Weakest Link replaced Scooby Doo, which puts Anne Robinson in proper perspective. Beanie babies replaced ... Beanie babies. (They must put something in them, or up them, so that - however pierced she becomes - she'll be collecting them until she's the appropriate age to collect them. Which is 67.) And halfway through violin practice - something she is beginning to suspect is forced on her as some kind of cosmic joke and which, between you and me, I must admit makes me chuckle occasionally - she first uttered the immortal phrase: "I hate my life." The ex-punk in me cheered; the middle-class parent marched her off to her room so that we could sit down and count her blessings. One by bloody one. You should have heard her violin-playing after that. She could guest on a Hole album.

The year 2000 was also the year she began to think that her father was a bit strange. She might be right, but I was hoping to keep it from her for a few more years. My lovable-eccentric ways are becoming irritating to her. I started 2000 as Funny Daddy, slipped during the year to acceptable figure of fun, and I am now all set to become the standard object of complete and utter scorn. By 2002, Maddy won't want me walking with her to the kitchen, let alone the tattoo parlour; her bedroom will be black, and Buffy the vampire slayer will have wiped out Barbie (who must be a vampire, so that makes sense). "Daddy" will have become "Dad": two syllables of unquestioning adoration becoming one hard syllable that takes things for granted.

I'm wondering if all these changes have something to do with my full-blooded performance of the Village People YMCA dance at her eighth birthday party last January. This was perhaps the moment when things turned. Maddy was no longer my little baby and it was no longer OK that I was Funny Daddy. She told me her schoolfriends commented on my exuberance. They all said that their dads would never be so foolish. She was mortified; pink with embarrassment. No wonder she went off the colour.

Now that Christmas Day has passed, her Beanie babies have officially become a plague and Sony her main sponsors, she'll have her mind on her birthday. She will be worried that her dad is going to do his Britney impersonation and permanently obliterate her as any kind of cool force at school. Worse, he might try to persuade all her classmates that the Pet Shop Boys are better than S Club 7. Can you imagine?

She needn't worry. I won't dance. And I won't buy her a pink violin. I'll do my best to be a grown-up father this year. One thing I've learned as a parent is that I am no longer a child, or even a teenager. I still act like one, at least in my dealings with other parents, who are mostly younger than me but still seem 20 years older - which means I can never think of anything to say to them. In that sense, my YMCA outrage last year was probably due to relief that none of the parents stayed, so I didn't have to recall any of the courses in small talk that, as someone from Stockport, the north, I found it necessary to go on. They probably left because of my incandescent awkwardness. I think of it as sensitivity, but I suppose it comes across as vaguely autistic.

Madeleine thinks she has it rough, but she should try to have to talk to the grown-ups like I do. Thinking of something to say does your head in. I've got absolutely nothing in common with them. They don't get me or my jokes or my music. Parents suck, man. It's enough to make you want to paint your bedroom black and pierce your navel.

 Paul Morley's book, Nothing, is published by Faber and Faber in paperback, price £11.99.

webTitle: 'His death barely touched me' - the story of Julie Myerson's father's suicide

fields.headline: 'His death barely touched me'
fields.standfirst: Julie Myerson  has no illusions about her father: he was sleazy, bitter and selfish. He even managed to spoil the birth of his granddaughter - by committing suicide. Here she recalls that fateful New Year's Day
fields.trailText: Julie Myerson  has no illusions about her father: he was sleazy, bitter and selfish. He even managed to spoil the birth of his granddaughter - by committing suicide. Here she recalls that fateful New Year's Day
fields.body:
Almost exactly 10 years ago, in the early hours of New Year's Day 1991, I gave birth to our daughter. It was unforgettable for several reasons. Because it was dazzlingly quick. Because the midwives on shift at St Thomas's Hospital in London had tinsel in their hair. Because we got to hold our minutes-old baby in our arms and watch the pink-wintry dawn explode over the Thames. And because we discovered the next day that my father had killed himself just as she was being born.

Spooky? Not really. People often take their own lives on the bleak edge of the year. In any case, we were estranged: he did not even know his granddaughter was due. And I wish I could say I wept, but I didn't. I didn't love my father. I had known since I was about 12 that I could not rely on him to show me any sort of love, let alone caring. His being alive was a constant reminder to me that I did not deserve - had not earned - his love. His death barely touched me.

But these days, when I see my boys and my girl (now a clever, curvy, all-but-10-year-old) playing, chatting, messing around joyfully with their own father, my heart aches. Here they are, safe with a man on whose undying affection, energy and commitment they can rely. And they know it.

"I hate you!" our 11-year-old yelled at him the other day when deprived of a further hour's Nintendo. I envied my son. At his age, I was anxiously polite to my father. Our fragile relationship lay in my skinny, nail-bitten hands. I never knew what sudden, unforeseeable blunder might make him turn away in disgust.

Virtually all my early memories of him are about sex. He liked Benny Hill, G-strings, Penthouse. When he married my mum, he was 32 and a mother's boy. I know he'd had one girlfriend, because years later he still went on about her - showing me photos of this icy, groomed blonde whose breasts poked at her sweater like ice-cream cones. On top of his wardrobe, he kept a photo of a nude woman straddling a chair. I thought she looked uncomfortable. Like the bare ladies lolling in prickly haystacks in his magazines, which we also giggled over. Though my mother was young and beautiful, my father felt that the 60s had come too late for him, that he'd missed out on the "permissive era". Other people's fathers went on about cars or sport or DIY. I was only eight but I knew mine was weird.

Girls should worship and adore their fathers. Mine was sometimes a laugh but, now that I'm older and he's safely gone, I understand that he revolted me. I was 12 when my mother - lonely, weary, brave - finally left him. Her leaving had two side-effects: it took me from him; good. And it left me (and my two younger sisters) alone with him; bad.

Every other weekend. That's what the judge said - and it was what my father wanted. Up to a point. He certainly wanted power over us, since it was his only means of getting back at Her. But once she'd gone, he became more and more embittered, angry and unkind, looking around obsessively for ways to hurt us. He refused to pay for a prescription when we stayed with him, wouldn't heat our rooms, or take us out anywhere. He scissored our mother's head out of every photo in the family album, and made us read aloud the affidavit for the divorce proceedings, which detailed her supposed adultery with our stepfather-to-be. I remember him ordering me to explain a sexual term to my eight-year-old sister: when I flushed and stumbled, he accused me of being "on Her side". I can see now what I couldn't see then: that he enjoyed an irresponsible, even unsavoury frisson when he saw us grapple with those words, those problems.

Every other Friday, he would drive over to collect us. He arrived later and later. I was 13, desperate to avoid a scene. My stomach would churn as I bobbed backwards and forwards, checking for his car. The deal was this: we had to leave the house immediately and speedily with our bags, so that he didn't have to spend time looking at "our mother's house". Also, we weren't allowed to refer to this place as "home" or mention Mum, the "streak of piss" she lived with, or his sons (our stepbrothers) by name. Naturally, we sometimes tripped up. I remember saying "Mummy" once by mistake and blushing to the roots of my hair. There were so many rules, I was sometimes almost sick trying to remember them.

His car smelled of cigarette smoke. He liked cars. He drove them and smoked in them and killed himself in one, but he never used them to do anything imaginative like leave Nottingham and see the world. The Audi's upholstery was sort of blond corduroy. He frequently asked us if we liked the colour. Yes, we said enthusiastically, we loved it. He used to ask me - incessantly, and sometimes in front of people - whether I had started my periods. I always shivered with embarrassment, always told him no. When I did start, I kept it quiet, but dreaded the possibility of staining that perfect blond upholstery.

At night, he would come and kiss us goodnight as he always had in the old life, except that our rooms were now depressing with their naked bulbs, lack of soft furnishing, knick-knacks or heating. When my mother left, she had taken half the furniture with her. He refused to replace anything. It was her choice, he reminded us again and again, that we lived like this. We came from a broken home, didn't we? Well, now we could reap the consequences.

I was 13, and then 14, and when he said goodnight, he put his tongue in my ear. When he did it to my younger sisters, they still shrieked with laughter. When he did it to me, I shuddered but didn't dare ask him to stop. I will never knock from my brain the memory of his moist tongue probing the inner shell of my ear.

When I was 16, he tried to get me to leave school, even though he was supposed to pay our school fees until we were 18. My mother took him to court and I was asked to pen a "polite and loving" note to my father, to be read out in court, explaining why I wanted to stay on. It was probably the most lucrative piece of writing I've ever done, since it won me my further education. But my father now loathed me more openly. A few months later, he wrote and said he thought it best if we did not see each other again.

Then, years later, when our first baby was born, my partner said that we should go and see him. I didn't want to. He told me we might regret it if we didn't try. Maybe, I said, maybe not.

I was terrified. When we knocked unannounced on his door, baby in sling, I could hardly breathe. My father was civil, cool, taken aback - but he gave us a drink, made a joke or two. webTitle: America's most over-rated

fields.headline: America's most over-rated
fields.standfirst: The problem with Colin Powell and a  small but significant protest on the streets of DC
fields.trailText: The problem with Colin Powell and a  small but significant protest on the streets of DC
fields.body:
Nothing is more lowering to the spirit than the season of goodwill, unless it is the season of the "healing process". In Washington, the recent combination of the two has been sickly and cloying beyond all words. The advent of Christmas always feels like a fortnight spent in a one-party state to begin with; the same music and exhortations on all channels and in all public places; the same fatuous paeans to a mythical "Dear Leader". Add to this a period of continuous unction and ostentatious "bipartisanship" and even the meekest might start to yearn for "the politics of division". (As if politics wasn't division by definition.)

The symbol of this uncritical and unreflective cultural moment is the coronation of America's most over-rated man, in the shape of former General Colin Powell. Because subliminal attitudes to pigment make him part of the Republican Party's much-ballyhooed "rainbow" strategy, his appointment as secretary of state is considered part of the outreach programme and his Senate confirmation hearings are going to be a congratulatory formality. This is a pity, because there are several questions that he ought to be asked.

Powell's fast-track career began in Vietnam, where he got the job of covering up the My Lai massacre in 1968. Two very brave American infantrymen, one of them a friend of mine named Ron Ridenhour and one named Tom Glen, had reported to their superiors - and in Ron's case to his congressman - a day-long orgy of murder, torture and rape in the above-named village, conducted by soldiers of the Americal Division of the US army. Glen's letter was forwarded to then-Major Colin Powell, who was then on the staff at Division HQ. Asked to draft a memo that would take care of matters, Powell wrote that Tom Glen had not come forward quickly enough and that his evidence was second-hand. "Relations between Americal soldiers and the Vietnamese people are excellent," concluded this ambitious young officer. The story of My Lai was buried and didn't break into the American press for another year.

Talent like that is quickly recognised and rewarded, and before long Powell was a White House fellow, keeping his mouth tight shut through the Watergate years. When Reagan came to power, Powell was found a high post at the Pentagon, working directly under Caspar Weinberger, and helped in the secret shipment of heavy weapons to Iran (in exchange for hostages, and also in exchange for secret money with which to fund an illegal war in Nicaragua). He also assisted in deceiving Congress about the violation of its ban on both dealings. Promote this man! Make him national security adviser! Hell - make him chairman of the joint chiefs of staff!

In the latter two capacities, Powell showed himself to be a poor soldier and a worse politician. Hearing reports of an Iraqi move against Kuwait, he strongly opposed sending even a flag-showing force to the Gulf. When Saddam Hussein took this and other Bush regime signals as a green light, Powell was forced to turn hawkish with the rest of them but always held out against helping the Kurdish and Shia rebellions. He was to take the same line on Bosnia, always putting the case that Milosevic was too strong to stand up to. (Operations like the invasion of Grenada or Panama, however, received his strong endorsement. Such demonstrations are easy and good for morale.)

President Harry Truman did two things to make himself felt as commander in chief. He ordered a reluctant army to desegregate and he unceremoniously sacked the arrogant General Douglas MacArthur, who was trying to run a private war in Korea. Colin Powell would have had no career if it wasn't for the first of those decisions. But when Clinton was elected in 1992 on a clear promise to lift the ban on homosexuals in uniform, Powell successfully led a near-mutiny to get him to back down. He also grossly exceeded his authority by going public in opposition to Clinton's other campaign pledge - which was to give military help to Bosnia.

This matters more than you might think, because the erosion of civilian control over the military has led us to a point at which - with almost no public debate - the US is considering the unilateral construction of a "Star Wars" missile-defence system. This is a crackpot scheme, ludicrously expensive and unworkable, while highly destabilising at the same time. Up until now, it has been restrained by protests from other countries, from scientists, from arms-control experts and from elements in the State Department. But now, at one stroke, the State Department has been annexed by a military conformist. Nobody is troubling to point this out because, like most bad things these days, it comes gift-wrapped by the ribbons and bows of "inclusiveness" and the politically correct.

Honk if you hate the electoral college!

Some of us hoped that there would be a rebellion among the ciphers of the "electoral college" and that at least some of them would vote with their consciences in protest against a scandalous process. In the anticlimactic event, on December 18, just one of them did: a staunch African-American lady from my home town of the District of Columbia. By refusing to vote at all, she robbed Al Gore of one digit he no longer needed, but that wasn't really the point. The citizens of DC are denied representation in Congress and live under colonial rule. Most of them are black and most of them vote Democratic. And a fat lot of good it has done them; Congress was in Democratic hands for most of the past five decades and did nothing to redress the injustice. Nor did eight years of Clintonism see the least attention paid to the open disenfranchisement of the people of the capital city of the free world.

However, there are tiny signs of growing resistance. One of the few powers retained by the DC government concerns the issuing of automobile licence plates. As with every other "state" of the union, these come complete with local mottoes. When I first moved here, the plates read "Nation's Capital", which was fair enough. The ghastly Mayor Marion Barry changed this, first to read, "A Capital City", which was too arch by far, and then, "Celebrate and Discover" - an insult to the eye and the intelligence alike. Just recently, after a local vote, the plate has been rewritten once more and, as new registrations kick in, the city's public and private vehicles increasingly flaunt the slogan: "Washington DC: Taxation Without Representation". A small gesture but, you will recall, one that has revolutionary implications.

 Christopher Hitchens is a columnist for Vanity Fair and The Nation. Francis Wheen is away.

webTitle: So, goodbye to Murray Walker

fields.headline: The final pit stop
fields.standfirst: The man known as 'the voice of motor racing' is to retire. As famous for his howlers as for his quickfire commentary, Murray Walker's passion - and prejudices - have always shone through, says  Stephen Moss
fields.trailText: The man known as 'the voice of motor racing' is to retire. As famous for his howlers as for his quickfire commentary, Murray Walker's passion - and prejudices - have always shone through, says  Stephen Moss
fields.body:
It's the end of an earache - or do I mean era? Murray Walker, the commentator once described as sounding as if his trousers were on fire, has announced that after 52 years he will be hanging up his microphone at the end of next year's formula one motor racing season. With David Coleman stepping down after 46 years, and Peter O'Sullevan enjoying a richly deserved retirement, it really is the end for the Grandstand commentary team who came to prominence after the war as TV and sport combined to take over our lives.

Walker, who is 77, has been getting some ageist flak in the tabloids, and says he is stepping down before the punters agree with the papers. "I want to go out while I'm ahead," he says, "because there are few things more pathetic than the chap who's hanging on desperately when the liking for him has gone and the control he has of the subject has gone." None of that, he hastens to add, has happened yet, but you never know what may be around the corner. Walker was an advertising executive for almost 40 years and evidently likes to play the percentages.

It is, as Walker himself points out, a journalistic cliche to trot out all the Murrayisms that have been the hallmark of his commentary over the years, but what the heck? "Do my eyes deceive me, or is Senna's Lotus sounding rough?" "He's obviously gone in for a wheel change. I say obviously because I can't see it." "With half the race gone, there is half the race still to go." "Tambay's hopes, which were nil before, are absolutely zero now." (Those of you who would like to read several hundred more of these should refer to www.worldmotorsport.com/murray/.

In fact, his reputation for mistakes was the making of Walker. He was always the fan who happened to have been given the keys to the commentary box: he couldn't control his enthusiasm and that seemed naturally to lead to catastrophe. Invariably, his reference to the ease with which a driver was winning a race would immediately be followed by the car skidding off the track, hitting a hoarding and somersaulting three times before disappearing into a ditch.

These incidents were replayed lovingly every year as part of the BBC's Sports Review of the Year, and the latter lost its most popular item when Walker followed formula one to ITV in 1996. "Unless I'm very much mistaken ... I AM very much mistaken!" became Walker's catchphrase: he might consider it a slur on his professionalism, but it made sure he was remembered. "We all make mistakes, but when I made mistakes there was no filter between me and the consumer," says Walker.

He has always been a conscientious mugger-up of facts and statistics, making sure he was prepared for any commentary, but the root of his popularity was the unalloyed joy his sport gave him. "I stand up in the commentary box, I get very excited, I rush about pointing at the screen. Most people seem to think I have about 16 monitors giving me a total view of the course. I don't. I have a monitor which gives me the picture that you see and everybody else sees at home."

From 1949, when he covered his first event, until 1982, when he retired from the ad agency where he had worked for 36 years, commentary was a sideline. "It was a hobby, like collecting stamps or chasing butterflies, but in 1978 the BBC said they were going to do all the grands prix and wanted me to do them, and that's when it started to take over."

Walker was born into motor racing. His father, Graham, was a TT champion, and Walker junior saw his first race when he was two. "I was soaked in the sport all through my childhood, and I was either going to like it or loathe it. I liked it, but I didn't really become enthusiastic to the point of obsession until after the war. I was in a tank regiment during the war, and started a brigade motorcycle club. When I came out I started racing, believing that I would show my father how to do it, but I very rapidly discovered that I wouldn't."

Failing to match his father's achievements didn't undermine him - he did far too well in the ad business for that - but did leave a mark. "It is difficult being the son of a famous father. You've always got this thing looming over you. I worshipped my father, but I remember thinking when I heard someone say, 'That's Graham Walker's son', I would like someone to point at my father and say 'That's Murray Walker's father.' I would be a lot prouder of myself if I had been world champion rather than just talking about it."

Instead of pursuing a career on the track, however, he chose the security of an ad agency. "I was a moderately good club-standard rider, but I suppose the truth is that it didn't matter enough to me and I chose to put my business career before trying to become a motorcycle superstar. But the enthusiasm remained and I sublimated it into talking about it." He began commentating on motorsports, especially motorbike racing, and during the 50s the Walkers formed a father-and-son commentary team.

Walker has two voices: one for conversation, the other for commentary. The latter is more a screech and resembles a 500cc engine being revved up. "I'm very lucky because I have got a voice that suits my sport," he says. "It's nothing that you can train yourself to have or to be. I deal with a harsh, aggressive, noisy, fast-moving sport and I have a harsh, aggressive, noisy, fast-moving voice."

In the early days of Grandstand, the commentary roster was fluid. Walker did a spot of rowing, but made the mistake of mocking the chaps in pink blazers (they were members of the crack Leander club). He also did some weightlifting, but eventually the motorsport took over and he became the voice of his sport. In his farewell year, he will commentate on 12 grands prix, leaving the other five open for ITV to try out possible replacements. He will be a tough act to follow.

For all the mistakes and malapropisms, there is a fund of goodwill towards him - when I met him he was signing hundreds of copies of his new book, Murray Walker's Formula One Heroes, for an adoring National Sporting Club audience in Manchester. That adoration has managed to survive his antediluvian attitudes. He has strong views on the place of women in motorsport: they don't have one. When I ask him how he would feel if a woman replaced him, he has a one-word answer: "Gutted." "I'm being chauvinistic, I know that, but motor racing is a male sport. If I hear a woman talking about cricket, I feel the same way. I have got nothing against women: my wife was a woman, my mother was a woman." This line may have been common in adman circles in about 1962.

Walker is also a chauvinist when it comes to Brits winning motor races. His three fondest memories are the races in which James Hunt, Nigel Mansell and Damon Hill took the world titles. The last of those - Damon Hill's triumph in 1996 - was especially sweet. "I had commentated on his father, double world champion Graham Hill, who was then killed and the family fell on very hard times. Damon fought his way up from nothing. Although he has an enormous amount of talent, he succeeded because he worked on that talent rather more than others more naturally gifted had to. He won the championship at the last event, the Japanese grand prix, and when he crossed the line to win the race and the championship, the whole thing welled up inside me and I said, 'I've got to stop, I've got a lump in my throat.' It sounds trite now, but it was totally genuine."

With Walker, what you see is what you get: he wears his passions - and his prejudices - on his rally jacket. He sits rather oddly with the snazzy, souped-up world of formula one, with its TV billions and corporate logos, a throwback to another age, who managed to survive all the revolutions in motor racing. He promises not to be a nuisance when he retires. "I will still go to races, but I'm not going to be a pathetic old hanger-on in the paddock saying, 'Do you remember when Fangio won in 1951?'" Just don't mention the motor racing-mad woman up in the ITV commentary box.
