From 1949, when he covered his first event, until 1982, when he retired from the ad agency where he had worked for 36 years, commentary was a sideline. "It was a hobby, like collecting stamps or chasing butterflies, but in 1978 the BBC said they were going to do all the grands prix and wanted me to do them, and that's when it started to take over." Walker was born into motor racing. His father, Graham, was a TT champion, and Walker junior saw his first race when he was two. "I was soaked in the sport all through my childhood, and I was either going to like it or loathe it. I liked it, but I didn't really become enthusiastic to the point of obsession until after the war. I was in a tank regiment during the war, and started a brigade motorcycle club. When I came out I started racing, believing that I would show my father how to do it, but I very rapidly discovered that I wouldn't." Failing to match his father's achievements didn't undermine him - he did far too well in the ad business for that - but did leave a mark. "It is difficult being the son of a famous father. You've always got this thing looming over you. I worshipped my father, but I remember thinking when I heard someone say, 'That's Graham Walker's son', I would like someone to point at my father and say 'That's Murray Walker's father.' I would be a lot prouder of myself if I had been world champion rather than just talking about it." Instead of pursuing a career on the track, however, he chose the security of an ad agency. "I was a moderately good club-standard rider, but I suppose the truth is that it didn't matter enough to me and I chose to put my business career before trying to become a motorcycle superstar. But the enthusiasm remained and I sublimated it into talking about it." He began commentating on motorsports, especially motorbike racing, and during the 50s the Walkers formed a father-and-son commentary team. Walker has two voices: one for conversation, the other for commentary. The latter is more a screech and resembles a 500cc engine being revved up. "I'm very lucky because I have got a voice that suits my sport," he says. "It's nothing that you can train yourself to have or to be. I deal with a harsh, aggressive, noisy, fast-moving sport and I have a harsh, aggressive, noisy, fast-moving voice." In the early days of Grandstand, the commentary roster was fluid. Walker did a spot of rowing, but made the mistake of mocking the chaps in pink blazers (they were members of the crack Leander club). He also did some weightlifting, but eventually the motorsport took over and he became the voice of his sport. In his farewell year, he will commentate on 12 grands prix, leaving the other five open for ITV to try out possible replacements. He will be a tough act to follow. For all the mistakes and malapropisms, there is a fund of goodwill towards him - when I met him he was signing hundreds of copies of his new book, Murray Walker's Formula One Heroes, for an adoring National Sporting Club audience in Manchester. That adoration has managed to survive his antediluvian attitudes. He has strong views on the place of women in motorsport: they don't have one. When I ask him how he would feel if a woman replaced him, he has a one-word answer: "Gutted." "I'm being chauvinistic, I know that, but motor racing is a male sport. If I hear a woman talking about cricket, I feel the same way. I have got nothing against women: my wife was a woman, my mother was a woman." This line may have been common in adman circles in about 1962. Walker is also a chauvinist when it comes to Brits winning motor races. His three fondest memories are the races in which James Hunt, Nigel Mansell and Damon Hill took the world titles. The last of those - Damon Hill's triumph in 1996 - was especially sweet. "I had commentated on his father, double world champion Graham Hill, who was then killed and the family fell on very hard times. Damon fought his way up from nothing. Although he has an enormous amount of talent, he succeeded because he worked on that talent rather more than others more naturally gifted had to. He won the championship at the last event, the Japanese grand prix, and when he crossed the line to win the race and the championship, the whole thing welled up inside me and I said, 'I've got to stop, I've got a lump in my throat.' It sounds trite now, but it was totally genuine." With Walker, what you see is what you get: he wears his passions - and his prejudices - on his rally jacket. He sits rather oddly with the snazzy, souped-up world of formula one, with its TV billions and corporate logos, a throwback to another age, who managed to survive all the revolutions in motor racing. He promises not to be a nuisance when he retires. "I will still go to races, but I'm not going to be a pathetic old hanger-on in the paddock saying, 'Do you remember when Fangio won in 1951?'" Just don't mention the motor racing-mad woman up in the ITV commentary box.

webTitle: Letter: Census, you can count me out

fields.headline: You can count me out
fields.trailText: The director of census, Graham Jones (Letters, December 23), suggests that he is pleased with the inclusion of a racial classification question in the 2001 UK census.
fields.body:
The director of census, Graham Jones (Letters, December 23), suggests that he is pleased with the inclusion of a racial classification question in the 2001 UK census. But he ought to remember that the inclusion of such a question, for the first time, in 1991, was one of the two main reasons why that census was the biggest shambles of any of the nine undertaken in the 20th century. (The other reason was the justifiable lack of trust in the census's confidentiality, and the implications for people's poll tax liability.)

It was admitted that a very large number of people were not included last time - though Jones's predecessor, PJ Wormald, tried to persuade Guardian readers a few years after the event that the census people had some magic way of deducing the "number and characteristics" of those who, by definition, they didn't know about. I don't think many of us fell for that.

In 1991, various friends and relations of mine, normally compliant and law-abiding, took great exception to attempts to have that meaningless concept, "race", compulsorily registered - an activity which they associated with Nazi Germany or apartheid South Africa. So they boycotted the census, as I did.

Conscientiously objecting to a part of the census form renders one liable to prosecution. Boycotting it altogether on the other hand - whilst also theoretically illegal - is easy and completely risk free. Hence the inclusion of a race question again this time round will ensure that many of us will again refuse to be counted.
Albert Beale
London
worldpeace@gn.apc.org

webTitle: Pass notes: Robert Downey Jr

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: Robert Downey Jr
fields.trailText: Robert Downey Jr
fields.body:
Age: 35.

Appearance: At a guess, I'd say suited and booted with a nice, clean shirt and neatly knotted tie. Brushed hair, probably, too.

Ooh. Why so smart? He's due in court today, charged with possession of cocaine and methamphetamine.

What, again? Give the man a break. After all, it's been a full seven days since Mr Downey completed his last drug-related prison sentence.

So how did Robert Jr enjoyed the festive season? Well, if history's anything to go by, it was a white Christmas round at his - and we're not talking unseasonal snowfall in California.

So what's happened to the once great actor who played Charlie Chaplin so convincingly? It seems that his role as a cocaine addict in Less Than Zero was an appropriate casting. In June 1996, he was arrested for driving under the influence, for possession of controlled substances and a concealed weapon (a .357 Magnum handgun).

Is that method acting? Or methadone acting. Less than a month after his original sin he was found passed out under the influence of drugs. He made it a hat-trick of arrests not long afterwards when he violated the conditions of his bail.

You just can't keep a bad Downey down. It seems Bob hasn't quite grasped the concept of quitting while out of his head. In October 1997, when he went on a four-day binge and was sentenced to six months in jail, he again violated the conditions of his probation and was sentenced to 14 months in prison. He was released in August and officially put on probation last week.

So will Downey be living the high life from now on? According to his lawyer, he'll be focusing his attention on "putting his life back together and putting this behind him ... I think he's committed himself to a life of sobriety".

Do say: " Just say no, Bob."

Don't say: "Need any help with your lines?"

webTitle: Letters: Anglo-Jewry should be on red alert

fields.headline: Side effects of conflict
fields.trailText: Anglo-Jewry should indeed be on red alert (Letters, December 22): against those Jews who, by calling every legitimate criticism of Israel anti-semitic, risk legitimising anti-semitism.
fields.body:
Anglo-Jewry should indeed be on red alert (Letters, December 22): against those Jews who, by calling every legitimate criticism of Israel anti-semitic, risk legitimising anti-semitism. One of the tragic side effects of the current conflict is the return to such utter foolishness as presenting Israel as a "crime-free" utopia, stereotyping all Arabs as irrational Jew-haters, and all the symptoms of the kind of denial pointed out by Martin Woollacott (Why peace processes are breaking down all over, December 22).
Simon Louvish
London

 I was very moved by Ahdaf Soueif's articles (A Palestinian journey, December 18 and 19). I often think that the media are so biased and one-sided in the western world that the Palestinian cause has no hope and the atrocities committed by the Israeli government will go unheard.

However, the Guardian does give me hope, in a country where the press is dominated by the right. Please keep up the good reporting and continue to publish material which gives a true account of current affairs.
Purvis Ghani
Nottingham

webTitle: Letters: Porn: who has the monopoly?

fields.headline: When it comes to porn, who has the monopoly?
fields.trailText: I am astonished by your comment on Richard Desmond's acquisition of Express Newspapers (Leader, December 22). There is no monopoly involved, so why encourage the Competition Commission to exceed its remit?
fields.body:
I am astonished by your comment on Richard Desmond's acquisition of Express Newspapers (Leader, December 22). There is no monopoly involved, so why encourage the Competition Commission to exceed its remit?

It is hard to claim that Northern & Shell will make a less satisfactory national news proprietor than News International just because its owner also runs a porn empire. The Sun prints pictures of naked girls every day and has done so without serious reprimand for decades. Desmond is unlikely to go further than this in any bid to increase Express circulation without alienating the remaining core readership. Anyway, Mr Desmond's successful OK! magazine demonstrates that he is quite capable of selling publications to middle Britain. I would hope that as a porn baron, he might recognise porn when he sees it. Maybe he is less open to the twisted moral sensibility that allows the Sun to call itself a "family" newspaper. This claim is at odds with its own soft porn content, which in turn clashes with its reactionary attitude to issues concerning sex in British society.

The MMC's concern over David Sullivan's 1990 Bristol Evening Post bid had three points. Let's apply them to this situation. First, the concern that editorial policy and content could be influenced. Why not let Des influence all he wants? NI papers never run negative stories on the Murdoch family or print empire, and the Sun's coverage of events has never been hailed for its objectivity or comprehensiveness. Second, that the paper's "standing in the community" might be affected by its corporate links to porn.

This is precisely a function of peculiarly British attitudes towards the sex industry which other tabloids do their level best to maintain, and which are absent from continental European cultures. Third, that "there could be some adverse effects on circulation". This is precisely what will be the proper test of whether Desmond can run the Express or not. His stated aim is to spend whatever it takes. Porn, especially internet porn, does at least make a lot of money, though how well off Portland Investments actually is seems to be open to question.

At the end of the day, if the Express does fold, who cares? My gran is the only Express reader I know. Why save it if nobody wants to read it?
Ludovic Tolhurst-Cleaver
Bowdon, Cheshire

• Thanks for the expose of Richard Desmond's porn connections. It is disturbing that some of his publications feature fetish material promising "hard action". Yet I remember a G2 (Mr Blowup and chums, August 2) featuring a very positive writeup of the London Fetish Fair, including interviews with a number of people providing very unusual sexual services. I know there is a difference between you and Desmond in terms of degree of involvement and the naffness factor, but is there not just a frisson of hypocrisy here?
Dave Burke
Houghton-le-Spring, Tyne and Wear ChezBurke@aol.com

webTitle: Letters: Unfit for humans

fields.headline: Unfit for humans
fields.trailText: Your leader (December 23) rightly refers to the mixed picture of local food law enforcement, but wrongly claims that there is no joined-up government between the Food Standards Agency and local authorities.
fields.body:
Your leader (December 23) rightly refers to the mixed picture of local food law enforcement, but wrongly claims that there is no joined-up government between the Food Standards Agency and local authorities.

One of the first acts of the newly established FSA was to agree with local authorities national standards for performance on food law enforcement and activity. These are to be monitored, audited and made publicly available.

Arising from the Rotherham case, the FSA is investigating an anomaly in the regulations in relation to meat that is unfit for human consumption. Of course, there is much more to do and we hope that our partnership with local authorities will raise standards throughout the UK. Inevitably, as the FSA continues its work new issues relating to food and food safety will be uncovered.

As you point out the public need to have more information and FSA policy is to improve labelling so that consumers can make informed choices.
Suzi Leather
Deputy chairman, Food Standards Agency

 Having deliberately sold contaminated meat for profit - which may have caused long-term illness or even death to those who ate it - the culprits receive jail sentences of between less than four years and eight years.

Barry Horne - an animal rights campaigner who wishes to see cruelty to animals stopped - placed incendiary devices in buildings. The devices did not go off, no one was harmed, yet he received an 18 year sentence.

It is not the severity of the crime that counts in British justice, but how political it is.
Sara Starkey
Tonbridge, Kent

webTitle: Letters: New light on our world

fields.headline: New light on our world
fields.trailText: Great photo of the world at night (Darkness visible, December 23). But it doesn't, as you state, depict population concentrations, so much as concentrations of technology, and therefore wealth.
fields.body:
Great photo of the world at night (Darkness visible, December 23). But it doesn't, as you state, depict population concentrations, so much as concentrations of technology, and therefore wealth. China appears decidedly dim if we see it as a population indicator.
David Clifford
Cambridge
djhc2@cam.ac.uk

 It is pleasant to find our school mentioned in your esteemed journal (How two dames saved Oh! Calcutta!, December 23). We know that child poverty is among our challenges, we have had our share of financial difficulties. Despite these vicissitudes we never deserved to become Kidbroke School.
Dick Quibell
Chair of governors, Kidbrooke School, London

 Your leader (December 23) describes Ken Clarke as the biggest beast in the Tory menagerie. Surely you mean the biggest flea in the circus.
Danny Proudfoot
Northwich, Cheshire
Danny@proudfootd.freeserve.co.uk

 Three cheers for Kate Hoey MP, when she calls for terracing to be allowed in football stadiums again (Hillsborough families attack sports minister over backing for terraces, December 23). Whereas one could then meet up with old friends by chance or arrangement, now one is often forced to sit next to bigots and bores with no chance of moving.
C Hopper
Brighton

 I do wish the Prince of Wales would get his brain in gear before running off at the mouth (Prince says sorry as EU army view is leaked, December 23). The special relationship between super power US and mini power Britain is that we do as they tell us. The relationship between the US and the EU would be rather more equal: that might be a little uncomfortable for the US, but in the long run it would be better for the world, better for Britain and the US.
David G Sawtell
Luton
david.sawtell@ukonline.co.uk

 I presume the intended answer to the King William's College quiz (G2 December 22) question 11x (rhyming words to describe a barrel organ) is hurdy gurdy. A hurdy gurdy is in fact a multi-stringed instrument whose only similarity to a barrel organ is that it is played by turning a handle. Nice to know that the quiz compilers are not infallible - and are maybe even human.
Neil Brookes
Higher Kinnerton, Flintshire

 Any 89-year-olds completed the King William's College quiz yet?
Sue Wallace
Chepstow, Monmouthshire
suewallace@itton.fsnet.co.uk

 Hot cross buns with a sell-by date of January 17 (Letters, December 23)? My Marks and Spencer's Christmas tree was labelled display until January 17 - I rather think demand might have dropped off by then.
Pamela Murphy
London

 My preferred seasonal greeting (Leader, December 23) is "Happy Christmas and a rewarding New Year".
David Halliday
London

webTitle: Japan slides back towards deflation

fields.headline: Japan slides back towards deflation
fields.trailText: The spectre of deflation returned to Japan yesterday as new government data showed rising unemployment, falling consumption and a steady deterioration of prices.
fields.body:
The spectre of deflation returned to Japan yesterday as new government data showed rising unemployment, falling consumption and a steady deterioration of prices.

The dismal statistics blighted hopes that the world's second-biggest economy could take up the slack left by the slowdown in the United States.

According to the management and coordination agency, consumer prices in Tokyo have declined by 1% since the start of this year, the steepest annual fall since records began in 1971.

Product prices slipped across the board for the second consecutive year and for the first time ever the cost of golf, karaoke and other services fell.

The deflationary trend was apparent nationwide in November, when consumer prices declined, by 0.5%, for the 15th month in succession. Retail sales fell for the 44th month in a row.

Government officials and analysts had expected an increase in sales of big-ticket items and in "oseibo," year-end gifts of gratitude.

"We had hoped that a rise in winter bonus payments would help push up consumption but that will not be very likely," said Fukushiro Nukaga, the economics minister.

Consumption accounts for 60% of Japan's gross domestic product, but separate figures showed wage earners' spending fell 2.3% in November.

Consumers are squirreling away their money in savings accounts because of jobs fears. The labour ministry announced that unemployent hit an eight-month high of 4.8% in November.

The gloom pushed the Japanese currency to its weakest level in more than a year at 113.6 yen to the dollar and 105 yen to the euro.

webTitle: Bitter pill for Glaxo staff

fields.headline: Bitter pill for Glaxo staff
fields.standfirst: Drugs merger will cost thousands of jobs as 'British' world beater's power base shifts across Atlantic
fields.trailText: It has been a tough Christmas for staff at Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham. The two firms' £114bn merger comes into effect today, creating the world's largest drugs company. Few will be hanging out the bunting.
fields.body:
It has been a tough Christmas for staff at Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham. The two firms' £114bn merger comes into effect today, creating the world's largest drugs company. Few will be hanging out the bunting.

The festive season has been marked by anxiety as employees wonder if they will have a place in the combined corporation. Unions expect between 2,000 and 5,000 redundancies from a workforce of 23,000 in this country, with up to 15,000 job losses worldwide.

One woman having a cigarette last week outside Glaxo's west London head office summed up the mood: "We've been climbing the walls all year - this thing's been going on for ever." She is one of the lucky ones - close to retirement. "If you've got a family and a mortgage it's very difficult."

Behind Glaxo's sprawling headquarters in suburban Middlesex, on the edge of an industrial estate in Greenford, the wood-panelled Black Horse is the pub of choice for employees.

The bar staff are among the few to be delighted at the impending deal because money has been rolling in from a series of parties. "We don't know which ones are Christmas do's and which ones are leaving do's," a barman said.

Few Greenford workers are prepared to talk, with their jobs in the balance. "I really can't say anything at all," says one smartly dressed man hurrying into the complex. A security guard then emerges to demand no more "intrusion" on Glaxo employees.

Officially, today marks a new dawn for Britain's pharmaceuticals industry, the creation of a rarity: a British company that leads the world in its sector.

GlaxoSmithKline will be the country's third-biggest corporation, with a market value of £114.3bn. In the drugs industry, it eclipses rivals such as AstraZeneca, which is worth £59bn, and its market share of 7% is a shade ahead of its nearest rival, Pfizer of the US, which recently merged with Warner Lambert.

The birth has been protracted. The US federal trade commission took months to decide whether a handful of smoking-cessation products conflicted, an issue still unresolved.

Meanwhile, "FDA" has become an unpleasant acronym for insiders as the US food and drug administration ordered withdrawal of Glaxo's much-hyped Lotronex, for irritable bowel syndrome, and refused approval for SmithKline's antibiotic Factive. Together with the failure of a late-stage heart drug in SmithKline's portfolio, these setbacks cost as much as £900m in annual sales.

Today's merger is being made as low key as possible. Even announcement of a new logo and corporate identity has been postponed, and chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier is refusing interviews.

Insiders say the setbacks mean even more savings will be sought to make the merger pay. The two groups have promised £750m of annual synergies but this figure could be increased to as much as £1bn.

Mr Garnier is considered an ascetic boss who is big on efficiency and low on sentiment. Based in Philadelphia, which many believe will be the genuine HQ of the "British" company, he has rationed the disclosure of personal information. He confesses a liking for the American game of paddle tennis and been seen eating lunch alone in a modest Greek restaurant near his office.

Mr Garnier is thought to be fond of centralisation , squeezing Glaxo's traditionally diffuse structure into a series of strict reporting lines. Power over strategy and accounting policy will be taken from regional managers, to be concentrated in Philadelphia.

The prognosis for employees in Britain is unclear. Glaxo and SmithKline have announced that they are shutting seven of their 10 sites in south-east England. New Horizons Court, a new building in Brentford, Middlesex, will be the corporate head office. The Greenford site will be a research and development centre.

Few doubt GlaxoSmithKline will put more investment into new drugs. But staff will have to swallow sour-tasting medicines, largely prescribed from across the Atlantic.

webTitle: Red tape taskforce tackles BT

fields.headline: Red tape taskforce tackles BT
fields.trailText: The government's red tape tsar, Lord Haskins, has begun an investigation into the way British Telecom is regulated, in response to "deep breathing" from the firm's unhappy competitors.
fields.body:
The government's red tape tsar, Lord Haskins, has begun an investigation into the way British Telecom is regulated, in response to "deep breathing" from the firm's unhappy competitors.

The multi-millionaire Northern Foods boss, who chairs the Better Regulation Taskforce, said he wanted to establish whether the current set-up hands an unfair advantage to BT or whether the company is hamstrung by excessive interference.

In an interview with BBC Radio 4's Today programme, he said: "The reality of BT is that they are now operating in a severely competitive market and it could be that some of the regulations are inhibiting them from operating in the market as well as they could be."

Equally, he said, he would examine complaints from the industry's "deep breathing lobby", which comprises unhappy telecom operators who feel they "don't get a proper chance to sell the wares".

His taskforce, which reports to the Cabinet Office, has already made informal contact with BT. It expects to report its findings in the middle of next year.

"We don't take a prejudiced position about these things," Lord Haskins said. "What's right and what's wrong, we'll have to see."

BT has been severely criticised by rival operators for dragging its feet in "unbundling the local loop". This is the process by which it allows competitors access to its network for the last few miles to consumers' doors.

The firm has also been accused of charging excessive prices to ordinary customers, and of failing to keep pace with the explosion in demand for mobile phones.

Insiders at BT complain that the company is restricted in what it can do by the industry regulator, Oftel.

A BT spokesman said yesterday: "BT operates under the most intrusive regime in the country, and in the world. If someone like Lord Haskins wants us to share our experiences with them, we'll be happy to do that."

The spokesman said a recent OECD report had found that BT's prices for internet access were among the lowest in the industry. He added that 5m British phone customers used "local loops" controlled by cable operators such as Telewest and NTL, which will not be required to open up to competitors.

"The extent of the regulatory regime permeates everything we do," he said. "We don't operate in a level playing field."

The Better Regulation Taskforce was set up to examine the role of regulatory bodies in different industries. The taskforce is also conducting inquiries into the energy regulator, Ofgem, and the civil aviation authority.

Lord Haskins said he wanted to see whether BT was having similar trouble to Railtrack in adapting to a competitive, market-driven environment.

BT's chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, has come under fire over the firm's sluggish share price. There have been complaints that the company's management culture lacks dynamism.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Graham Corbett, chairman of the new post regulator, PostComm, has decided to scrap the Post Office's monopoly on letter deliveries completely from March.
fields.body:
Sunday Business

Graham Corbett, chairman of the new post regulator, PostComm, has decided to scrap the Post Office's monopoly on letter deliveries completely from March.

Compass Partners, the US venture capital firm, is the mystery bidder in talks to by Clubhaus, the British golf club operator.

MG Rover, the carmaker, is set to cut its losses from £824m during 1999 to £120m by the end of 2001.

The office of fair trading is expected to clear Dixons of charges of fixing the personal computer market. An investigation followed a complaint from John Lewis, the department store group, in April.

Tomkins, the engineering group, is considering a break-up which would see the sale of its two core businesses: auto components and construction equipment. It would first have to sell its Smith & Wesson guns business, however, which is viewed as a "poison pill" to potential buyers.

Observer

The publishing empire run by Richard Desmond, the new owner of the Express newspapers, has paid just £200,000 in corporation tax since it was established eight years ago.

National Lottery operator Camelot will pay GTech, the controversial gaming technology group, £230m over the course of its new seven-year licence.

Amazon.co.uk, the British wing of the American online retailer, saw a 40% surge in visitors in the run-up to Christmas, according to marketing consultancy AC Neilsen.

Sunday Times

Internal figures from Marks & Spencer point to another disappointing Christmas for the retailer. In the six weeks to mid-December, clothing sales are thought to have fallen 12% year on year.

Kingfisher, the Woolworth's and B&Q operator, is considering the sale of its £1.6bn property portfolio, wiping out the group's debts.

Vickers, now owned by Rolls Royce, is on track to win an order worth £2.4bn to build armoured vehicles for the Greek government.

Sunday Telegraph

The four bidders vying to run two of the three planned sectors of the London Underground have been told to submit fresh proposals after their initial offers were rejected.

Aegon, the Dutch financial services group, is said to be the leading bidder to run Equitable Life's investment management business and sales force.

French spirits group Pernod Ricard is front-runner to win the distribution rights for Sweden's Absolut vodka.

Mail on Sunday

FI Group, the computers services concern, is running a "sack-a-colleague" scheme, where staff are being offered a £1,000 bounty to name jobs which could be done by cheaper workers from India.

Don Cruickshank, chairman of the London Stock Exchange, is on a collision course with board members and the City over the failure to find a new chief executive and his reluctance to consult on strategic issues.

IoS

Pay-TV operator ONdigital is at odds with the Broadcasters' Audience Rating Board over the number of its subscribers. The affair could cloud the company's £2bn flotation, expected within the next 12 months.

Matthew Fosh, managing director of Garban Futures, has declared himself a contender to become chief executive of London Stock Exchange.

webTitle: Leader: The accordion is inseparable from the memory of Jimmy Shand

fields.headline: What a squeeze
fields.standfirst: Some call it a bagpipe with pleats
fields.trailText: For generations the strains of the accordion, played to introduce a jig or reel or strathspey,   immediately identified no one except Jimmy Shand and his band.
fields.body:
At the end of It's a Wonderful Life - where would Christmas be without Capra? - the benign Bedford Falls police chief (played by Ward Bond), renders Hark the Herald Angels on an accordion, at least until the off-screen 100-piece studio orchestra takes over. It is just the right instrument for the occasion, brash and versatile, perfect for a raucous sing-along. Never mind that some call it a bagpipe with pleats.

Yet instrumentally speaking the accordion is a bit of a bastard, with umpteen kin, among them the harmonium and mouth organ and any number of variant squeezeboxes. Perhaps because of its hybrid descent, it never quite made it into the mainstream. Accordions are rarely seen in either the classical orchestra or jazz lineup. Yet the instrument and its kin enjoy worldwide appeal. Its popularity has not faded since the collapse of Russian communism - where would the leaping cossacks of the Red Army have been without an accordion ist? It is played in America north and south, a mainstay for example of the Canadian band La Bottine Souriante, who wowed audiences here on a recent visit. As well as Cajun music, it is the traditional accompaniment to the Argentine tango. If in England it is the kind of thing played when the men with hankies strut their stuff on the village green, in Ireland and Scotland the accordion will forever be associated with the 20th century urban dance band personified by Sir Jimmy Shand who has just died.

Purists may say Sir Jimmy played not an accordion but a concertina (an analogue of the piano with each button for both hands playing one note at a time rather than chords). Whatever, his distinction among musicians was to make a sound unmistakably his own. For generations (and he enjoyed a revival among the young in his eighties), those long chords played to introduce a jig or reel or strathspey - immediately identified no one except Jimmy Shand and his band.

webTitle: Time for the provinces to fight back?

fields.headline: Capital offence
fields.standfirst:
It is an awesome, self-sufficient powerhouse that looms over the regions and plays to no one's rules but its own. But is London sucking the life out of the rest of the country? Hywel Williams believes it is time for the provinces to fight back
Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: It is an awesome, self-sufficient powerhouse that looms over the regions and plays to no one's rules but its own. But is London sucking the life out of the rest of the country?  Hywel Williams believes it is time for the provinces to fight back
fields.body:
Earth in 2000 - it seemed - had nothing to show that was more fair. It was London's year. Heritage had always been good for local trade, but now there was a dramatic edge of elegant modernity to gratify the locals and attract the visitors. Suddenly this was a renaissance city, an affair of courtyards and galleries, of walkways, avenues and towers which revealed new vistas and perspectives to feed the mind and delight the spirit. Forgotten buildings were reborn and new ones rose from the ground. London had made it new and the shock of the modern had arrived by the banks of the Thames.

Londoners still had to contest with the tube, of course, as their daily via dolorosa. But however battered by infrastructure, they knew as they looked above ground that they were privileged to be part of a phenomenon. 2000 was one of those years in urban history when one city held the world's attention. Even the one failure - the Dome - was so monstrous that it could only have happened in the city which was the one and only place to be.

The scale of the success dazzled but also bewildered - so out of pro portion, it seemed, with what went on anywhere else in Britain. It was all heady stuff, and London was certainly good for London. But was it good for Britain as a whole?

London now stretches from Chelmsford in the east to Reading in the west, from St Albans in the north to Crawley in the south. Oxford and Brighton, Colchester and Milton Keynes are its suburbs. All who live within this area are Londoners. They earn more money, exercise sharper wits, lead faster lives and live in more expensive houses than their fellow Britons. Go beyond this domain and you're out of it. What you may gain in manners you will lose in edge and pace. The differences between Londoners and the English are now as great as those between the British and the Italians. This is not a city. It is a nation.

London works harder and longer than England. But the work ethic which is its tribute to residual protestantism is twin to its hedonism. London always did drink more than England - first gin, then beer and now wine. It also swears more, with that violently exhaled "fuck", the product of the extra aspirant peculiar to the word's London pronunciation.

Provincial laments about London recur in English history. The "great wen" was thought to be a spectacularly sinful consumer of goods and gratifier of appetites. But its most important consumption has always been that of people, whom it draws within its maw and turns to its own use. Hence the lament of the London-Welsh preacher that Paddington station was the most sacred spot on earth because it was where the Welsh deposited their souls on arrival. It has always been seen as a foreign place - and one that is out of synch with the English nation's temper, whose most tempting self-image is one of rural withdrawal and gentrified order.

Once there were towns medium and large that mediated between these two extremes of Arcady and Babylon. But their importance in politics and culture has died. The county towns are now just a part of the English countryside. Leeds and Sheffield, Birmingham and Newcastle contribute little to the outside world's view of what England is and does.

Middlemarch is the last great English provincial novel, and George Eliot is now almost as dead as Queen Anne. Arnold Bennett is remembered - if at all - as an omelette invented at the Savoy, not as the voice of the Potteries. Our literary voices are London ones. Muriel Spark's tone is never that far a cry from Kensington and Beryl Bainbridge is more Camden than Scouse. Martin Amis's characters display the Londoner's self-conscious enjoyment of low motive. Julian Barnes's are discoverable only under the auspicious constellations of SW and N. The cardiganed angst of Anita Brookner's heroines is a peculiarly north London condition. Literature enforces London nationalism.

Like all nations, ever since Upper and Lower Egypt started the game, London has its "north-south divide". It has its national symbol in the Eye - a suitably pagan appropriation of Fortuna's wheel for a very secular place - and a worthy necropolis in the Dome. It has an assembly and a healthy tradition of radical rioting. But the nation is more interested in money than in politics. GLC abolition came and went while life flowed back into the boroughs, London's constituent cities of Clerkenwell and Chelsea, Islington and Lambeth.

London is more tolerant of eccentricity, of differences of race, faith, colour and sexuality than the rest of England. But it is a tolerance which is born of indifference. We rub shoulders - and so we have to get on with things rather than introspect.

The nation is international without being particularly outward- looking. It can afford to indulge its own form of provincialism. Here you can eat and forget that most of England remains a gastronomic dump. We're gratified to have 200,000 French citizens here - and some believe the Europhobic press, which sees them all as economic exiles from taxation rather than the jobbing waiters they more often are.

London is the central imaginative, commercial and political fact of modern England. But London as nation is also a European disaster.

There's no continental equivalent for the way London looms over the country in which it finds itself. "Over-centralised" France has always been something of a comforting Euro-sceptic myth, especially after the decentralisation of the 80s. Rhetorical emphasis on national unity - like republican injunctions of fraternity - were only necessary because the reality was so different.

Paris's influence has been cultural and intellectual. But the lives lived in Lyons and Bordeaux, Rennes, Tours and Avignon show not only models of bourgeois civilisation which have disappeared from the English provincial town, but also a diffusion of power and influence. England, the country that united earlier and more completely than any other European one - and did so under the aegis of an imposed Protestant uniformity and a dominant capital - is a European oddity.

In Germany, ancient forms of imperial free cities, the Freistädte, lurk beneath modern Länder and a myriad civic forms of autonomy bloom. In Italy, Rome is a home for the spirit and the bureaucrat, but Turin is one for intellectuals and Milan is the capital of the catwalk and of capitalism alike. Madrid was an Iberian Canberra invented by Philip II at the artificial heart of his country - but in Barcelona, Vigo and Bilbao ancient liberties are revived in the regionalised peninsular experience.

In continental Europe the city-state tradition is alive and kicking. Sometimes that tradition has taken an imperial form (Venice) and an occasionally despotic one (Florence). But by and large it has looked back to a more ancient model, to Athens and Rome - and to republican traditions of participation which made sense because the political unit was small enough.

England offers no parallel to these survivals from an old world renewed. Its regions are not authentic provinces. Wessex and Mercia are dreary units of diminished local government - not cultural forces that attract loyalty. Offa's memory moves no West Midlands dissidents. East Anglia is just a TV franchise and, apart from the terrible sound of Peter Pears wailing in the Aldeburgh marshes, is not a cultural experience. And London in all its national but anonymous vastness can offer no political space - only room to consume.

London is not just bigger - and more conceited - than any other European capital. It is also immeasurably more powerful financially. The euro cannot work if the world's largest foreign exchange market stays outside. Breaking the euro will also be the breaking of Europe. But a wrecked Europe is also the ruination of London.

Europe needs the London nation but cannot accommodate it. That nation's rootless, shiftless sense of adventure makes it an impossible partner in the imagined safety zone of "European integration". To the settled political-historical differences we must add London's present mood of capitalist glee and cultural pride in which it imagines itself to be an imperium receiving tribute from every subject race. The conceit is not just foolish - it has all the elements of a "necessary" tragic conflict: irreconcilable opposites, hubris, ignorance and collision ending in waste.

Berlin, Rome, Paris and their sisters can all handle "Europe". London, seeing it as either a threat or an irrelevance, can't or won't. This is the only capital in Europe which sees itself as an awesomely self-sufficient power exercising a dominion of homogenised taste, central government and financial power over the benighted provinces.

But in post-Maastricht Europe the English regions and cities are now offered not only money but also a constitutional model. There's the prospect of a prestige which they lost in Britain's late imperial 20th century but can regain in the Europeanised England of the 21st century. The provincial elites can confront the metropolitan elites and look beyond them to the European ones. Here lie the seeds of a major conflict of allegiances and powers: not only a regional renaissance but also a capital counter-revolution.

"Provincial" can now mean "European" - not obscure. Yorkshire, Cornwall and Devon can join Rhne-Alpes, Catalonia and Lombardy in the recognition that we are all Euro-regionalists now. But metropolitan London, so long the beneficiary of a feudal dominance over England, will seem self-centred and even small-minded when its self-interest separates it from England.

The journey towards the recognition that the Midlands need not be sodden and unkind will be a bumpy one. But it is more realistic to see here the pattern of an inescapable conflict. England's great cities - the Manchester of the Manchester Guardian and the Birmingham of the Chamberlains - were once civic jewels. But the tradition is decayed - the victim of centralism in both its Old Labour and its rebarbative Thatcherite forms.

The European regionalism which may revive those cities as power-houses does stand in an awkward relationship to the English experience. Continental Europe is a place of shifting boundaries. Alsace- Lorraine transferred from France to Germany and to France again, Poland partitioned, Trieste suspended between the Hapsburg dynasty and the Italian state: all sum up a continuous European story of treaties made and broken, of loyalties transferred and boundaries rendered ambiguous. Where nothing is constitutionally fixed for ever, it makes sense to have multiple allegiances.

Now for the first time in English history since the civil war there is the prospect of the provincial powers distancing themselves from the capital and seeing London as the problem, not the solution. Europe wants to show the regions that they have more in common with each other than they do with London. Stand by, then, for the rise of the English-European region - and for the London backlash.
fields.bodyText: Earth in 2000 - it seemed - had nothing to show that was more fair. It was London's year. Heritage had always been good for local trade, but now there was a dramatic edge of elegant modernity to gratify the locals and attract the visitors. Suddenly this was a renaissance city, an affair of courtyards and galleries, of walkways, avenues and towers which revealed new vistas and perspectives to feed the mind and delight the spirit. Forgotten buildings were reborn and new ones rose from the ground. London had made it new and the shock of the modern had arrived by the banks of the Thames. Londoners still had to contest with the tube, of course, as their daily via dolorosa. But however battered by infrastructure, they knew as they looked above ground that they were privileged to be part of a phenomenon. 2000 was one of those years in urban history when one city held the world's attention. Even the one failure - the Dome - was so monstrous that it could only have happened in the city which was the one and only place to be. The scale of the success dazzled but also bewildered - so out of pro portion, it seemed, with what went on anywhere else in Britain. It was all heady stuff, and London was certainly good for London. But was it good for Britain as a whole? London now stretches from Chelmsford in the east to Reading in the west, from St Albans in the north to Crawley in the south. Oxford and Brighton, Colchester and Milton Keynes are its suburbs. All who live within this area are Londoners. They earn more money, exercise sharper wits, lead faster lives and live in more expensive houses than their fellow Britons. Go beyond this domain and you're out of it. What you may gain in manners you will lose in edge and pace. The differences between Londoners and the English are now as great as those between the British and the Italians. This is not a city. It is a nation. London works harder and longer than England. But the work ethic which is its tribute to residual protestantism is twin to its hedonism. London always did drink more than England - first gin, then beer and now wine. It also swears more, with that violently exhaled "fuck", the product of the extra aspirant peculiar to the word's London pronunciation. Provincial laments about London recur in English history. The "great wen" was thought to be a spectacularly sinful consumer of goods and gratifier of appetites. But its most important consumption has always been that of people, whom it draws within its maw and turns to its own use. Hence the lament of the London-Welsh preacher that Paddington station was the most sacred spot on earth because it was where the Welsh deposited their souls on arrival. It has always been seen as a foreign place - and one that is out of synch with the English nation's temper, whose most tempting self-image is one of rural withdrawal and gentrified order. Once there were towns medium and large that mediated between these two extremes of Arcady and Babylon. But their importance in politics and culture has died. The county towns are now just a part of the English countryside. Leeds and Sheffield, Birmingham and Newcastle contribute little to the outside world's view of what England is and does. Middlemarch is the last great English provincial novel, and George Eliot is now almost as dead as Queen Anne. Arnold Bennett is remembered - if at all - as an omelette invented at the Savoy, not as the voice of the Potteries. Our literary voices are London ones. Muriel Spark's tone is never that far a cry from Kensington and Beryl Bainbridge is more Camden than Scouse. Martin Amis's characters display the Londoner's self-conscious enjoyment of low motive. Julian Barnes's are discoverable only under the auspicious constellations of SW and N. The cardiganed angst of Anita Brookner's heroines is a peculiarly north London condition. Literature enforces London nationalism. Like all nations, ever since Upper and Lower Egypt started the game, London has its "north-south divide". It has its national symbol in the Eye - a suitably pagan appropriation of Fortuna's wheel for a very secular place - and a worthy necropolis in the Dome. It has an assembly and a healthy tradition of radical rioting. But the nation is more interested in money than in politics. GLC abolition came and went while life flowed back into the boroughs, London's constituent cities of Clerkenwell and Chelsea, Islington and Lambeth. London is more tolerant of eccentricity, of differences of race, faith, colour and sexuality than the rest of England. But it is a tolerance which is born of indifference. We rub shoulders - and so we have to get on with things rather than introspect. The nation is international without being particularly outward- looking. It can afford to indulge its own form of provincialism. Here you can eat and forget that most of England remains a gastronomic dump. We're gratified to have 200,000 French citizens here - and some believe the Europhobic press, which sees them all as economic exiles from taxation rather than the jobbing waiters they more often are. London is the central imaginative, commercial and political fact of modern England. But London as nation is also a European disaster. There's no continental equivalent for the way London looms over the country in which it finds itself. "Over-centralised" France has always been something of a comforting Euro-sceptic myth, especially after the decentralisation of the 80s. Rhetorical emphasis on national unity - like republican injunctions of fraternity - were only necessary because the reality was so different. Paris's influence has been cultural and intellectual. But the lives lived in Lyons and Bordeaux, Rennes, Tours and Avignon show not only models of bourgeois civilisation which have disappeared from the English provincial town, but also a diffusion of power and influence. England, the country that united earlier and more completely than any other European one - and did so under the aegis of an imposed Protestant uniformity and a dominant capital - is a European oddity. In Germany, ancient forms of imperial free cities, the Freistädte, lurk beneath modern Länder and a myriad civic forms of autonomy bloom. In Italy, Rome is a home for the spirit and the bureaucrat, but Turin is one for intellectuals and Milan is the capital of the catwalk and of capitalism alike. Madrid was an Iberian Canberra invented by Philip II at the artificial heart of his country - but in Barcelona, Vigo and Bilbao ancient liberties are revived in the regionalised peninsular experience. In continental Europe the city-state tradition is alive and kicking. Sometimes that tradition has taken an imperial form (Venice) and an occasionally despotic one (Florence). But by and large it has looked back to a more ancient model, to Athens and Rome - and to republican traditions of participation which made sense because the political unit was small enough. England offers no parallel to these survivals from an old world renewed. Its regions are not authentic provinces. Wessex and Mercia are dreary units of diminished local government - not cultural forces that attract loyalty. Offa's memory moves no West Midlands dissidents. East Anglia is just a TV franchise and, apart from the terrible sound of Peter Pears wailing in the Aldeburgh marshes, is not a cultural experience. And London in all its national but anonymous vastness can offer no political space - only room to consume. London is not just bigger - and more conceited - than any other European capital. It is also immeasurably more powerful financially. The euro cannot work if the world's largest foreign exchange market stays outside. Breaking the euro will also be the breaking of Europe. But a wrecked Europe is also the ruination of London. Europe needs the London nation but cannot accommodate it. That nation's rootless, shiftless sense of adventure makes it an impossible partner in the imagined safety zone of "European integration". To the settled political-historical differences we must add London's present mood of capitalist glee and cultural pride in which it imagines itself to be an imperium receiving tribute from every subject race. The conceit is not just foolish - it has all the elements of a "necessary" tragic conflict: irreconcilable opposites, hubris, ignorance and collision ending in waste. Berlin, Rome, Paris and their sisters can all handle "Europe". London, seeing it as either a threat or an irrelevance, can't or won't. This is the only capital in Europe which sees itself as an awesomely self-sufficient power exercising a dominion of homogenised taste, central government and financial power over the benighted provinces. But in post-Maastricht Europe the English regions and cities are now offered not only money but also a constitutional model. There's the prospect of a prestige which they lost in Britain's late imperial 20th century but can regain in the Europeanised England of the 21st century. The provincial elites can confront the metropolitan elites and look beyond them to the European ones. Here lie the seeds of a major conflict of allegiances and powers: not only a regional renaissance but also a capital counter-revolution. "Provincial" can now mean "European" - not obscure. Yorkshire, Cornwall and Devon can join Rhne-Alpes, Catalonia and Lombardy in the recognition that we are all Euro-regionalists now. But metropolitan London, so long the beneficiary of a feudal dominance over England, will seem self-centred and even small-minded when its self-interest separates it from England. The journey towards the recognition that the Midlands need not be sodden and unkind will be a bumpy one. But it is more realistic to see here the pattern of an inescapable conflict. England's great cities - the Manchester of the Manchester Guardian and the Birmingham of the Chamberlains - were once civic jewels. webTitle: Hunting ban row takes to the street

fields.headline: Hunting ban row takes to the street
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: The biggest event in the fox hunting calendar went ahead amid bitter scenes yesterday as thousands of protesters turned out to jeer and heckle riders at Boxing Day meets across the country.
fields.body:
The biggest event in the fox hunting calendar went ahead amid bitter scenes yesterday as thousands of protesters turned out to jeer and heckle riders at Boxing Day meets across the country.

Emotions ran high on both sides of the political divide less than a week after MPs voted heavily in favour of a second reading of the government bill banning fox hunting in England and Wales.

The national debate was most fiercely played out in Maldon, Essex, where members of the hunting lobby and protesters took up positions on opposite sides of the narrow high street in a face-off lasting several hours.

Traffic was diverted from the usually quiet town centre as two small armies of more than 500, hemmed in by crash barriers and police, taunted each other as they waited for the local hunt to pass through.

Protesters waved placards showing pictures of brutalised foxes as they declared "moral war" on the hunting lobby.

One activist, a hunt saboteur for 20 years, said the feeling was one of "now or never". The 53-year-old professional who declined to be named, said: "This is our finest hour. If we do not get a ban now, I do not believe we ever will. Hunting isn't the cruellest thing going on. It is the tip of a huge iceberg but it is the easiest thing to get banned. It has got to go.

"It would be a moral victory and it would open the floodgates for further essential reform. This is crucial for animal rights. It is a war. There is no other word for it. It is not a class war, it is a moral war."

Laina Cracknell, executive committee member of the League Against Cruel Sports, said she believed the bell was finally tolling for hunting and was confident that an absolute ban was the only was forward.

But, across the road, the Countryside Alliance poured scorn on the "excessive boasts" of animal rights activists, dismissing any suggestion of defeat and insisting thousands of people across the UK had shown themselves committed to securing hunting's future.

Liz Mort, spokeswoman for the pro-hunting group, said: "We are very buoyant and optimistic and we are certainly looking forward to hunting in the next millennium. There are few protesters compared with the numbers of supporters."

An hour-long standoff escalated into an emotional frenzy as the men and women of the Essex Farmers & Union Foxhounds hunt approached Maldon high street. Horses and hounds appeared bewildered by the deafening noise as they were corralled between the two camps, while immaculate riders greeted supporters, smoked cigarettes and enjoyed cups of wine before the day's exertions.

Police later confirmed that there had been one arrest after hunters and horses were pelted with missiles, including eggs, during their 15-minute appearance in Maldon.

Protesters also targeted a meet of the Holcombe Harriers near Bolton, Greater Manchester, and a further 120 activists descended on the Spooners and West Dartmoor hunt's meet in Tavistock, Devon. At the Duke of Beaufort's estate in south Gloucestershire, police estimated there were about 1,500 hunt supporters.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, recently offered the hunters a glimmer of hope that the government might be prepared to back down, when he came out against an outright ban, declaring his support for a compromise which would allow the option of tighter licensing of hunts.

But the bill is certain to meet passionate opposition in the Lords where peers will be allowed to vote on three options.

The Conservative leader, William Hague, is also under backbench pressure to give a commitment to make repealing a ban a top priority if re-elected.

Mr Hague was warned last week by the former agriculture secretary Douglas Hogg that he would "have to look over his shoulder" if he did not give a clear commitment.

He told MPs he was not speaking for himself, but some of his colleagues in saying: "If we get back in with a majority and the bill is passed, we will do our utmost to ensure that hunting is lawful once again."

The bill will reach the Lords near the end of February. Discussions have already started on the best sequence of voting to ensure that the Lords get a proper chance to support for their preferred option. It is expected the Commons will vote for an outright ban early next month. The Lords will then be given the option of voting for the ban, a licensing authority or self-regulation.

Timetable for bill

The hunting bill presents three options:

A complete ban on hunting with hounds - put forward by the RSPCA, the League Against Cruel Sports and the International Fund for Animal Welfare under the umbrella group Deadline 2000

Statutory regulation - based on the premise that hunting with dogs should be allowed to continue only on a licensed basis with an enforceable code of conduct - put forward by the cross-party middle way group

Self-regulation - put forward by the Countryside Alliance

MPs are to vote on the three options in January

Bill will then go into standing committee, to be completed by February 8

Expected to go to House of Lords by end of February

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Your guide to the best TV films
fields.body:
Strangers On A Train

(Alfred Hitchcock, 1951)

12noon, 6pm, Sky Cinema

A classic, black-hearted thriller, with Hitchcock's tongue even more firmly in cheek than usual. The story, part-written by Raymond Chandler from Patricia Highsmith's novel, has tennis player Guy meeting the apparently sane Bruno, who suggests a murder-swap - he will top Guy's troublesome wife if Guy will reciprocate in the case of his father, the logic being that the police will never trace the killers. Some wonderfully wry scenes, including one of Hitch's nastiest murders, at the fairground.

Citizen Kane

(Orson Welles, 1941)

6pm, FilmFour

Nearly 60 years on, Citizen Kane still tops most best-movie-ever lists. Directed, co-written by and starring the brash 25-year-old debutant Welles, it sets about unravelling, through a series of brilliantly interwoven flashbacks, the significance of a newspaper tycoon's deathbed utterance: "Rosebud", and pushes back the technical and imaginative boundaries of cinema.

Shakespeare In Love

(John Madden, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

Madden's robust comic romance plays handsomely to the masses in the pit rather than the highbrows in the gallery, and much of the fun is down to Tom Stoppard's witty, literate script. Expect pratfalls, wicked puns, rhetorical flourishes, tears and laughter, and a cast that revels in it all, from Joseph Fiennes' feckless Will to Gwyneth Paltrow's Viola, his love and muse (both pictured).

Miller's Crossing

(Joel Coen, 1990)

10pm, Sky Cinema

The gangster movie gets a witty and ironic update from the mercurial Coen brothers. Gabriel Byrne's Tom is lieutenant to crimelord Leo (Albert Finney) in a 1930s neo-Chicago; Tom's attempts to go legit are undermined by his boss's old-fashioned way of dealing with rival Jon Polito's outfit. And Tom is also having an affair with Leo's girl (Marcia Gay Harden, who's a real tough femme fatale). It's an intricate plot, but this comes hard, fast and witty as a Dashiell Hammett novel.

webTitle: Decision day for Middle East talks

fields.headline: Decision day for Middle East talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Today is the deadline set by President Bill Clinton for both sides in the Middle East conflict to declare whether they accept proposals put forward in Washington last week as a framework for continuing talks
fields.body:
Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat was last night facing the toughest decision of his long political career. Today is the deadline set by President Bill Clinton for both sides in the Middle East conflict to declare whether they accept proposals put forward in Washington last week as a framework for continuing talks.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, has already said he would be "compelled" to accept the proposals if Mr Arafat does so.

Although the US plan falls well short of Palestinian expectations, outright rejection would force Mr Arafat into a corner. The violence, which has cost 350 lives since the end of September - 90% of them Palestinian - would almost certainly resume at heightened levels.

Underlining the threat, a fresh round of violence erupted yesterday when Palestinians opened fire on a Jewish settlement near Nablus. Israeli troops responded with heavy machine gun fire.

Lower-level gun battles erupted over Christmas, but no deaths were reported in nearly three days - a rarity for the latest uprising.

President Clinton has told both sides that if they say no, he will pull out of negotiations. That could strengthen the hand of Ariel Sharon, the Likud contender for Israel's prime ministership, which would present the Palestinians with an even tougher adversary. Acceptance, on the other hand, runs the risk of a backlash among Mr Arafat's supporters.

The latest plans appear to offer a concession to the Palestinians on the all-important issue of Jerusalem, granting them sovereignty over the sacred area known as al-Haram al-Sharif, the Temple Mount to Jews, though with strings attached.

In return, the Palestinians are being asked to concede another major principle: the right of refugees to return home.

An indication of the likely reaction came yesterday from Marwan Barghouthi, a senior official in Mr Arafat's Fatah organisation and a key figure in the present uprising. "Show me one Palestinian who would dare accept these American ideas or even thinks of accepting them," he said.

The US proposals were Israeli ideas in disguise, he added. "They are a departure from UN resolutions."

Mr Barghouthi said Mr Clinton's ideas "mean maintaining Israeli occupation of most of Jerusalem, keeping settlements on our land, that Israel won't withdraw to the 1967 borders and no right of return of refugees. This is rejected."

Although the fate of Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem has been widely regarded as the main issue in the latest intifada, the 4m-5m Palestinian refugees cannot be lightly abandoned.

It is thought likely that Mr Arafat will try to avoid giving a commitment and seek further clarification of the proposals. In expectation that the Palestinian reply will not be an outright no, the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, is preparing to meet Mr Barak in the Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh tomorrow.

webTitle: Queen extols her belief in the spiritual

fields.headline: Queen extols her belief in the spiritual
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Christmas 2000
Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Queen used her Christmas day broadcast this year to make an unusually forthright defence of her personal religious beliefs, as if to answer the critics of her role as defender of the faith and supreme governor of the Church of England.
fields.body:
The Queen used her Christmas day broadcast this year to make an unusually forthright defence of her personal religious beliefs, as if to answer the critics of her role as defender of the faith and supreme governor of the Church of England.

Largely setting aside the more usual litany of trips made and people met, the Queen chose instead to affirm her sense of personal accountability to God and the comfort she draws from various Christian references.

Her remarks came on a day when her daughter, Princess Anne, did not endear herself to elderly subjects gathered to see the royal family leave the morning service at St Mary Magdalene Church on the Sandringham estate in Norfolk. Several of the elderly onlookers claimed in distress that the Princess Royal appeared to snatch a floral basket proferred by a pensioner with the words: "What a ridiculous thing to do."

She was also alleged to have hustled her nieces, the princesses Beatrice and Eugenie, past the crowd by telling them to get a move on.

Her mother's speech, which was recorded earlier in the month at Buckingham Palace, contained the comment: "Many will have been inspired by Jesus's simple but powerful teaching: love God and love they neighbour as thyself - in other words treat others as you would like them to treat you. His great emphasis was to give spirituality a practical purpose."

The speech, broadcast on the internet as well as on radio and television, appeared to be aimed at the largely overlooked spiritual dimension to the millennium, and was underlined by the pictures accompanying the television version showing the Queen standing self-consciously beside a grinning Tony Blair at the fraught celebrations at the Millennium Dome last New Year's Eve.

The Queen takes seriously her coronation commitment to uphold the country's religious settlement, including the established church, and is known to have firm private convictions.

Her words, as some thought to comment yesterday, would not have seemed out of place in a pulpit.

The Queen told the people - her "subjects" - only 7% of whom now attend church on Sundays, though up to two-thirds still profess to have some form of religious belief: "If you want to see an expression of Christian faith, you only have to look at our awe inspiring cathedrals and abbeys, listen to their music or look at their stained glass windows, their books and their pictures.

"Whether we believe in God or not, I think most of us have a sense of the spiritual, and I believe that this sense flourishes despite the pressures of our world."

And, mindful of the multi-ethnic character of Britain these days, the Queen yesterday added: "This spirituality can be seen in the teachings of other great faiths. Of course, religion can be divisive but the Bible, the Koran and the sacred texts of the Jews and Hindus, Buddhists and Sikhs, are all sources of divine inspiration and practical guidance passed down through the generations. To many of us, our beliefs are of fundamental importance. For me the teachings of Christ and my own personal accountability before God provide a framework in which I try to lead my life.

"I, like so many of you, have drawn great comfort in difficult times from Christ's words and example. I believe the Christian message in the words of a familiar blessing remains profoundly important to us all."

The Archbishop of Canterbury, who on Sunday preached to the royal family at Sandringham, used his Christmas day sermon to call for more Christian compassion in Britain for asylum seekers, comparing their plight to that of Mary and Joseph arriving in Bethlehem.

George Carey told the congregation at Canterbury Cathedral: "As hundreds of asylum seekers pour through Dover weekly, local people find it difficult to reconcile the duty of hospitality which has been so characteristic of our nation for many years, with the prospect of finite resources being overburdened ...

"It is to the credit of the people of the ports of east Kent that resentment has not totally blocked the spirit of human kindness and hospitality."

Even that was too much for one tabloid. Yesterday's Daily Mail, which has led a campaign against asylum seekers, tempered its Christmas spirit with the comment: "How telling it was that our leading churchman...used his pulpit to deliver a political message ... his record amply shows he tends to see social problems in facile, liberal terms.

"It is, putting it mildly, disingenuous to suggest that the plight of Mary and Joseph has anything but the most superficial resemblance to the position of asylum seekers here. For a start [they] were not in Bethlehem as refugees ... nor did they lie about their reason for wanting shelter...They were not given handouts from the pockets of the over-taxed citizens."

webTitle: TV cameras planned for court cases

fields.headline: TV cameras planned for court cases
fields.standfirst: Judges urged to build up public confidence in criminal justice system
fields.trailText: Judges urged to build up public confidence in criminal justice system
fields.body:
Television cameras are to be allowed into courts for the first time in England and Wales in a ground-breaking initiative to bring the "remote" judicial system closer to people's lives.

Under plans being drawn up by ministers, cameras would be free to film virtually all court proceedings except jury trials. This would open up all appeal court hearings, judicial reviews and Lords hearings.

Senior members of a ministerial committee, which is looking at ways of reforming the court system, believe the English and Welsh judicial system can learn a lot from America, where voters were able to hear or watch every legal move in the marathon presidential court hearings.

"The courts belong to the people and this is about making the system more relevant and closer to the people," one minister said. "I've been struck by the US ability to see the Florida supreme court in action."

The initiative, which is being championed by the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, highlights a growing fear in the government and among senior judges that the criminal justice system is in danger of appearing remote.

The lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, spoke publicly of his fears yesterday when he said that judges should do more to build confidence in the criminal justice system. He wants judges to take time out to visit schools and to invite schoolchildren to visit their courts.

In an interview with the Today programme Lord Woolf said: "What I believe is critically important is to contribute to public confidence in the system. I think, in the same way as the police are getting much better at going into schools, so we have got a message to give, because we play a very important role in society."

Ministers hope to take a big step towards fostering confidence when they unveil plans after the election to allow cameras into courts. Cameras would be allowed to film three types of hearing - appeal court hearings, judicial reviews and Lords hearings.

If the law had been in place in the past year, cameras would have filmed three high-profile cases - Neil Hamilton's libel appeal last week, which he lost; Sinn Fein's ongoing judicial review against David Trimble's decision to ban the party from a special cross-border ministerial body; and the full House of Lords hearings into General Pinochet.

One minister said the public should have been able to see the whole Pinochet case instead of the "shoot-outs" when cameras were only able to film individual law lords as they stood up to deliver their rulings: "It was a pity that you only saw the shoot-outs in the Pinochet case because the rules only allowed the televising of the Lords chamber and not the presentation of cases."

But ministers are expected to draw the line at filming jury trials and magistrates' courts. The minister said: "There would be a danger of a member of the jury seeing edited highlights of a court case on the television. That section could then be blown out of all proportion in his or her mind."

Ministers on the review group, which is chaired by the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine of Lairg, and which includes the home secretary, Jack Straw, are following the example of the Scottish judicial system which has allowed cameras into courts since 1992, provided all sides agree.

The ministerial review complements a review of the criminal courts being carried out by the appeal court judge, Lord Justice Auld.

Previous attempts to change the 1925 Criminal Justice Act, which prohibits cameras in English and Welsh courts, have failed. A backbench bill, drawn up with the support of the Bar Council in 1991, fell for lack of government support.

Since then the judiciary has opposed the televising of court proceedings. Lord Bingham of Cornhill, the former lord chief justice, said it would "increase enormously" the stress of everyone involved.

In the Today interview his successor highlighted the judiciary's new awareness of the importance of the media. "I want to try to explain to the public what judges are about," Lord Woolf said.

You only saw the shoot-outs in the Pinochet case because the rules allowed the televising of the Lords chamber and not the presentation of cases
