webTitle: Guardian Christmas charity appeal

fields.headline: Giving a vital helping hand to the needy
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Christmas charity appeal: A blaze of publicity, especially at Christmas, brings charities much needed income. But too often donors never get the chance to ask how the cash is spent. This week we caught up with the groups that featured in last year's appeal

Special report: Christmas appeal 2000
fields.trailText: Guardian Christmas charity appeal: A blaze of publicity, especially at Christmas, brings charities much needed income. But too often donors never get the chance to ask how the cash is spent. This week we caught up with the groups that featured in last year's appeal
fields.body:
Ockenden International

This charity promotes self-reliance for refugees and other displaced people. Working with refugees, survivors of wars and the internally displaced, the organisation's aim is to help restore self-sufficiency.

Often the charity works with families where the heads of the households are women, and where there are disabled or very young children. Frequently the people needing help are among the most vulnerable in society.

Ros Taylor, the charity's fundraising manager, said: "The £50,000 we received from Guardian readers after last year's Christmas appeal was used as quite a big contribution towards a pilot programme in Adjumani, northern Uganda, one of the main areas where the Ebola virus has struck."

Adjumani is an area where many Sudanese refugees flee to in order to escape the war in southern Sudan.

Agnes Aldino, one of the women we heard about last year, had seen her youngest child die from malaria in a shanty town near Port Sudan. She has not seen her firstborn, who lives in northern Uganda, for 15 years. Another of her daughters lives with relatives in the south of Sudan where the civil war grinds on.

Agnes's husband has vanished, and now only Viola, another daughter aged 13, is staying with her.

Their beds take up most of the small shelter they occupy on the edge of the desert where temperatures soar to 45C and sand storms rattle the flattened cooking oil drums which serve as walls.

For Agnes, 35, the choices have been stark. Some women go into prostitution to provide for their families. After arriving in Port Sudan she chose a business almost as risky in a strict Islamic society - brewing alcohol.

"My condition was very bad," she says. "I was brewing and selling spirits made from date palms. The police used to catch me and send me to prison for three months at a time.

"But I needed to make the money to eat and feed Viola. I didn't have anyone to help me. When I was in prison I used to leave Viola with neighbours but I couldn't continue doing that."

She came to the attention of Ockenden's team of workers helping refugees to learn new trades.

A year on and thanks to a loan from Ockenden International, Agnes is involved in handicrafts and has a small catering business of her own selling tea and coffee in a market place.

She is also able to give help to other women, and more importantly she earns an income for her family which is not likely to land her in jail.

(Ockenden International: 01483 772012)

The Fairtrade Foundation

A total of £50,000 was raised last year, as a result of the Guardian Christmas Appeal, for the Fairtrade Foundation, a charity that helps impoverished farmers in developing countries get a fair deal and cover the cost of their crop production.

The donated money went towards the charity's communications programme, boosting by 25% the number of consumers aware of the Fairtrade mark and now buying at least some of their goods as Fairtrade products.

The Guardian last year highlighted the need for fair trade in the four Windward islands that supply Britain with many of its bananas.

Last year, Renwick Rose who lives in St Vincent, had been trying to persuade the big supermarkets to offer Fairtrade bananas.

She said: "When you buy a cheap banana [one sold on the conventional market] you are unwittingly participating in the exploitation of labour. There is blood, sweat and toil behind that banana.

"Fairtrade does not ask you to pay more - just what it costs."

One year on, farmers' products from these islands appear in UK shops with the consumer guarantee label awarded by the Fairtrade Foundation to companies buying on the alternative, fair trade, market.

Julia Powell, the group's communication director, said: "There's no doubt that that kind of publicity in the Guardian helped to put pressure on the supermarkets who in turn put pressure further down the line.

"Already on St Vincent a few hundred farmers are generating an extra £1,000 a week from the sales to the UK market and that is going in a separate fund which all four islands will decide how to spend to improve conditions generally.

"It means [farmers] are earning around a third more than they would have been getting - though they are having difficulties even covering their costs, let alone making an income."

Phil Wells, of the Fairtrade Foundation, says there are at least 500,000 farmers around the world probably benefiting from the charity's work. "But very many farmers - the bulk of the small farmers around the world - are suffering terribly still."

(Fairtrade Foundation: 0207 4055942)

Friends for Young Deaf People

A partnership that helps deaf people become active members of society, Friends for Young Deaf People wanted to provide a family coordinator to work with parents of deaf babies.

Through last year's Guardian Christmas Appeal, the charity was able to highlight the lack of services available for parents of newly diagnosed deaf babies.

Therese Wilson, FYD's head of marketing and fundraising, said many parents the charity sees have just discovered the disability in their baby, deafness that sometimes has occurred after meningitis or measles. Whatever the cause, the impact is always the same - shock and bewilderment.

"If you are hearing parents, it's a ghastly shock," said Ms Wilson. "And there are not that many services available to advise parents on how to cope. Parents ask themselves how are they going to communicate with their child.

"How will their baby learn to speak and read? They are really terrified for their child's future.

"Even basic questions such as how you tell your children you love them or how deaf children tell you they are thirsty, seem enormous problems at first.

"But all these problems can be overcome and there are tried and tested mechanisms for teaching your child to sign. You do build up a rapport with them. But you need the confidence to know that it will be all right.

"That's what FYD plans to give these parents."

(FYD: 01342 323444)

The Family Welfare Association

Publicity, said Helen Dent, chief executive of the Family Welfare Association, has over the past year pumped up their annual fundraising by £50,000, thanks to the Guardian Christmas Appeal for 1999.

This has meant more money for giving directly to poor families living in Britain.

One case she remembers well was that of the Iraqi mother of three who fled Saddam Hussein's regime.

She is now living in Wales but has been waiting two years for the outcome of her asylum application. With her husband missing, presumed dead, she is struggling to support three children aged 11, 13 and 15.

She is not allowed to work and besides finding it difficult to adapt to the new culture in the UK, still fears she may be deported back to Iraq.

Although this family gets 90% of income support benefit, they are living at 10% below subsistence level and they are not entitled to other benefits normally allowed those on full income support.

They receive £105 a week out of which they pay water rates, gas, electricity and laundry bills, and bus fares to school.

It leaves just £50 a week for food and clothing.

The charity stepped in provide cash for compulsory school uniforms, without which the children would not have been able to attend lessons and continue their education.

Ms Dent said: "Sadly, this case is typical. We are hearing so many stories about asylum seekers living in severe poverty here and it's difficult keeping track of all the cases.

"This Iraqi family were struggling but by refugee standards were fortunate. Normally, most refugees live on 70% of the income support rate, barely enough to survive on. It is not as if they have a choice. Many families, like these Iraqis, cannot go back to their country because they would be killed.

"While there is never going to be enough money given by Guardian readers or other organisations to deal with such issues, we feel we can provide some help to tackle these ongoing problems."

(Family Welfare Association: 0207 2546251)

webTitle: Ceaseless quest of King Rat's father

fields.headline: Ceaseless quest of King Rat's father
fields.standfirst:
Three years on, David Wright still seeks to fathom his son's jail killing
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Three years on, David Wright still seeks to fathom his son's jail killing
fields.body:
Billy "King Rat" Wright struck terror into the heart of mid-Ulster as one of Northern Ireland's most ruthless loyalist paramilitaries.

Now, three years after republicans gunned him down in a high security jail, his father, David, ironically finds himself in a similar position to several nationalist families, battling for inquiries into murders they suspect the state might have played a part in.

The government has admitted there were serious security lapses in the Maze prison on the day Wright was killed, but strenuously denied there was collusion.

Lagan Valley Ulster Unionist MP Jeffrey Donaldson has also called for an immediate inquiry into thekilling. He said: "The murder of Billy Wright had the potential to up-end the entire peace process. It is essential something like this never happens again inside a prison.

"We need answers to many unresolved questions, both so that the Wright family can learn the truth and so the public interest can be served. There should be an independent inquiry

"My interest in this issue is not in terms of an interest in paramilitarism but I am concerned about the circumstances of this murder in the Maze, in my constituency."

Wright's father has vowed to fight for answers to his questions: "I will not rest until I get a full inquiry into the death of my son. He was murdered while under the care of the state."

On one wall of the neat living room in David Wright's tiny, red-brick terrace house is a faded, framed newspaper article about his father Billy's shoe shop and antique business, which begins: "The name of Wright is one that holds an honoured tradition in Portadown."

From another wall, a colour photograph of a tough-looking, intense, young man with close-cropped hair and a checked shirt, stares down. This young man, named Billy after his grandfather, was also well known in mid-Ulster, although infamous would be a better description.

Sentence

Billy Wright was shot dead by the Irish National Liberation Army in the Maze on December 271997 where he was serving an eight-year sentence for threatening to kill a woman.

Security sources claim that Wright, 37, once the local Ulster Volunteer Force leader and later boss of the breakaway Loyalist Volunteer faction, was behind up to 20 brutal murders, although he was never convicted of any.

"He put the fear of God into people," said one man. "There is no doubt that as a UVF leader he was blooded in violence but it is difficult to separate the myth from the reality. A King Rat lookalike only had to be spotted somewhere for republicans to go to ground for three weeks."

Later, his high profile, hard-line stance in support of the Drumcree Orangemen in their quest to march down Portadown's mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road led to a meeting with Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, and Democratic Unionist Willie McCrea appeared alongside him at a protest rally when he was expelled from the UVF. Republicans condemn him as a fanatic, out to exterminate anyone opposed to his cause. But many loyalists, for whom he remains an icon, his image tattooed on countless chests, insist he did not hate Roman Catholics, only republicans.

Controversy dogged his life and death and questions continue to haunt his pensioner father, an articulate, courteous man with no paramilitary connections, who will never be shaken from his belief that the state conspired to get rid of his son because he was a "problem" to the peace process.

Why were three members of the INLA, among the LVF's most deadly enemies, housed in the same block, albeit in separate wings? How did they know Wright would be in the prison yard that morning, waiting in a van to be taken to the visiting area?

How did they manage to smuggle guns into one of Europe's most secure jails, cut a 2ft by 2ft hole in the fence, and squeeze through it undetected by prison guards?

Why was a crucial video camera not working and a security guard inexplicably called away from an overlooking watchtower in the vital moments before Christopher "Crip" McWilliams pumped seven bullets into Wright?

Even after Wright's death, the killing went on. A total of 10 people died in an orgy of tit-for-tat violence in the following few weeks.

"Two wrongs don't make a right," said his father. "I never slept for months. I just prayed, 'Please God, make it stop'."

Three years later, the peace process more secure even if the political institutions are still under serious strain, David Wright is still searching for answers.

How did a boy from a respectable family and with "a brain well above street level", as his father puts it, end up one of the country's most notorious paramilitaries?

webTitle: South MPs warn of 'prosperity crisis' as more jobs force up home prices

fields.headline: South MPs warn of 'prosperity crisis' as more jobs force up home prices
fields.standfirst: Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: Labour MPs in southern England have started lobbying government ministers to stop creating new jobs in their constituencies, warning of a crisis in prosperity.
fields.body:
Labour MPs in southern England have started lobbying government ministers to stop creating new jobs in their constituencies, warning of a crisis in prosperity.

The lobbying has centred on the Thames Valley corridor where demand is pushing up house prices and leading to hundreds of vacancies in key public sector jobs, such as teaching, nursing, policing and bus driving.

MPs report an increasing number of complaints from constituents about a crisis of prosperity, including trans port congestion, massive public sector recruitment problems and excessive housebuilding.

Thames Valley MPs are opposing new investments until more is done to ease the cost of housing.

News that southern MPs are lobbying against extra jobs has surprised ministers, such as the environment minister, Chris Mullin, representing northern cities blighted by joblessness and boarded-up unsaleable homes.

It has also strengthened the hand of ministers, including the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who are pressing for Labour's election man ifesto to contain a clear commitment to a stronger regional policy.

Mr Prescott wants the manifesto to promise to set up elected regional assemblies in areas where there is clear local support for them.

House prices have more than doubled in less than four years in parts of the Thames Valley. Two-bedroom terraced properties are selling for £120,000, far beyond the means of most public sector workers on a salary of £20,000 or £22,000.

The crisis in house prices and travel congestion has already led Jane Griffiths, Labour MP for Reading East to oppose the Meteorological Office relocating to her constituency from nearby Bracknell. She told MPs last week: "We do not need those jobs. New jobs that come into the local area do not necessarily bring benefits with them".

Martin Salter, the neighbouring MP for Reading West said yesterday: "I am deeply worried that when Cisco Systems moves to the area with 5,500 jobs where the company will find the labour and what it will do regional house prices.

"Companies are buying up whole streets of terraced properties for executive homes.

"We are confronting nega tive unemployment along the Thames Valley corridor.

"The labour shortage is so great that corner shops are paying £6 an hour and the local Burger King is offering £5.85 an hour, the equivalent of a semi-skilled job in the North".

David Rendel, the Liberal Democrat MP for Newbury has echoed these fears, pointing out that by the time the new Vodaphone headquarters in his constituency is completed there will be 14,000 more jobs in West Berkshire than people to do the jobs.

Latest projections suggest employment demand is likely to increase by a further 6% by 2006 in the south east, especially in high tech, highly skilled jobs.

Ms Griffiths warned of a possible nightmare scenario in which schools work only a four day week, the streets remain unpoliced, patients lie on trollies for lack of nurses and there are no buses for lack of bus drivers.

Ms Griffiths and Mr Salter claim the crisis is such that the local council is offering to put teachers up in temporary accommodation. Ms Griffiths has received repeated letters from head teachers complaining they are unable to find sufficient numbers of primary school staff, most of them cit ing the lack of affordable housing. Figures by the Royal College of Nursing show the three month vacancy rate has risen by 30% - almost one third - in the south east. She also claimed that some firefighters are travelling from as far as Dorset to work in Reading.

The excess congestion is also forcing public sector bus companies to reduce the number of journeys by as much as 10%. Southern bus firms are in a wages war to retain staff.

Ministers hope this month's £250m starter homes initiative for as many as 10,000 key workers will ease the housing crisis. Rendel has warned that the plan may as help as few as 14 key workers per constituency per year.

Regional MPs are also lobbying the Home Office to give local police forces greater discretion in the use of extra government money designed to boost recruitment.

The Home Office has insisted the money earmarked in a new crime fighting fund must be used solely for salaries, but local MPs want some of the money to be siphoned off to help police buy homes. The proposal has the support of the Berkshire police, but has so far been vetoed by the Home Office.

webTitle: The rock art from 6,000 years ago

fields.headline: The rock art from 6,000 years ago
fields.standfirst: British archaeologists uncover 'the Sistine Chapel of predynastic Egypt' at 30 sites in the desert east of the Nile
fields.trailText: British archaeologists uncover 'the Sistine Chapel of predynastic Egypt' at 30 sites in the desert east of the Nile.
fields.body:
Discoveries that open a new window on the prehistory of ancient Egypt have been made by British archaeologists who have found 30 sites rich in art chiselled into rocks up to 6,000 years ago in the desert east of the Nile.

The rock drawings show cattle, boats, ostriches, giraffes, hippos and the men and women who lived in the area in 4,000BC, long before the first pharaohs, or the first pyramids.

"It's the Sistine Chapel of predynastic Egypt. It's amazing," said Toby Wilkinson, of Christ's College, Cambridge, who led the Eastern Desert Survey this month. "What this does is open up a completely new chapter in the study of Egyptian civilisation and its origins."

Ancient Egypt was always a puzzle. The civilisation appeared to archaeologists to have sprung up as a succession of dynasties of master-builders along a ribbon of fertile land on either side of the river Nile.

Even to the ancient Greeks, the Sphinx and the pyramids seemed to have always been there. The challenge has been to identify the origins of settlement on the Nile.

Egyptologists now think that the forefathers of the pyramid builders could be the same people who left their signatures on stones in the desert 6,000 years ago.

"Some of it is quite breathtaking," Dr Wilkinson said. "It is very difficult to date precisely, but looking at the stylistic parallels, a lot of this art has got to be from around 4,000BC. That is pretty old - and some of it is even older.

"Looking at the striking similarities between the rock art pictures and the painted pottery from the same period in the Nile valley, it is pretty clear that the same people were producing both."

In the 1930s, a German scientist began examining evidence of ancient human activity in the desert between the Nile and the Red sea, but the second world war interrupted the work. The origins of Egyptian civilisation began to emerge as a hot academic topic in the 1970s. More recently, British teams began to look systematically at the eastern desert.

"Until the last two or three years, people had been looking entirely in the Nile valley, and people had never really considered that there might be a vast treasurehouse of information out there in what is now desert, because it is so inhospitable and inaccessible today," Dr Wilkinson said.

"People hadn't stopped to think that it might have been rather different thousands of years ago."

Egypt began to turn to desert in about 3,500BC. Until then, the landscape would have been much like the present east African savannah, with waterholes and seasonal rivers, and with much the same fauna.

Dr Wilkinson and his colleagues - some of them amateurs who joined the team as part of an adventure holiday to finance the research - began exploring a section of desert between two major roads, the Wadi Hammamat and the Wadi Barramiya.

"Pretty much everywhere we have looked we found a plethora of rock art sites," he said. "A couple of weeks ago, we found more than 30 new sites that had never been recorded or mentioned before.

"Sites can vary in size from a boulder with a few animals or boats pecked on it to a vast area of cliff face dotted with pictures of people and animals, hunting scenes, flotillas of boats and giraffes, ostriches and elephants."

Wadis are ancient riverbeds that now serve as channels for periodic flash floods, and ancient travellers would have stayed close to them. About 20 of the new rock sites are at a wadi called Umm Salam. Some bear the graffiti of generations.

The team found evidence of Bedouin, Roman and Greek markings, and of travellers who went that way in the era of the pharaohs. But the most dramatic were pictures that told a story of an unknown pastoral people, driving their cattle from one watering place to another, between the Nile valley and the Red sea.

Some of the boats chiselled into the rocks are fairly simple. Some seem to have religious significance. They show figures with large plumes in their hair, like the later gods of Egypt. Some of the boats are being dragged - an image that recurs in the tombs in the Valley of the Kings. Some of the figures depicted are clearly chiefs, wearing what might be ostrich feathers.

There has always been evidence of prehistoric commercial traffic in the region. Coral, sea shells and obsidian - a black volcanic glass - came to the Nile from the Red sea. But the picture that emerges is of an indigenous nomadic people, moving from place to place according to season with their cattle, who may have been forced to settle as the land around them began to parch.

"There is a lovely little scene of seven women dancing, holding hands," Dr Wilkinson said. "They seem to have skirts on, but in general the figures are quite rudimentary. We think of Egypt today as just a narrow strip on either side of the Nile valley. We are going to have to rethink our idea of the extent of Egypt, 7,000 or 6,000 years ago. It wasn't just the Nile valley, it was this vast area on either side which was able to support life.

"These people moved out of the savannahs into the Nile valley and settled there, and this is what kickstarted Egyptian civilisation."

Countdown to civilisation

8,000 BC First clay tokens used to record livestock and grain in Mesopotamia

7,000 BC First mortar used with sun-dried brick in Jericho; cloth is woven in Turkey

6,000 BC Wheat grown for bread in south-west Asia

5,000 BC The horse is domesticated in Ukraine

4,000 BC The Sumerians build Ur in Mesopotamia

3,500 BC Minoan civilisation begins in Crete, and the first hieroglyphs are used in Egypt

3,000 BC The Babylonians predict eclipses

2,700 BC The Great Pyramid of Giza is built for the pharaoh Cheops

500 BC Athenian civilisation begins

Some of the boats chiselled into the rocks are fairly simple. Some seem to have religious significance. They show figures with large plumes in their hair, like the later gods of Egypt. Some of the boats are being dragged - an image that recurs in the tombs in the Valley of the Kings. Some of the figures depicted are clearly chiefs, wearing what might be ostrich feathers. There has always been evidence of prehistoric commercial traffic in the region. Coral, sea shells and obsidian - a black volcanic glass - came to the Nile from the Red sea. But the picture that emerges is of an indigenous nomadic people, moving from place to place according to season with their cattle, who may have been forced to settle as the land around them began to parch. "There is a lovely little scene of seven women dancing, holding hands," Dr Wilkinson said. "They seem to have skirts on, but in general the figures are quite rudimentary. We think of Egypt today as just a narrow strip on either side of the Nile valley. We are going to have to rethink our idea of the extent of Egypt, 7,000 or 6,000 years ago. It wasn't just the Nile valley, it was this vast area on either side which was able to support life. "These people moved out of the savannahs into the Nile valley and settled there, and this is what kickstarted Egyptian civilisation." webTitle: 1,000 jobs plan to put rail back on track

fields.headline: 1,000 jobs plan to put rail back on track
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack is to recruit 1,000 extra staff as part of its efforts to get services back to normal after the Hatfield crash, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Railtrack is to recruit 1,000 extra staff as part of its efforts to get services back to normal after the Hatfield crash, it was revealed yesterday.

The company is looking for 700 signallers and 300 engineers to help Britain's railways climb out of crisis. The announcement comes as 8,000 employees were last night working to replace 25 miles of track and points at 60 sites.

Transport minister Lord Macdonald inspected a railway engineering site yesterday as Railtrack announced its recruitment drive, which in addition to boosting the effort to return services to normal, aims to restore public confidence in the rail network.

Under the scheme Railtrack will attempt to lure back engineers who have taken early retirement and whose expertise could be vital when it comes to rebuilding the network. School leavers, graduates, people returning from a career break and professional engineers will also be targeted.

Lord Macdonald visited the Waterloo to Bournemouth main line at Wimbledon in south west London, where gangs have been working round the clock since Saturday to replace more than half a mile of track.

Railtrack chief executive Steve Marshall said the company expects 85% of services to be back to normal by the time the January 29 emergency timetable is published.

Lord Macdonald welcomed the announcement, saying: "I am delighted that Railtrack are taking such a positive approach and showing that they are prepared, in the context of a 10-year investment plan, that they can hire and train the kind of skills they need."

The 300 engineering jobs are a direct result of the crisis sparked by Hatfield. As the 50-strong team started their fourth day of repairs at Wimbledon, Lord Macdonald added: "We have got to rebuild the railway's skilled workforce. Where there has been fragmentation we are working to try to bring coherence.

"And where there's been neglect we intend to bring in vestment of nearly £50bn over the next 10 years.I have been telling the workers here that if they are looking for a career in rail construction it's one they can be assured of for the next 10 years."

But Mr Marshall said the majority of the 1,000 new jobs - the 700 signalmen's posts - are in response to changes in working practices and negotiations with trade unions.

Phil Wilks of the Rail Passengers Council welcomed the news, saying public confidence was at "rock bottom".

"The sooner they get them in and trained and get services back to normal the better, as patience wore out long ago."

Mr Wilks said the Christmas rail services appeared to have been a lot better than people feared. While passengers were correct to say that the intensive work programme was overdue thanks to 20 years of underinvestment, the Railtrack chief said: "The important thing is that we are catching up."

webTitle: Courts fight shy of 'three strikes'

fields.headline: Courts fight shy of 'three strikes'
fields.standfirst:
'Get tough' sentencing policy left on back burner

Special report: Policing crime
fields.trailText: 'Get tough' sentencing policy left on back burner.
fields.body:
The courts have yet to use their powers to imprison a persistent burglar under the home secretary's controversial "three strikes and you're out" mandatory sentence.

Home Office figures demonstrate that the courts have failed to embrace a range of law and order initiatives introduced over the past 18 months. The police and local authorities have also not yet used a child curfew order since the changes.

Recent parliamentary questions confirm that the courts, like the police, have failed to use their powers to impose mandatory three-year sentences on persistent burglars, or to issue a child safety order, a measure that is similar to a curfew but involves a single named child.

Only four convicted drug dealers have received a statutory mandatory seven-year sentence for a second trafficking offence since the rule was introduced in October 1997.

Mr Straw's anti-social behaviour orders, designed to tackle the problem of "neighbours from hell", have been a little more successful, with 140 orders made by the courts from the time the orders were introduced in April last year until the end of October. The much trumpeted "parenting orders" are also beginning to take off and the courts have made more than 400 such orders during the past six months.

Some government measures aimed at tackling juvenile crime have been more successful, too. Reparation orders - under which the child offender has to make some kind of restitution to the victim - have been used 2,148 times, and action plan orders - which set out a programme of community service and conditions - used 2,408 times.

The most popular measures with the courts were orders that were improved versions of long-standing sentences used by magistrates. There have been more than 18,000 supervision orders, and more than 2,000 detention and training orders under which juveniles are sent to secure units and young offenders' institutions.

But most party political interest is likely to focus on the failure of the courts to embrace the "three strikes and you're out" law with regard to burglars. This measure was put on the statute book by the last Conservative home secretary, Michael Howard. The present home secretary, Mr Straw, said it would only be implemented when there was sufficient prison space to house extra inmates.

The National Association of Probation Officers has calculated that thousands of burglars could be imprisoned when the courts start to use the "three strikes" policy. Napo estimates that by 2004 about 8,000 offenders will have been convicted of three house break-ins and so will face the automatic three-year jail term.

It is believed that the courts' failure to use the new mandatory sentence stems largely from the limited discretion they have in avoiding imposing it in cases where it would be "unjust in all the circumstances". It may also be due to delays in the courts which have meant that few burglars have been convicted three times in the past year since the authorities began using the new power.

Harry Fletcher, of Napo, said: "We are pleased that the courts are exercising their discretion, otherwise Britain's jails would not be able to cope.

"The previous records of those on probation suggest that if the provision for three strikes were implemented in every case, the jail population would rise by nearly 5,000 over a full year. At the moment the prison population stands at 64,075."

webTitle: Troops on streets in Indonesia as churches burn

fields.headline: Troops on streets in Indonesia as churches burn
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of Indonesian troops and police mobilised after a Christmas Eve bombing spree killed at least 15 people and injured almost 100 failed to prevent an attack on a church in central Java yesterday.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of Indonesian troops and police mobilised after a Christmas Eve bombing spree killed at least 15 people and injured almost 100 failed to prevent an attack on a church in central Java yesterday.

Fear that the blasts aimed at churches and priests would provoke revenge attacks when the majority Muslim population began celebrating the end of Ramadan yesterday proved groundless.

But millions of people ignored their religious leaders' calls for quiet celebrations and held huge noisy parties.

Against rising speculation about who was responsible for the 15 explosions, mostly within 30 minutes, in nine cities in Java and Sumatra, Vice-President Megawati Sukarnoputri said the motive was political, not religious.

A caretaker at the Catholic church of St John the Evangelist in Kudus, 150 miles south-east of Jakarta, returned from a short lunch break yesterday to find the vestry alight.

He managed to extinguish the blaze before it caused more damage.

"There's no way this could have been an accident," a local church source said. "It is clearly part of this wider campaign to spread fear through shameful terror."

The senior security minister, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, said that the police, supported by soldiers, would remain on the highest state of alert until after the New Year's Eve celebrations.

At least 14,000 police reinforcements were on the streets of Jakarta yesterday searching everyone entering the main mosques for Eid al-Fitr prayers.

In London, the Foreign Office minister John Battle wrote to President Abdurrahman Wahid, saying the people of the UK "shared your sense of outrage at the [bombings]."

It is widely thought that the perpetrators are trying to discredit and eventually topple Mr Wahid, who has gone on national television to appeal for calm.

He has said he will not be bullied by acts of terrorism.

Two people were arrested in the Javanese city of Bandung after a device they were preparing exploded prematurely, but the police say they have few concrete leads.

But the head of the forensics department said that two bombs found in Jakarta and defused were proved to be almost identical

webTitle: Widdecombe clashes with Tory rival on police pledge

fields.headline: Widdecombe clashes with Tory rival on police pledge
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe yesterday clashed with a potential rival for the Conservative leadership, David Davis, when she said huge difficulties stood in the way of his plan for 30,000 extra police
fields.body:
The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, yesterday clashed with a potential rival for the Conservative leadership, David Davis, when she said huge difficulties stood in the way of his plan for 30,000 extra police over eight years.

Mr Davis, chairman of the powerful Commons public accounts committee, is seen as a potential rival to Ms Widdecombe for votes from the centre and right of his party if Wiliam Hague steps down after the general election.

The intervention by Mr Davis in the crime debate came as the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, again warned that pressure on resources was leading to police being transferred to white collar desk work.

Sir John warned that the Met would be short of 1,000 civilians by February, with the total number of uniformed officers down by 2,500 from six years ago.

Officers were being pulled off the beat to answer emergency calls and carry out administrative tasks.

"We have had to take 200 officers off the street to do office duties and deal with things like 999 calls to ensure we provide a proper service, and that really is not on," said Sir John.

He also appeared to echo some of the criticisms made by Mr Hague of the Macpherson report into the Metropolitan police, which were reignited by the death of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor.

"In any organisation that's been the first in this country to be found guilty of institutionalised racism - whatever that means in the Macpherson test - of course people are going to be bruised," Sir John said.

Ms Widdecombe said the commissioner's comment "fully vindicates William Hague's position and it's a terrible indictment of this government's handling of law and order".

However, she also found herself in the unusual position of being outflanked from the right within her own party when Mr Davis called for 30,000 extra police at an extra cost of £2bn per annum by the eighth year, which he said were "quite small numbers in terms of our overall spending".

Mr Davis described Ms Widdecombe's commitment to restore the 3,000 police officers lost under Labour as the work of a year or two, adding: "We need to go much further and I think many members of the Conservative party would agree."

In an implicit criticism of the party leadership, he said the Conservatives were fighting only on the centre ground on crime and it was time to move on.

Ms Widdecombe has so far been only permitted by the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, to promise not to cut the budget for the police.

She said yesterday the reversal of decline was "a first step. When you are making a clear commitment to the general public you need to make a commitment you know you can produce and produce quickly. We have never said we shall stop when we have reversed the numbers."

Ms Widdecombe said that apart from the problem of cost, there was no point setting a numerical target regardless of the quality or the history of recruits.

"No chief constable would support that", she said. "There will be huge difficulties in the way, and I will make it my business always to promise only what we can deliver."

webTitle: Reheated turkey a health risk

fields.headline: Reheated turkey a health risk
fields.trailText: Eating reheated Christmas turkey could damage your health, a food poisoning expert has warned. The number of reported food poisoning cases goes up every December.
fields.body:
Eating reheated Christmas turkey could damage your health, a food poisoning expert has warned. The number of reported food poisoning cases goes up every December.

Sarah O'Brien, from the Public Health Laboratory Service (PHLS) in London, said the health risk was caused by people buying bigger birds than they needed and continuing to serve up turkey for days after Christmas is over.

Most casualties fell victim to salmonella or another food bug called Clostridium perfringens.

Dr O'Brien said: "Clostridium tends to be linked with cooling and reheating either meat or gravy.

"If you're continually cooling and reheating things your chance of making someone ill with Clostridium perfringens is quite high."

Two increases were regularly seen in food poisoning statistics, one in summer - caused by food being left out in warm temperatures - and the other in December.

Of the 200 to 300 infection outbreaks associated with poultry reported to the PHLS each year, between 50 and 70 occurred in December, said Dr O'Brien.

She said it was very important to leave enough time for a frozen turkey to thaw thoroughly before cooking.

The best advice was to follow the supplier's guidelines. "If you follow the instructions supplied by the supermarket carefully, that should reduce your risk," she added. Press Association

webTitle: Jailed drug Britons arrive home

fields.headline: Jailed drug Britons arrive home
fields.standfirst: Pair freed after two years in Middle East tell of appalling conditions
fields.trailText: Pair freed after two years in Middle East tell of appalling conditions
fields.body:
Two Britons who endured more than two years jailed in what they said were dreadful conditions in the United Arab Emirates after being caught with a small amount of cannabis arrived home yesterday having been pardoned.

Head teacher Lynn Majakas and social worker Ian Bamling flew back from Abu Dhabi to Heathrow airport for an emotional reunion with their families.

With tears streaming down her face, Ms Majakas, 45, continued to protest her innocence. Her friend Mr Bamling, 31, said: "After two years and two months in inhumane conditions I want to go and sleep and spend some time with my family."

The pair, who were next door neighbours in west London, were arrested at Abu Dhabi in October 1998 at the start of what was meant to be a relaxing cut-price holiday in the sun as officials stopped Ms Majakas as she walked through the airport smoking a rolled-up cigarette.

Officials examined the cigarette but found no drugs in it. When they searched her luggage, however, they found three grams of cannabis in a camera case. Mr Bamling was also arrested when he intervened.

Despite a sworn statement from a friend claiming the drugs were his and they knew nothing of them, they were jailed for four and a half years. They were granted a pardon as an act of clemency to mark the end of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

Ms Majakas said: "I've done two years and two months for something I didn't do." Speaking of the inmates left behind she said: "There were 145 of us on that floor. I didn't want to leave any of them there - I wanted to bring them all back with me. There were some lovely, lovely people. They are all so pleased I've been pardoned.

"We were all sitting there throughout Ramadan waiting to find out who was going to be released. We began to wonder and we thought no one was going to get out. Then I was called to the manager's office. I thought: 'I haven't done any thing wrong'. He said: 'You're getting out'. I haven't slept since then."

A gaunt-looking Mr Bamling said: "It's like a dream come true. I'm overwhelmed. I haven't slept for 48 hours." He hugged his brother Robert, and cradled his five-year-old niece Charlotte in his arms.

The conditions the pair were held in were terrible, they said. Soon after their arrest they had their heads shaved and were forced to wear dirty prison smocks and sleep on concrete floors with a rag as a blanket.

Mr Bamling said he and his fellow inmates were treated like "caged animals" in a "hell on earth". He heard men being beaten in the night and could not get their screams out of his head. Taking three tranquillisers a day was the only thing which kept him sane, he said.

He said he was fed "disgusting mutton slop" and pitta bread. Within a few weeks he lost a stone. He was denied soap, toothpaste and razors and gave up trying to wash because the facilities were so squalid.

Mr Bamling said he had been amazed at some of the offences fellow prisoners had been jailed for. One told him he was being held without being charged because he had washed his car in the street in contravention of a by-law.

Ms Majakas, daughter of a vicar and former head of Bedelsford special needs school in Kingston upon Thames, south-west London, had to wash in showers which doubled as toilets.

She spent much of her time with three or four prisoners in a small cell designed for one and infested with cockroaches.

Families of the pair campaigned vigorously for their release. They asked Prince Charles to plead their case when he visited the UAE.

Mr Bamling's father, Robert, flew out in October to try to win their release but was not able to meet the Sheik of Abu Dhabi as he was recuperating from an operation. On his return he reported that his son was kept in a cell with 11 other inmates.

At one point Mr Bamling threatened to go on hunger strike if he was not released. On another occasion his family said he was so depressed that they feared he might commit suicide.

He was denied soap, toothpaste and razors and gave up trying to wash because the facilities were so squalid. Mr Bamling said he had been amazed at some of the offences fellow prisoners had been jailed for. One told him he was being held without being charged because he had washed his car in the street in contravention of a by-law. Ms Majakas, daughter of a vicar and former head of Bedelsford special needs school in Kingston upon Thames, south-west London, had to wash in showers which doubled as toilets. She spent much of her time with three or four prisoners in a small cell designed for one and infested with cockroaches. Families of the pair campaigned vigorously for their release. They asked Prince Charles to plead their case when he visited the UAE. Mr Bamling's father, Robert, flew out in October to try to win their release but was not able to meet the Sheik of Abu Dhabi as he was recuperating from an operation. On his return he reported that his son was kept in a cell with 11 other inmates. At one point Mr Bamling threatened to go on hunger strike if he was not released. On another occasion his family said he was so depressed that they feared he might commit suicide.

webTitle: Sperm donors face loss of privacy

fields.headline: Sperm donors face loss of privacy
fields.trailText: The government is about to relax strict rules of confidentiality protecting the identity of sperm donors to allow their children to discover key facts about their genetic origins.
fields.body:
The government is about to relax strict rules of confidentiality protecting the identity of sperm donors to allow their children to discover key facts about their genetic origins.

Yvette Cooper, the public health minister, will produce a consultation paper early in the new year which will spark a public debate on changing the regulations guarding the anonymity of people donating sperm, eggs or embryos.

She does not want children to have a right to learn the identity of their biological parents. Such a prospect would deter donors who might reasonably fear they could be pursued by large numbers of unknown offspring seeking emotional or financial support.

But the government will consult on a range of options that could allow the children of "gamete donors" to build up a picture of the biological parent's characteristics.

The least radical option would allow disclosure of non-identifiable information about the donor's background, education, occupation, interests and characteristics such as hair colour.

This option is likely to include details of the biological parent's racial background.

A second more far reaching option would extend to information that could come closer to identifying the donor, including medical history and family health records. Although this would not be a direct breach of anonymity, it might provide clues that could allow the child to track down a biological parent.

A third option will be to give the donor an opportunity to choose to provide a name and address at the time the donation is made that would be available to the child on request.

More than 11,000 children have been born by donor insemination since 1991 when the human fertilisation and embryology authority was set up to license fertility clinics and keep records of all sperm and egg donors.

Under present regulations children over 18 can be told - after appropriate counselling - whether or not they were conceived by donor insemination. The same applies to children over 16 who want to get married.

But in neither case can any information be given about the background or characteristics of the donor.

Ms Cooper will reassure past donors that there is no question of changing the law retrospectively and their anonymity will remain protected.

Doctors and infertility support groups are concerned that relaxation of the confidentiality rules could discourage potential donors, who are paid on average £15. But there is evidence of confusion and insecurity among children who have been told they were conceived by artificial insemination, but denied further information about their biological parent.

Liberty, the civil rights organisation, is bringing a test case under the Human Rights Act on behalf of a brother and sister conceived through donor sperm insemination demanding the right to know details of their father.

Adam and Jo Rose, now in their 30s, argue that the law banning disclosure of information about sperm donors is a breach of article 8, the right to respect for private and family life.

A Department of Health official said: "Our proposals are responding to an increase in numbers of gamete donors raising questions of whether people should have the right to know their genetic background. Ministers know this is a sensitive issue and we will need full consultation with interested parties and individuals."

webTitle: Dead air stowaways still unnamed

fields.headline: Dead air stowaways still unnamed
fields.trailText: Detectives were last night trying to identify a stowaway who died after plunging from a plane at Gatwick airport hours after the body of another stowaway was found nearby.
fields.body:
Detectives were last night trying to identify a stowaway who died after plunging from a plane at Gatwick airport hours after the body of another stowaway was found nearby.

The man who died on Christmas Day fell from the undercarriage of a British Airways jet just after it had taken off.

On Sunday evening, farm workers found the body of another man in a field. He is thought to have fallen from aplane as it came into land.

Monday's death was witnessed by an airport worker who saw the man falling after the pilot of the Boeing 777, destined for Cancun, Mexico, raised the landing gear.

Gatwick duty manager Michael Ingle said: "We received a phone call from one of the workers on the ground saying that he had seen an object fall from the plane. We sent an operations team to the hard shoulder of the runway and found the body of a young man. There is a police investigation underway and until that is completed, we will know very little."

The 9.15am flight, BA4503, continued without anyone realising what had happened. Police and ambulances were called to the scene and airport officials were forced to close the North Terminal's main runway delaying flights.

In some instances bodies have remained for several flights after becoming lodged in the undercarriage bay. Because the space is so small, the bodies can become jammed and tumble out several days later, dislodged by a bumpy landing or turbulence.

On most jets, the only way a flight deck sensor would show a problem was if the undercarriage failed to fully retract, suggesting an object had jammed it.

The other body, believed to be of a man aged between 18 and 20, was found on Sunday evening in an 80 acre field at Rudgwick, Surrey.

The man, described as white, of Mediterranean appearance with short black hair, is thought to have fallen several thousand feet as the plane he had stowed away on prepared to land.

Police said that the body could have been in the field for several days. "The probability is that he had sought refuge in the main landing gear bay of the plane," added a spokesman.

"Unfortunately, it is very unlikely anyone would survive because of the lack of oxygen and freezing temperatures at that altitude, around 35,000 feet. It is about minus 40 at that height. We think the victim was already dead and fell out over Rudgwick as the plane approached Gatwick airport and lowered its wheels."

There have been several attempts by suspected illegal immigrants to stow away on planes bound for Britain.

In October 1996, a couple in a pub garden spotted a body falling from a DC9 over Richmond, south-west London, as it approached Heathrow.

Vijay Saini, 19, fell 2,000 feet from the jet and was discovered three days later. A post mortem revealed that he was dead when he tumbled from the plane.

His brother Pardeep, 22, survived the 10 hour journey from Delhi in freezing temperatures. He was given compassionate leave to stay in Britain for a year after appealing to the Home Office.

webTitle: Get away from it all on Merlin's island retreat

fields.headline: Get away from it all on Merlin's island retreat
fields.standfirst: Tenancies on offer to 'professional castaways' willing to commit to 20 years on a Welsh coast outcrop
fields.trailText: Tenancies on offer to 'professional castaways' willing to commit to 20 years on a Welsh coast outcrop
fields.body:
Winters might be lonely with only the bones of 20,000 saints for company on the long, dark nights, and mainland Wales could seem a million unnavigable miles away across a storm battered sound. But for those in search of themselves - or perhaps of natural wonders or Celtic spirituality - Bardsey Island, just off Wales's Lleyn peninsula, could prove the ideal retreat from 21st century Britain.

The home of Merlin, King Arthur's resident wizard, the island now requires other tenants to share the 444-acre mix of rock and pasture with the floating population of basking seals, the passing dolphins, the 3,000 or so pairs of summertime Manx shearwaters, and the two live-in nuns.

Bardsey was bought by a trust in 1979 and by 1986 had become a national nature reserve famous for the variety of its flora. It has 280 varieties of lichen and in the summer attracts a regular flow of visitors, some of whom find themselves marooned when the weather turns nasty.

But a 300-year farming tradition ended when the last farmers left five years ago. Now the Bardsey Island Trust is anxious to find tenants of an adaptable and adventurous nature willing to commit the next 20 years of their lives to working and living on the island full-time.

Simon Glyn, the trust's director, said that the rewards for those desperate to escape the rat-race would far outweigh the difficulties of living on one of Europe's "most remote outposts". Tenants, he warned, would need to invest in a flock of sheep, a tractor, and fishing boat so as to be able to travel to the mainland. But there would be income from the land, and from bed and breakfast cottages and a summer-time cafe.

"We are looking for people to become professional castaways and we're going to offer them a 20-year lease," said Mr Glyn. "It could cost initially £25,000 or £30,000, but it is not a lot in one sense. There is so much there - the tranquillity and the peace are something else. The beauty of the island is something I can't describe. It's totally unspoiled.

"Whoever comes to the island will make a living, and if that person is enterprising, a comfortable living too. But I think it is the beauty of Bardsey which will attract the applicants."

Applications for tenancy will be invited in the new year and the successful will become the tenants of a 130-year-old farmhouse with three bedrooms and an open fire. Two cottages will be available for visiting friends and relatives.

Children will have a village school all to themselves, but unfortunately no teacher; the last teacher left in 1947. Local entertainment will include strolls to the lighthouse (built 1821) and to the island's 550ft summit which, on the occasional clear day, offers views of the Snowdon range and Ireland's Wicklow mountains.

The ruined 14th century Augustinian abbey of St Mary, originally founded by St Cadfan in 516, has long been a place of pilgrimage: three trips to Bardsey were the medieval equivalent of a trip to Rome. The incomers could evidently quickly stock up on spiritual wealth if not on worldly riches.

Christians still come to the island each summer for a week's stay that promises a "daily pattern of prayer, study, work, with times of solitude and silence". Their sojourn costs £290 full-board, including boat fares. One highlight is to watch the sun sink in the Irish Sea after compline.

If that does not appeal, the North Wales Radio Rally Club is intending to spend a week on the island, perhaps ensconced in the lighthouse, during August. Their break will cost just £100 and is being advertised as "a cheap week's holiday, playing radio".

Life on Bardsey, known in Welsh as Ynys Enlli ("the island in the tide race") could also have musical rewards. The island has had a long monarchist tradition and the present king is the celebrated Welsh baritone Bryn Terfel.

webTitle: Liverpool council try to end street soccer

fields.headline: Council's goal is to end street soccer
fields.trailText: Boys - and grown men - who kick footballs on street corners in Liverpool while dreaming of scoring the winner at Anfield or Goodison may soon be shown the red card.
fields.body:
Boys - and grown men - who kick footballs on street corners in Liverpool while dreaming of scoring the winner at Anfield or Goodison may soon be shown the red card.

New by-laws proposed by the Liberal Democrat-controlled city council would ban street football, the traditional nursery for soccer talent, from "roads, footways, forecourts or grassed areas".

Members of the community safety committee have ordered a report on how a ban could be implemented. But the move has already been condemned as "bureaucracy gone mad" by the former Liverpool skipper, Tommy Smith, who learnt his skills on the terraced streets of Kirkdale.

Councillors plan to open up school yards and create kick-about areas in public parks to children no longer able to play in the streets. "We get a constant stream of complaints from residents who are plagued by children playing football outside their homes," said Vera Best, a councillor. "It's often a source of very real hardship for people, who can be afraid to challenge rowdy gangs of teenagers. Sometimes there are even groups of men playing in the street. You can imagine the nightmare for pensioners who have balls kicked at their walls or windows at all hours of the day and night.

"There have been some very nasty cases of pensioners being intimidated. This is a very real problem and one we cannot simply ignore."

But Mr Smith, a former England international, said the proposals would damage professional and amateur soccer in Liverpool and prevent players of the talent of Robbie Fowler and Steve McMannaman from developing their skills.

"This is a crackpot idea, petty bureaucracy gone mad," he said. "The back streets of Liverpool are the real breeding ground for natural talent. It's no use saying all the kids can join clubs or schoolboy leagues - that happens as they get older."

webTitle: Blackout could speed Mir's end

fields.headline: Blackout could speed Mir's end
fields.standfirst:
Long power cut at doomed space station is still a mystery

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Radio contact was lost with the Russian space station Mir for 20 hours yesterday and Monday, prompting international alarm that the unmanned vessel could begin falling to earth.
fields.body:
Radio contact was lost with the Russian space station Mir for 20 hours yesterday and Monday, prompting international alarm that the unmanned vessel could begin falling to earth.

Engineers at Star City, just east of Moscow, managed to re-establish satellite contact yesterday afternoon - after what onlookers described as an extremely tense night.

The scare revived security concerns about the condemned station, which has had such a catalogue of problems throughout its 14-year life that it has become known as Starship Lada, after Russia's undependable Lada automobile.

In recent years the problems have become so persistent that the head of the Russian aerospace agency got government approval in November to ditch the space station because experts had become so uncertain about its safety. "We cannot continue this game... which I call Russian roulette," Yury Koptev said at the time.

Mir was due to be dropped into the Pacific about 1,000 miles east of Australia at the end of February, but yesterday's communications blackout led to speculation last night that termination of the space station might be brought forward.

Contact with Mir was lost after Star City's evening linkup with onboard computers at 6.40pm Moscow time on Monday. Successive attempts to restore the link on Monday night failed, and the space agency admitted the problem late yesterday morning.

The potential for danger was considerable: when regular contact with the ship is lost, its solar panels begin to lose alignment with the sun, causing a power shortage. Eventually this would freeze its systems and send it into a chaotic rotating descent.

After 20 hours of repeated attempts, contact was re-established soon after 3.00pm yesterday.

To calm public anxiety, the head of Mission Control, Vladimir Solovyov, announced: "Mir will not fall on your head on New Year's Eve. The latest communications session showed that we are controlling events, not the other way around."

Mr Solovyov said the station's batteries had somehow lost nearly all their power, leaving too little energy for Mir to communicate. But it was not clear what had caused the power shortage.

Trying to fix the breakdown, controllers switched off energy-consuming systems, such as the temperature controls, so the remaining energy could be conserved for communications with earth.

A disabled spacecraft falling out of orbit and crashing to earth is not without precedent. A Soviet satellite crashed into northern Canada in 1978 - injuring no one, but scattering radioactive debris across the tundra; the following year, the unmanned American Skylab space station shattered into pieces over western Australia when it dropped unexpectedly and swiftly out of orbit.

The 14-year-old Mir was designed to last for three to five years. Its problems in recent times have included a serious fire and a near fatal collision with a cargo ship in 1997.

An ambitious project to save the station by turning it into a profit-making business and an exclusive tourist resort failed earlier this year, after only one investor emerged willing to pay the $20m (£13.5m) asking price for a ticket.

webTitle: Landslide victory for Serb reformers

fields.headline: Landslide victory for Serb reformers
fields.standfirst:
Democratic Opposition routs Milosevic's Socialists to face an ailing economy and high public expectations

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Reformers have won a landslide victory in Serbia, giving them a strong mandate to deal with the collapsed economy and tackle corrupt state machinery.
fields.body:
Reformers have won a landslide victory in Serbia, giving them a strong mandate to deal with the collapsed economy and tackle corrupt state machinery.

"This is the most convincing victory in the history of the Serbian parliament and will be hard to repeat," said Cedomir Jovanovic, senior aide to the prime minister-designate, Zoran Djindjic.

Although the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS) coalition government led by Mr Djindjic is now on track to win 176 seats in the 250-seat parliament - the Socialist party has just 37 - it must satisfy high expectations and address complex problems.

The Serbian Unity party founded by the murdered paramilitary Zeljko Raznatovic, known as Arkan, captured 14 seats, shocking analysts.

Topping the political agenda is the role of Kosovo and Montenegro in the Yugoslavian federation, and the infiltration of Albanian separatists in southern Serbia.

Montenegro wants its own seat at the United Nations, external recognition of its government, and then talks on some kind of alliance with Belgrade.

On the social and economic front, the immediate concern is the lack of electricity. The day after Serbia went to the polls, prolonged power cuts plunged homes and factories into darkness for up to eight hours.

The new government's other priorities, Mr Jovanovic said, were rapid social reform, and legislation to define the principal responsibility of "politicians who are in power now or who recently held power".

Two top military allies of the former president Slobodan Milosevic - General Milorad Obradovic and Admiral Milan Zec - were sacked yesterday. Both were linked to the aggressive Milosevic policy in Montenegro, which many feared would lead to war.

By dismissing them, DOS leaders aim to appease the pro-independence president of Montenegro, Milo Djukanovic. They have also sought to ease tension in Montenegro by promising to disband a reviled special military police unit.

Although many fear that the new Serbian regime may be as corrupt as the last, the wheels of justice have begun to turn against Mr Milosevic.

At the weekend Mr Djindjic said that he expected an investigation of the former president to begin next month. A Centre for Policy Studies survey found that 32% of people wanted Mr Milosevic tried for election fraud and corruption, and 41% wanted him tried for war crimes as well.

The time available to solve such long-term problems is limited, and some fear that the long-standing rivalry between President Vojislav Kostunica and Mr Djindjic may burst into the open now that the elections are over.

Mr Djindjic wants rapid reform and a far-reaching purge of the Milosevic "kleptocracy", while Mr Kostunica is seeking a more gradual approach. Many predict such pressures could split the coalition within six to eight months.

Projected results based on 98% of votes counted:

Democratic Opposition of Serbia (Vojislav Kostunica)
Seats: 176 (64% of vote)

Socialist Party of Serbia (Slobodan Milosevic)
Seats: 37 (14% of vote)

fields.bodyText: Reformers have won a landslide victory in Serbia, giving them a strong mandate to deal with the collapsed economy and tackle corrupt state machinery. "This is the most convincing victory in the history of the Serbian parliament and will be hard to repeat," said Cedomir Jovanovic, senior aide to the prime minister-designate, Zoran Djindjic. Although the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS) coalition government led by Mr Djindjic is now on track to win 176 seats in the 250-seat parliament - the Socialist party has just 37 - it must satisfy high expectations and address complex problems. The Serbian Unity party founded by the murdered paramilitary Zeljko Raznatovic, known as Arkan, captured 14 seats, shocking analysts. Topping the political agenda is the role of Kosovo and Montenegro in the Yugoslavian federation, and the infiltration of Albanian separatists in southern Serbia. Montenegro wants its own seat at the United Nations, external recognition of its government, and then talks on some kind of alliance with Belgrade. On the social and economic front, the immediate concern is the lack of electricity. The day after Serbia went to the polls, prolonged power cuts plunged homes and factories into darkness for up to eight hours. The new government's other priorities, Mr Jovanovic said, were rapid social reform, and legislation to define the principal responsibility of "politicians who are in power now or who recently held power". Two top military allies of the former president Slobodan Milosevic - General Milorad Obradovic and Admiral Milan Zec - were sacked yesterday. Both were linked to the aggressive Milosevic policy in Montenegro, which many feared would lead to war. By dismissing them, DOS leaders aim to appease the pro-independence president of Montenegro, Milo Djukanovic. They have also sought to ease tension in Montenegro by promising to disband a reviled special military police unit. Although many fear that the new Serbian regime may be as corrupt as the last, the wheels of justice have begun to turn against Mr Milosevic. At the weekend Mr Djindjic said that he expected an investigation of the former president to begin next month. A Centre for Policy Studies survey found that 32% of people wanted Mr Milosevic tried for election fraud and corruption, and 41% wanted him tried for war crimes as well. The time available to solve such long-term problems is limited, and some fear that the long-standing rivalry between President Vojislav Kostunica and Mr Djindjic may burst into the open now that the elections are over. Mr Djindjic wants rapid reform and a far-reaching purge of the Milosevic "kleptocracy", while Mr Kostunica is seeking a more gradual approach. Many predict such pressures could split the coalition within six to eight months. webTitle: France forced to free 'Jackal's ally'

fields.headline: France forced to free 'Jackal's ally'
fields.trailText: A new law limiting the length of time suspects can be held without trial has forced France to release from jail a woman suspected of being a leading accomplice of the convicted terrorist Carlos the Jackal.
fields.body:
A new law limiting the length of time suspects can be held without trial has forced France to release from jail a woman suspected of being a leading accomplice of the convicted terrorist Carlos the Jackal.

Judicial sources said that Christa-Margot Frohlich, imprisoned in 1996 after extradition from Italy, was freed last week under the law, which comes into force on January 1. It says suspects cannot be held for longer than four years without facing trial.

She must report regularly to the police and, according to her lawyers, has promised not to try to leave the country - the overriding fear of France's leading anti-terrorist magistrate, Jean-Louis Bruguière, who has warned that Germany never extradites its citizens.

Ms Frohlich, 58, a schoolteacher from Hanover who became a member of the Red Army Faction and West Germany's notorious Revolutionary Cells, is accused of murder and taking part in an attack by explosives resulting in deaths.

She is accused of playing a key role in a April 1982 car bomb attack outside a restaurant in the Rue Marboeuf, Paris, which killed a pregnant passerby and injured 63 more people, 10 of them seriously.

Investigators also believe it was she who planted the explosives that blew up a Paris-Toulouse express train the previous month, leaving five dead and 30 injured.

The orders for both attacks were given by Carlos, the terrorist born Ilich Ramirez Sanchez in Venezuela, because he was peeved at the French authorities for arresting his wife, Magdalena Kopp, in February that year.

Carlos, now a portly 50, is blamed for more than 80 deaths and hundreds of injuries during a spectacular career in the 1970s and 80s.

He is serving a 50-year sentence at Paris's forbidding La Santé prison for murdering two French policemen and their Lebanese informant in 1975.

In the two-month run-up to his wife's trial, scheduled for April 15 1982, Carlos embarked on a bloody bombing and shooting spree to persuade the French authorities to release her.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: A Moscow court ruled yesterday that the fraud charges against the head of the country's biggest independent media empire were unsubstantiated and illegal.
fields.body:
Russian fraud charges 'illegal'

A Moscow court ruled yesterday that the fraud charges against the head of the country's biggest independent media empire were unsubstantiated and illegal.

The Media Most head Vladimir Gusinsky is under house arrest in Spain, where he was detained earlier this month at the request of Russian officials seeking his extradition. Russian prosecutors will appeal against the decision.
AP, Moscow

Gangsters hit armoured van

An audacious gang of robbers attacked an armoured van with a rocket launcher yesterday just 100 metres from the Paris ring road, French police sources said.

At least one guard was wounded in the gun battle that followed in the south-eastern suburb of Gentilly, and several vehicles were set on fire.
Reuters, Paris

Knicker-lift to North Korea

A coalition of South Korean religious and civic groups has begun a campaign to donate 1m pieces of underwear to help hunger-stricken North Koreans weather the bitter winter.

The first shipment of 17,000 pieces donated by a South Korean Buddhist organisation will be shipped next week, organisers say.
AP, Seoul

Freed Neo-Nazi held in stabbing

Three neo-Nazi youths, one of whom was released last month after the murder of an Algerian immigrant, stabbed a man in the back in a hate attack early yesterday in Cottbus, eastern Germany, local police said. The victim received a one-inch stab wound.
AP, Berlin

webTitle: Right elects Serb warlord's heirs

fields.headline: Right elects Serb warlord's heirs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The ghost of the murdered paramilitary leader Zeljko Raznatovic, more commonly known as Arkan, has returned to haunt Serbia: the party he founded captured seats for the first time in Saturday's parliamentary elections.
fields.body:
The ghost of the murdered paramilitary leader Zeljko Raznatovic, more commonly known as Arkan, has returned to haunt Serbia: the party he founded captured seats for the first time in Saturday's parliamentary elections.

Arkan's fellow paramilitary Borislav Pelevic leads his Serbian Unity party (SSJ), which shocked analysts by sweeping into parliament with 14 MPs. None of the national pollsters had predicted a resurgence of the Serbian right.

The party's main support comes from hardcore Serb nationalists who have not abandoned the deposed president Slobodan Milosevic's vision of a "greater Serbia". Together the SSJ and the rightwing Radical party took more than 10% of the vote.

"Ten per cent of the population is voting for the radical solution," the political columnist Aleksandar Tijanic said, adding that the SSJ had benefited from disillusioned Socialist voters.

Others say its rise was the result of the low turnout.

Mr Pelevic further aroused moderate Serb fears yesterday when he announced that he would stand for the Serb presidency in the election due in the middle of next year.

He came to prominence as a member of Arkan's Serbian Volunteer Guard - a notorious unit known as the Tigers - during the war with Croatia, and was wounded in Krajina. He is remembered for his eulogy at Arkan's funeral.

Arkan was killed in January at the Intercontinental hotel in Belgrade. Some blamed Mr Milosevic for the murder, others said it was a mafia settling of scores. Mr Pelevic said his commander died at the hands of the CIA.

The party describes itself as centrist, but analysts say it represents the extreme right.

"They are thinking about greater Serbia," Srdjan Bogosavljevic, a statistical analyst at a Belgrade polling agency, said. "They are saying they will protect all Serbs wherever they are."

webTitle: Mitterrand's son to seek bail in arms case

fields.headline: Mitterrand's son to seek bail in arms case
fields.trailText: The son of the late president François Mitterrand will ask to be freed on bail today after spending Christmas in prison for his alleged role in illicit weapons sales to Angola.
fields.body:
The son of the late president François Mitterrand will ask to be freed on bail today after spending Christmas in prison for his alleged role in illicit weapons sales to Angola.

Jean-Christophe Mitterrand, who was his father's special adviser on African affairs for six years, was jailed last week on suspicion of influence peddling, complicity in arms trafficking, and abuse of funds in connection with big sales of Russian arms to Angola in the early 1990s.

Investigators are trying to find out why, in 1997 and 1998, a numbered Swiss bank account in his name was credited with up to £1.3m by Brenco Trading International, a firm owned by the accused arms dealer Pierre Falcone.

French newspapers reported that Mr Mitterrand, 54, had told the police that £500,000 of the money belonged to him and had been temporarily placed in a Brenco account, while the rest represented "consultancy fees" paid to him by Brenco.

According to the sources he said that at the beginning of the 1990s he advised Mr Falcone to open talks with the Angolan ruling party, the MPLA, and its leader, Jose Eduardo Dos Santos, who became president in 1992.

Thanks to this advise, Mr Falcone arranged loans - including one from the French bank Paribas, now part of BNP Paribas - for the Angolan regime, guaranteed by income from future oil production.

The police suspect that the money paid for Russian tanks, helicopters and MiG fighters, worth more than £345m which Brenco Trading allegedly sold illicitly to Luanda in 1993 and 1994, when the regime appeared to be losing ground to Jonas Savimbi's Unita forces.

Mr Mitterrand, a former Africa correspondent for Agence France-Presse, joined his father's Elysée Palace staff in 1984 and headed the president's so-called "Africa cell" from 1986 to 1992, handling the highly complex relations between France and the leaders of its former colonies.

Other leading figures allegedly involved in the scandal are the former interior minister Charles Pasqua, a former senior civil servant, Jean-Charles Marchiani, and a former director of the state arms export company, Bernard Poussier.

Of Mr Mitterand's two main alleged associates, Mr Falcone was jailed on December 1and an arrest warrant has been issued for Russian-born businessman Arkadi Gaidamak.

Mr Gaidamak rose to prominence in France by helping to negotiate the release of two French pilots shot down by Bosnian Serbs in 1995. He also holds the French record for unpaid taxes - about £50m.

Simon Taylor of the British organisation Global Witness, which published a report earlier this year on illicit arms deals and the civil war in Angola, said that two Brenco International subsidiaries had taken over most of the work of procuring weapons, equipment and food for the Angolan army.

"Far from being simply another French corruption scandal, the real story is wide-reaching and involves oil companies, offshore financial centres, international banks and highest-level French and Angolan officials," he said.

Kickbacks and rake-offs in Angola now rivalled the scale of state robbery in Abacha's Nigeria and Mobutu's Zaire, he added.
