webTitle: Beckers touch a US nerve

fields.headline: Beckers touch a US nerve
fields.standfirst: Custody case may deepen criticism of alleged German bias
fields.trailText: Custody case may deepen criticism of alleged German bias.
fields.body:
The acrimonious split between Boris Becker and his wife, Barbara, could intensify a long-standing and emotionally charged dispute between Germany and the United States.

According to a report at the weekend, the retired tennis star's lawyers lodged a case in the German courts on Friday requiring Mrs Becker to return their children from Florida to the family home in Munich. The report said that in asking the German legal authorities to act, Becker, 33, cited the international agreement governing abductions.

His decision will focus attention on Germany's attitude to international "tug-of-love" custody disputes: America and other countries have repeatedly accused it of unfairly siding with the German partner.

Soon after the announcement of the Beckers' separation earlier this month, Barbara Becker flew with her two sons, Noah Gabriel, six, and Elias Balthasar, one, to the family's holiday apartment in the Florida resort of Fisher Island, near Miami.

Becker's spokesman said last week that the three-times Wimbledon champion planned to fly to Florida on Saturday, apparently with the intention of spending Christmas with his children.

The tabloid Bild am Sonntag, which published what it said were the reference numbers of Becker's petitions, reported that he had applied for sole custody of his two boys. Because of the holiday period, there was no official available to confirm or deny the report, but it was consistent with an earlier legal move by Becker.

After his wife sued for alimony and child support on December 8, Becker asked Miami-Dade circuit court to dismiss her action. His petition asserted, among other things, that the couple had always resided in Germany, that his wife had abandoned their marital home in Munich, and that, without consulting him, she had enrolled their eldest son in a Florida school.

Mrs Becker is the daughter of a German mother and a US serviceman who was based in Germany.

A judge in Miami is to rule on January 8 whether the case should be heard in a US or German court.

The Becker dispute is edging into perhaps the most sensitive area of German-US relations. Earlier this year both houses of the US Congress unanimously approved resolutions condemning Germany and four other countries for "consistently violating" the 1980 Hague convention.

President Bill Clinton raised Germany's record when he met Chancellor Gerhard Schröder in June. He said afterwards that it was one of the three issues dominating their talks, along with Russia and missile defence.

The Hague convention - signed by the US, Germany and 52 other states - was reported as having been cited by Becker in his application to the German federal courts. The convention says that abducted children should be returned swiftly to their country of habitual residence, unless this would put them at grave risk.

This appears to favour Becker, but there are complicating factors, and if a Miami ruling hands the matter to the German courts at the outset it can be counted on to outrage campaigners and legislators who believe foreigners cannot expect a fair deal from German justice. According to Washington, American courts return to other countries 90% of the children abducted to the US; German courts asked to decide cases involving Americans returned barely 40%.

Among those campaigning for a change is the wife of the British ambassador to Washington, Lady Catherine Meyer. She has had limited access to her two sons since her former German husband took them to Germany in 1994.

Becker announced earlier this month that he and his wife of seven years were to break up. On December 15 he filed for divorce. His custody peteition last week was said by legal experts to have increased the chances of the US court ceding jurisdiction to Germany, where maintenance settlements are lower.

The Beckers signed a prenuptial agreement. It states, according to the Miami Daily Business Review, that custody and divorce suits must be filed in Germany and that Mrs Becker is not entitled to alimony. She got a sum equivalent to £1.6m on marrying.

The agreement was reported to stipulate that, in the event of a divorce, child custody would be shared, but any offspring would live primarily with Mrs Becker.

This would be subject to renegotiation if either partner left Germany.

webTitle: Deutsche Bank chief dies in crash

fields.headline: Deutsche Bank chief dies in crash
fields.trailText: Deutsche Bank last night paid tribute to Edson Mitchell, 47, the London-based head of its global markets and equities divisions, who was killed while flying to his holiday home near Rangeley, Maine, in the United States.
fields.byline: Agencies  in London and Rangeley, Maine
fields.body:
Deutsche Bank last night paid tribute to Edson Mitchell, 47, the London-based head of its global markets and equities divisions, who was killed while flying to his holiday home near Rangeley, Maine, in the United States.

The twin-engine aircraft in which he was travelling crashed into the side of a mountain. The pilot was also killed.

Rolf Breuer, Deutsche Bank's chairman, said: "It is with deep sadness that I heard of Edson's death. He has contributed substantially to the group's success in recent years.

"He was admired by all for his great sense of leadership, dedication to the bank's vision and his deep commitment to the people he worked with.

"The robust foundation and management structures he has laid in his field of responsibility and his visionary strategic contribution will continue to serve the bank in the future."

Mr Mitchell was appointed to Deutsche's management board in June after joining the bank in 1995. He previously worked for Merrill Lynch and Bank of America.

Mr Mitchell was an economics graduate of Colby College and later became a member of its board of trustees. With his wife, Suzan, he established the Mitchell Family professorship in economics. He held an MBA from Dartmouth College.

He was also co-founder of the Rangeley Lakes Heritage Trust, which has overseen preservation of 10,000 acres of countryside in Maine.

In addition to his widow, he is survived by his daughters Katie, Becky and Elle, and sons Erik and Scott. His children all live in the US. - Press Association and AP

webTitle: How to draw up a best value performance plan

fields.headline: How to draw up a best value performance plan
fields.standfirst: Putting a best value performance plan together can be a headache for even the most dedicated council officer. Think carefully about who you're writing it for, and you won't go far wrong, says Adrian Barker.
fields.trailText: Putting a best value performance plan together can be a headache for even the most dedicated council officer. Think carefully about who you're writing it for, and you won't go far wrong, says Adrian Barker.
fields.body:
"How do you write the perfect best value performance plan (BVPP)?" It's a trick question isn't it? But what is the trick? The trick is what you do to produce it and how you use it afterwards. Let's go back to who the plan is for and what it is there to do. There are three audiences and purposes.

1. The public. Accountability to the public is the main purpose. The plan helps people keep a check on what their local council is doing and planning. But after passing judgement, they must be able to do something about it. Their main option is voting at the next local election, but there are other ways, like bringing pressure to bear on officers or members, or participating in a best value service review. The performance plan needs to encourage such responses.

2. The government. The 1998 white paper Modern Local Government: In touch with the people introduced the idea that in best value, local authorities will "have a responsibility to central government in its role as representative of the broader national interest". In a recent MORI survey for the Audit Commission, 87% of officers said the main audience for the plan is the auditor, 73% said the DETR and only 29% said local people.

This means meeting statutory requirements and any national standards set, as well as keeping in close touch with the external auditor (without abdicating responsibility for taking decisions).

3. Members and officers. The BVPP can be a powerful mechanism for driving up performance. It is the window on plans, targets and progress towards meeting them for managers as well as the public.

These different purposes require different sorts of plan. The law requires an "official" version and a summary. The "official" plan meets the requirements of accountability to government but could also be used internally for performance management. There have been complaints over the length of BVPPs - which can be very weighty indeed.

But if the plan is not intended to be read from cover to cover, perhaps it should be longer rather than shorter, but with fewer produced. It could bring together service plans, financial and other information, either within the BVPP or in a separate, "reference" version.

As a public document, the "official" plan helps promote accountability to the public, even if most people don't read it directly. The summary, though, is the relevant document for most people. Rather than just one, a number of different summaries could be produced for different purposes and different target audiences.

So, if the BVPP is for accountability to the public, to government and for internal improvement, what are the implications for the plan in its various forms?

The "official" plan
The official plan brings together lots of useful information in one place. That means it should be:

Accurate and clear
 Use good and reliable performance information systems
 Write in plain language
 Give clear explanations
 Provide a glossary

Accessible
 Remember to provide an index
 Make good use of the contents page
 Use clear headings, sub-headings and cross references so people can find their way round the document
 Put it on the web, both as an Acrobat document but also make use of all the electronic navigation aids available
 Make it available in different languages and formats (audio, braille, etc.)
 Make it easily available.

Meaningful and useful
 Performance information should have some context or reference point for it to make sense to people
 Provide comparisons with other authorities, organisations in other sectors and over time for all performance indicators
 Provide concrete illustrations which relate to people's everyday lives
 Provide targets not just for the next year but for three years, five years and even further ahead, with explanations how they are to be met
 Provide the confidence that targets have not just been plucked out of the air!

Promote accountability
 Encourage feedback
 Make it easy to respond
 Provide a range of options to allow people to respond to the plan and get involved with the council

Summaries
Summaries have to engage interest, attracting people and maintaining their attention. You can learn some lessons from tabloid journalism, broadcasting or the better internet sites. However, the government says the summary also needs to "offer a fair and accurate reflection of information within the plans themselves".

Other things to consider are:

Address burning local issues
 Make good use of graphics and maybe cartoons
 Keep it short. How many pages of any other organisation's corporate report are you prepared to wade through at the breakfast table?
 Encourage and help people to respond by providing contact names and numbers, easy to complete forms etc.

Disseminating the information from the plan in other ways Any one individual could easily get performance plan information via their local radio station, CD Rom, voluntary body's newsletter, internet, from friends or acquaintances or posters in council outlets. The authority can influence and manage - if not totally control - communications through all of these channels. This requires taking a strategic approach to disseminating the information and integrating it with the rest of corporate communications. Making use of communication channels that already exist can be both cheap and effective so it is worth investing the time to explore the options available.

So, the trick isn't to write a perfect performance plan. It's about:
 Getting the right planning, performance management and performance information systems which the plan reflects
 Producing the plan in all sorts of formats which will support those internal systems, but which will also
 Reaching out to all parts of the community to explain what the authority is planning, how it has done and encouraging responses and participation.

Quite a trick if you can manage it.

 Adrian Barker is a senior best value consultant for the Improvement and Development Agency (IDeA)

webTitle: Obituary: Sir Jimmy Shand

fields.headline: Sir Jimmy Shand
fields.standfirst: Strict-tempo hero of Scottish musical nostalgia
fields.trailText: Strict-tempo hero of Scottish musical nostalgia.
fields.body:
Jimmy Shand, who has died at the age of 92, was the musical icon of Scotland's tartan sub-culture. Over more than half a century, his name was synonymous with a certain style of Scottish music and with a nostalgic image of Scotland which has proved eminently marketable around the world.

His recordings sold by the million and, from the 1940s to the 1970s, the name of Jimmy Shand and his Band would fill halls throughout the United Kingdom as well as in any centre of the Scottish diaspora, New York's Carnegie Hall included. In 1955, his Bluebell Polka was one of the most unlikely top 20 entrants of even that eclectic musical era.

Shand remained a most unlikely figure of show business celebrity. While the band, led by his own button-key accordion, produced music to set even the most reluctant toes tapping, their stage appearance often bordered on the funereal. Shand would allow himself little more than a shy grin and a few words. His was really a band for dancing to, and it was his strict sense of timing, as well as his technical skill, that set him apart. Phil Cunningham, one of the most innovative of present-day Scottish accordion players, described him as "a human metronome".

Shand's contribution to popularising Scottish music was immense, although it also did much to channel perceptions of it into a particular style. There is a contradiction between the free-flowing ceilidh tradition and strict tempo dance music. Shand had thousands of superb imitators - tartan jackets and all - but few, until recently, broke out of the limiting format of two accordions, piano, fiddle, double-bass and drums; the stereotype was reinforced by BBC television's White Heather Club series of the 1960s, built around him.

Like many talented and successful Scots, Shand came from a mining background. He was born at East Wemyss, in Fife, left school at 14 and went straight into the local pit. Conditions were terrible, and the 1926 general strike brought his career as a miner to an end. He spoke movingly in later life of his decision not to go back down the pit, though his bond with the mining communities of Fife remained extremely strong.

Since childhood, he had been picking up tunes on his father's melodeon, a close relative of the button-key accordion. When he visited a music shop in Dundee, the owner gave him a job as a salesman. He thus got to know which of the better-off families bought sheet music, and sought out their houses so that he could listen to them playing and add to his knowledge.

In 1933, he made his first record, and by the following year was broadcasting for the BBC Scottish Home Service. His reputation grew steadily, but it was only after the war that he put together the Jimmy Shand Band.

The former Labour MP, Willie MacKelvey, recalls that his father was the "second box" player. The MacKelveys lived in a spacious new council house in Dundee, which, because it accommodated a piano, became the practice place as the band prepared for an increasingly hectic schedule of one-night stands, television appearances and overseas tours. The neighbours would hang out of their windows to listen.

Whenever possible, Shand would head back home to Auchtermuchty, in Fife, after gigs - sometimes from as far away as the south of England. He had been a motorcycle racer in his youth and retained a love of fast vehicles and white-knuckle driving. Otherwise, his lifestyle was modest. Whatever international hotel they might be in, he would famously order for the band: "Sausage, egg and chips for six".

In retirement, honours were showered upon him, culminating in a knighthood last year. There was never any sign of this affecting Shand. He was a shrewd, dignified, Scottish gentleman whose greatest ambition was to be at home in Auchtermuchty among his own people.

He is survived by his wife Anne, whom he married in 1936, and their two sons.

James Shand, accordionist and bandleader, born January 28 1908; died December 23 2000

webTitle: Signs of recession turn up heat on Bush

fields.headline: Signs of recession turn up heat on Bush
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: President-elect George W Bush is banking on his promises of $1.3 trillion in tax cuts to steer the United States away from recession as two indices of economic health are expected to produce unfriendly news this week.
fields.body:
President-elect George W Bush is banking on his promises of $1.3 trillion in tax cuts to steer the United States away from recession as two indices of economic health are expected to produce unfriendly news this week.

Wall Street analysts are warning that the gauge of leading economic indicators, published later today, is likely to show fresh evidence of economic slowdown, while the monitor of consumer confidence to be published tomorrow is likely to be worse.

"Now that the economy appears to be slipping, tax cuts are even more important," said Philip Crane, the Republican expected to be the next chairman of the House of Representatives ways and means committee.

"The economic case for tax cuts is that this is the absolute perfect time to cut taxes. We are on the eve of a potential recession. The right time to cut taxes is when the economy is really slowing down, which means that Bush has to pass this immediately."

An immediate indicator of consumer confidence - the volume of Christmas shopping - was being massaged by talk that it is the week after, rather than before, the holiday that really matters.

Business at US department stores was up 2% in December, according to a survey by RCT Systems Inc. That compared with a 6% or 7% rise last year and is attributed to weak stocks, job fears, high energy prices and bad weather across much of the country. The big stores, many of which started their sales well before Christmas, say that this week can account for 11-17% of sales.

Several leading companies announced lay-offs before Christmas and more are resorting to recruitment freezes and limits, including Eastman Kodak, General Motors and News Corp.

"Companies that have slowdowns are waiting to see what happens after the first of the year," said Allen Salikof, chief executive officer of Management Recruiters International, based in Cleveland. "The next six or eight weeks will determine what happens with staffing."

The one sector that is showing signs of strong growth is bankruptcy lawyers. "In the last two months I have definitely noticed much greater interest in immediate hiring in bankruptcy groups and an interest in staffing up even if the departments aren't exceedingly busy yet," said Jeff Schneider, president of Schneider Legal Search, based in New York. "Nobody wants to be caught short-staffed."

The most recent measure ment of consumer confidence, by the University of Michigan, showed the fourth-largest monthly fall since the exercise began 22 years ago. "The last time consumer confidence declined, a comparable extent was prior to the recessions in 1990 and 1980," said Richard Curtin, director of the survey of consumer sentiment, which showed a drop from 107.6 in November to 98.4 this month.

"Consumers have lost their optimism about the outlook for the economy but they have not become pessimists. While the December plunge does not indicate a recession will take place in 2001, if losses were to continue during the months ahead the likelihood of a recession would rise substantially."

Republican leaders have been talking down the economy for some time, not least to lay the blame on the departing Clinton administration.

But even some rightwing economists doubt easing the tax burden would be enough and fear that a prolonged debate might dissuade the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates rapidly enough.

"The problem with tax cuts is their timing," said William Niskanen, chairman of the economically conservative Cato Institute thinktank. "They don't kick in in time to be a solution for economic weakness. That's the awkward thing."

webTitle: Websites cannot replace the human touch

fields.headline: Websites cannot replace the human touch
fields.trailText: Personal finance websites are great for gathering information, but they are not replacing the need for face to face meetings with independent financial advisers (IFA). That, at least, is what financial advisers told Forrester Research for its new report 'Online financial advice hits the UK'.
fields.body:
Personal finance websites are great for gathering information, but they are not replacing the need for face to face meetings with independent financial advisers (IFA). That, at least, is what financial advisers told Forrester Research for its new report 'Online financial advice hits the UK'.

Websites carry marketing and product information comfortably, they say, and most will invest in good site functionality - offering interactive calculators, performance tables, portfolio valuations and product searches - but most will also have the option for face to face meetings with clients when they are making final decisions. Clients buy advice, not products, from IFAs, they say, and advice is something the internet cannot provide.

One respondent said: "I think clients like the personal touch. The difference between the best and worst financial decision is significant. The real cost of choosing the wrong product is massive: it outweighs the cost of advice. If you are looking at an off-the-peg suit, then that's fine. Our clients look for tailor-made advice."

Another said: "Clients need to be able to interpret and compare products. Access to so much information may improve the clients' awareness, but it also increases uncertainty. There is a psychological issue here: the need for human reassurance from IFAs."

But in the long run, demographic pressures are likely to see the internet play a more, not less, important role. As one IFA remarked: "Clients who have investment money are older and less used to the internet. Younger ones may be more comfortable with technology but are not the ones with the money. Until the level of wealth filters down or older people become more used to technology, things will remain the same with IFAs."

However, this wealth will filter down and it will filter down to today's teenagers and twenty-somethings, already used to buying simple financial products, such as car insurance, credit cards, bank accounts and loans, over the web.

This group, particularly the more financially savvy among them, will want to manage as much of their finances as they can, independently and online. Chances are they will only visit IFAs for specialised, tailor-made advice on complex, long-term products such as pensions and investments, tax planning or setting up a trust fund for the kids.
